question_text: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because her lips turned blue for several minutes earlier during feeding. Her father reports that the patient had similar episodes while playing that resolved quickly. During the examination, she sits calmly in her father's lap. When her ears are examined, the patient begins to cry and her lips and fingers begin to turn blue. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because her lips turned blue for several minutes earlier during feeding. Her father reports that the patient had similar episodes while playing that resolved quickly. During the examination, she sits calmly in her father's lap. When her ears are examined, the patient begins to cry and her lips and fingers begin to turn blue. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The cyanotic episode described here is characteristic of the tet spells seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
learning_objective: Recognize tetralogy of Fallot, and recall its characteristic ECG finding.

answers.content: Anomalous pulmonary venous return on MR angiography
answers.explanation_why: Anomalous pulmonary venous return on MR angiography is diagnostic of total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). Although TAPVR is survivable and can cause central cyanosis in patients with a right-to-left shunt, symptoms are continuous rather than episodic, as seen here.

A machine-like murmur over the heart is pathognomonic for patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). PDA is usually an acyanotic congenital condition because most blood passes through normal circulation and thus sufficient oxygen saturation is maintained; only a small amount of blood is pumped through the PDA. Furthermore, PDA causes continuous symptoms, as opposed to the episodic symptoms described for this patient.

A diminutive left ventricle on echocardiogram is seen in hypoplastic left heart syndrome, which can also present with central cyanosis. Because the left heart is unable to adequately perfuse the peripheral tissues, the associated cyanosis would be constant, rather than episodic.

answers.content: Decreased blood pressure in both lower extremities
answers.explanation_why: Decreased blood pressure in the lower extremities is characteristic of aortic coarctation, which presents with differential cyanosis (i.e., of the lower extremities) instead of the central cyanosis (i.e., blue lips and fingers) seen in this patient. Moreover, aortic coarctation rarely causes hypoxemia; in the rare case of hypoxemia, it is usually mild. Finally, aortic coarctation results in chronic rather than episodic symptoms.

answers.content: Pulmonary vascular congestion on chest x-ray
answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary vascular congestion seen on chest x-ray is a sign of left heart failure, with subsequent “backing up” of blood into the pulmonary vasculature, leading to enlarged pulmonary vessels. Although pulmonary vascular congestion is classically associated with congestive heart failure in adults (especially elderly patients), some congenital cardiac defects can also cause this finding (e.g., truncus arteriosus, total anomalous pulmonary venous return). In TOF, there is a right ventricular outflow obstruction, leading to decreased blood flow to the pulmonary vasculature and, consequently, decreased pulmonary vascular markings on chest x-ray.

Right axis deviation is typically seen on ECG in cases of TOF due to right ventricular hypertrophy. The thickened myocardium in the right ventricle produces increased electrical activity, which shifts the axis of cardiac depolarization. TOF also involves an overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, and pulmonary stenosis. It is the most common congenital cyanotic heart lesion. In addition to these ECG findings, a chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped heart also supports the diagnosis. Echocardiography is used to confirm TOF.

images.title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of FallotThe cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

question_text:
A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being shot in the abdomen during a violent altercation. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 118/min and regular, and blood pressure is 88/65 mm Hg. Examination shows cool extremities. Abdominal examination shows a 2.5-cm entrance wound in the left upper quadrant at the midclavicular line, below the left costal margin. Focused ultrasound shows free fluid in the left upper quadrant. Which of the following sets of hemodynamic changes is most likely in this patient?

Cardiac output (CO)
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)
Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)
Central venous pressure (CVP)

A
↑
↓
↓
↓

B
↓
↓
↑
↓

C
↓
↓
↑
↑

D
↓
↓
↓
↓

E
↓
↑
↑
↑
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being shot in the abdomen during a violent altercation. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 118/min and regular, and blood pressure is 88/65 mm Hg. Examination shows cool extremities. Abdominal examination shows a 2.5-cm entrance wound in the left upper quadrant at the midclavicular line, below the left costal margin. Focused ultrasound shows free fluid in the left upper quadrant. Which of the following sets of hemodynamic changes is most likely in this patient? Cardiac output (CO) Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) Central venous pressure (CVP) A ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓ B ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓ C ↓ ↓ ↑ ↑ D ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ E ↓ ↑ ↑ ↑
hint: The patient has many signs of hypovolemic shock, including evidence of bleeding, decreased blood pressure, rapid pulse, cool extremities, and free fluid in the abdomen.
learning_objective: Recognize hypovolemic shock, and recall its hemodynamic findings.

answers.explanation_why: The combination of ↑ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↓ SVR, and ↓ CVP is seen in some cases of distributive shock (e.g., early septic shock), not in hypovolemic shock. Distributive shock is sometimes referred to as warm shock because it involves inappropriate peripheral vasodilation (causing ↓ CVP, ↓ SVR, and thus ↓ PCWP) and increased CO, which leads to excessive blood delivery to the limbs, resulting in inappropriately warm limbs in a hypotensive patient. This patient's limbs are cool, which indicates appropriate peripheral vasoconstriction in an attempt to maintain adequate blood pressure. In addition, this patient has no history of infection that would predispose to septic shock.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↑ SVR, and ↓ CVP is characteristic of hypovolemic shock (hemorrhagic shock). Hemorrhage (e.g., after a gunshot wound) leads to intravascular volume depletion, which decreases venous return to the right atrium (as evidenced by ↓ CVP). Reduced venous return to the right heart results in decreased blood delivery to the left atrium (evident in ↓ PCWP) and consequently low left ventricular end diastolic volume (i.e., decreased preload). Low preload causes decreased CO (because the heart cannot pump blood that is not there). Because low CO leads to hypotension, the peripheral vasculature constricts (↑ SVR) in an attempt to maintain blood pressure that is adequate for organ perfusion.

See “Overview of the types of shock” table.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↑ SVR, and ↑ CVP is characteristic of obstructive shock (e.g., massive pulmonary embolism), not hypovolemic shock. In obstructive shock, blood flow from the right heart to the left heart is blocked, which causes blood to “back up” into the right atrium, causing increased CVP. Insufficient blood is delivered to the LA, leading to decreased LA pressure (and thus ↓ PCWP) and little preload for the LV (causing ↓ CO). Low CO results in hypotension, which induces peripheral vascular constriction (and thus ↑ SVR) in an attempt to maintain adequate blood pressure. This patient's history of a gunshot wound to the abdomen and free fluid in the abdomen suggest a different form of shock.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↓ PCWP, ↓ SVR, and ↓ CVP is seen in some cases of distributive shock (especially neurogenic shock), not in hypovolemic shock. Neurogenic shock typically results from severe CNS trauma (e.g., spinal cord transection) and is associated with other neurologic abnormalities (e.g., paralysis). Neurogenic shock is believed to be caused by loss of autonomic control of cardiovascular parameters due to CNS damage. Heart rate is characteristically low in neurogenic shock (likely due to excessive vagal tone), which leads to decreased CO. SVR is low because of peripheral vasodilation due to loss of sympathetic tone. Peripheral vasodilation causes decreased venous return to the heart, leading to low CVP and consequently low LA pressure (and thus low PCWP). This patient has no history or physical findings to suggest neurologic injury and he is tachycardic on examination.

The combination of ↓ CO, ↑ PCWP, ↑ SVR, and ↑ CVP is characteristic of cardiogenic shock, not hypovolemic shock. If the heart is unable to pump adequately, CO decreases. Blood then “backs up” into the left atrium, causing increased LA pressure (and thus ↑ PCWP). Increased LA pressure leads to increased right heart pressures, causing high CVP. Because decreased CO leads to hypotension, the peripheral vasculature constricts (↑ SVR) in an attempt to maintain blood pressure that is adequate for organ perfusion. This patient has no history to suggest a pump dysfunction (e.g., history of heart failure or arrhythmia) that would predispose to cardiogenic shock.

question_text:
A 71-year old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath that have lasted for 3 days. During the last month, he has also noticed dark-colored urine. He had an upper respiratory infection 6 weeks ago. He underwent cholecystectomy at the age of 30 years. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include simvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. He immigrated from Italy 50 years ago. He appears pale. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 128/98 mm Hg. Auscultation of the heart shows a grade 4/6 systolic murmur over the right second intercostal space that radiates to the carotids. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin

8.3 g/dL 

Hematocrit
24%

Leukocyte count
9000/mm^3

Platelet count
180,000/mm^3

Haptoglobin

15 mg/dL (N = 41–165) 

Serum

 Na^+

138 mEq/L 

 K^+

4.5 mEq/L 

 Cl^-

102 mEq/L 

 HCO_3^-

24 mEq/L 

 Urea nitrogen

20 mg/dL 

 Creatinine

1.2 mg/dL 

 Total bilirubin

1.8 mg/dL 

 Lactate dehydrogenase

290 U/L 

A direct antiglobulin test is negative. Stool testing for occult blood is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's anemia?
content_preview: A 71-year old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath that have lasted for 3 days. During the last month, he has also noticed dark-colored urine. He had an upper respiratory infection 6 weeks ago. He underwent cholecystectomy at the age of 30 years. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include simvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. He immigrated from Italy 50 years ago. He appears pale. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 128/98 mm Hg. Auscultation of the heart shows a grade 4/6 systolic murmur over the right second intercostal space that radiates to the carotids. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 8.3 g/dL Hematocrit 24% Leukocyte count 9000/mm3 Platelet count 180,000/mm3 Haptoglobin 15 mg/dL (N = 41–165) Serum Na+ 138 mEq/L K+ 4.5 mEq/L Cl- 102 mEq/L HCO3- 24 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 20 mg/dL Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL Total bilirubin 1.8 mg/dL Lactate dehydrogenase 290 U/L A direct antiglobulin test is negative. Stool testing for occult blood is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's anemia?
hint: The patient's dark urine, increased LDH, and decreased hemoglobin, hematocrit, and haptoglobin are consistent with intravascular hemolytic anemia (IHA). The presence of a loud systolic murmur in the second intercostal space with radiation to the carotid region suggests aortic stenosis (AS). Calcific AS can cause IHA due to increased turbulent flow.
learning_objective: Recognize intravascular hemolytic anemia due to aortic stenosis, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Corticosteroids are indicated for patients with warm agglutinin hemolytic anemia (WAHA). However, the direct Coombs test is positive in patients with WAHA and indicates the presence of antibodies against RBC membranes. Furthermore, patients with WAHA typically present with extravascular hemolysis.

Hydroxyurea is used to decrease the frequency and severity of sickle cell crises. A patient with sickle cell anemia (SCA) may develop acute chest syndrome characterized by acute shortness of breath and tachypnea due to sickling of erythrocytes within the pulmonary vasculature. The Coombs test would also be negative. However, SCA usually results in extravascular hemolysis within the spleen. IHA, as well as a loud systolic murmur in the right 2^nd intercostal space, suggests a different diagnosis.

Iron supplementation may be given to patients with hemolytic anemia who develop iron deficiency due to hemoglobinuria or hemosiderinuria following intravascular hemolysis. Because iron studies have not been conducted in this patient, it is uncertain as to whether or not iron deficiency is present.

IHA is a common finding in patients with moderate and severe AS and develops as a result of high-velocity, turbulent blood flow near the stenotic valve, which causes mechanical destruction of erythrocytes (macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia). Because IHA suggests severe AS, aortic valve replacement (AVR) is typically indicated. This procedure lowers the aortic transvalvular pressure gradient and consequently decreases the degree of RBC fragmentation. Prosthetic heart valves are a risk factor for macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia, but the condition is much less likely to develop with modern prosthetics. AVR is the only treatment that can improve and possibly cure IHA in patients with severe AS.

Some medications may cause IHA, particularly in patients with G6PD deficiency. This patient takes simvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin, none of which are known to cause IHA. Medications known to trigger IHA in patients with G6PD deficiency include primaquine, dapsone, and sulfonamide antibiotics.

question_text:
A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe retrosternal pain radiating to the back and left shoulder for 4 hours. The pain began after attending a farewell party for his coworker at a local bar. He had 3–4 episodes of nonbilious vomiting before the onset of the pain. He has hypertension. His father died of cardiac arrest at the age of 55 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 23 years and drinks 2–3 beers daily. His current medications include amlodipine and valsartan. He appears pale. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung base and crepitus is palpable over the thorax. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
16.5 g/dL

Leukocyte count
11,100/mm^3

Serum

 Na^+

133 mEq/L

 K^+

3.2 mEq/L

 Cl^-

98 mEq/L

 HCO_3^-

30 mEq/L

 Creatinine
1.4 mg/dL

ECG shows sinus tachycardia with left ventricular hypertrophy. An x-ray of the chest shows a left-sided pleural effusion and mediastinal widening. Treatment with intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotics is started. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe retrosternal pain radiating to the back and left shoulder for 4 hours. The pain began after attending a farewell party for his coworker at a local bar. He had 3–4 episodes of nonbilious vomiting before the onset of the pain. He has hypertension. His father died of cardiac arrest at the age of 55 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 23 years and drinks 2–3 beers daily. His current medications include amlodipine and valsartan. He appears pale. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung base and crepitus is palpable over the thorax. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 16.5 g/dL Leukocyte count 11,100/mm3 Serum Na+ 133 mEq/L K+ 3.2 mEq/L Cl- 98 mEq/L HCO3- 30 mEq/L Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL ECG shows sinus tachycardia with left ventricular hypertrophy. An x-ray of the chest shows a left-sided pleural effusion and mediastinal widening. Treatment with intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotics is started. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This patient's history of vomiting, alcohol consumption, signs of shock, and crepitus over the thorax should raise concern for esophageal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome). The x-ray findings (widened mediastinum and unilateral pleural effusion) further support this diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize esophageal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome), and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Contrast esophagography (e.g., barium swallow) is used to confirm the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome in hemodynamically stable patients who are able to cooperate (rupture can be verified with escaping contrast and its location and size estimated). However, contrast esophagography with gastrografin (a water-soluble contrast) is preferred over barium swallow because barium causes an inflammatory response in the mediastinum, which can lead to mediastinitis and fibrosis. In addition, contrast esophagography should not be performed in patients who are hemodynamically unstable.

CT scan of the chest is used to confirm the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome in patients who are hemodynamically unstable or otherwise not suited to undergo contrast esophagography. CT findings of Boerhaave syndrome include pneumomediastinum, esophageal wall thickening, pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, subcutaneous emphysema, and pleural effusion. While bedside testing is usually preferred over CT scan for unstable patients (e.g., TEE to confirm aortic dissection), there is no bedside imaging available to reliably confirm the diagnosis of esophageal rupture. In this hemodynamically unstable patient (low systolic pressure, high pulse) with inconclusive x-ray findings, a CT scan of the chest should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and aid in procedure planning. In patients who are hemodynamically stable, contrast esophagography with gastrografin is the preferred confirmatory test.

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) may be used to diagnose Boerhaave syndrome if other imaging techniques are inconclusive. Because EGD increases the likelihood of an esophageal leak, it is typically reserved for patients with a poorly localized esophageal perforation and in whom endoscopic treatment is already indicated.

In the past, aortography was used to detect aortic dissection. This patient has severe retrosternal pain radiating to his back and is hemodynamically unstable, which may be seen in patients with aortic dissection. However, the patient's recent alcohol intake followed by several episodes of vomiting and the presence of crepitus over the thorax favor the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome, which is confirmed with a different method.

Transthoracic echocardiography can be used for diagnosing aortic dissection in hemodynamically unstable patients. While this patient's signs of shock, severe retrosternal pain radiating to the back, and x-ray findings may be due to aortic dissection, his recent history of alcohol intake followed by several episodes of vomiting and crepitus over the thorax support the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome, which is confirmed with a different method.

Abdominal ultrasound may be performed in the case of suspected acute pancreatitis. This patient had several vomiting episodes following alcohol consumption, accompanied by pain radiating to the back. This patient's presentation may resemble that of acute pancreatitis. But pain in acute pancreatitis is typically located in the upper abdomen, and the patient would not have crepitus over the thorax. These features support the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome instead, which is confirmed with a different method.

question_text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe epigastric discomfort and left-sided chest pain radiating to the back that began after waking up. He has also vomited several times since the pain began. He underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy the previous day for evaluation of epigastric pain. He has ischemic heart disease and underwent a coronary angioplasty 3 years ago. His mother died of pancreatic cancer when she was 60 years old. His current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, ramipril, and rosuvastatin. He is pale, anxious, and diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg in his upper extremities and 108/68 mm Hg in his lower extremities. Pulse oximetry on room air shows oxygen saturation at 98%. An S4 is audible over the precordium, in addition to crepitus over the chest. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric area. Serum studies show an initial Troponin I level of 0.03 ng/mL and 0.02 ng/mL 6 hours later. A 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia with nonspecific ST-T changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe epigastric discomfort and left-sided chest pain radiating to the back that began after waking up. He has also vomited several times since the pain began. He underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy the previous day for evaluation of epigastric pain. He has ischemic heart disease and underwent a coronary angioplasty 3 years ago. His mother died of pancreatic cancer when she was 60 years old. His current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, ramipril, and rosuvastatin. He is pale, anxious, and diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg in his upper extremities and 108/68 mm Hg in his lower extremities. Pulse oximetry on room air shows oxygen saturation at 98%. An S4 is audible over the precordium, in addition to crepitus over the chest. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric area. Serum studies show an initial Troponin I level of 0.03 ng/mL and 0.02 ng/mL 6 hours later. A 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia with nonspecific ST-T changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea, and crepitus over the chest (mediastinal emphysema) one day after an endoscopic procedure.
learning_objective: Recognize esophageal perforation.

answers.explanation_why: Pneumothorax typically manifests with chest pain and may also be accompanied by subcutaneous emphysema with crepitus. However, the pain is usually described as a sharp pain that increases with inspiration. Additionally, this patient does not seem to be in significant respiratory distress since his oxygen saturation is within the normal range (98%), all of which favors another diagnosis.

Acute pancreatitis is associated with a dull pain that radiates to the back. Fever also commonly occurs and there may even be ST-T changes. Although this patient presents with radiating chest pain to the back, fever, and nonspecific ST-T changes, his crepitus over the thorax shortly following the endoscopic procedure favors a different diagnosis.

This patient most likely has an esophageal perforation, a severe complication of the esophagogastroduodenoscopy that was performed the day before symptom onset. Iatrogenic esophageal perforation usually occurs within 24 hours of upper endoscopy. Fever may occur as a result of a secondary infection of the mediastinum or peritoneum.

Iatrogenic esophageal perforation and Boerhaave syndrome have similar clinical features, but different causes.

Patients with aortic dissection typically present with sudden, severe, “tearing” chest pain, radiating to the back, and potentially symptoms of cardiac tamponade (e.g., marked jugular venous distention, hypotension). Another important feature of aortic dissection is asymmetric blood pressures and pulses. Although this patient presents with chest pain radiating to the back, he has very similar blood pressures in his upper and lower extremities. His symptoms also occurred shortly after an endoscopic procedure, which makes another diagnosis more likely.

Acute myocardial infarction is typically characterized by acute‑onset substernal pressure in the chest, which can radiate to the left arm, neck, or jaw. Although this patient's chest pain may mimic the pain seen with MI, he presents with nonspecific ST-T changes on the ECG and normal Troponin I levels, which make the diagnosis of an acute MI less likely.

question_text: A previously healthy 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after he was involved in a motor vehicle collision. He is conscious. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years but quit 8 years ago. Physical examination shows several ecchymoses over the trunk and abdomen. The abdomen is soft, and there is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant without guarding or rebound. Vital signs are within normal limits. An x-ray of the chest shows no fractures; a 10-mm solid pulmonary nodule is present in the central portion of the right upper lung field. No previous x-rays of the patient are available. A CT scan of the chest is performed, which shows that the nodule has irregular, scalloped borders. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's pulmonary nodule?
content_preview: A previously healthy 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after he was involved in a motor vehicle collision. He is conscious. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years but quit 8 years ago. Physical examination shows several ecchymoses over the trunk and abdomen. The abdomen is soft, and there is tenderness to palpation of the right upper quadrant without guarding or rebound. Vital signs are within normal limits. An x-ray of the chest shows no fractures; a 10-mm solid pulmonary nodule is present in the central portion of the right upper lung field. No previous x-rays of the patient are available. A CT scan of the chest is performed, which shows that the nodule has irregular, scalloped borders. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's pulmonary nodule?
hint: This patient has an incidental solid solitary pulmonary nodule. Based on quantitative predictive models, the nodule has an intermediate risk for malignancy.
learning_objective: Recognize an intermediate-risk solitary pulmonary nodule, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Antituberculous therapy is used to treat pulmonary tuberculosis. Infectious granulomas (e.g., due to tuberculosis or histoplasmosis) are responsible for the majority of benign solitary pulmonary nodules. Though this patient's nodule may be caused by tuberculosis, further evaluation (e.g., tuberculin skin test, IFN-γ release assay) is required at this time prior to initiating any specific therapy.

The evaluation of an incidental solitary solid pulmonary nodule involves an assessment of the nodule's risk for malignancy. Radiological factors that increase the risk for malignancy include large nodule size (≥ 8 mm), location in the upper lung fields, and irregular, spiculated, or scalloped borders. Clinical risk factors for malignancy include age > 40 years, a history of smoking or asbestos exposure, and a positive family or personal history of malignancy. This patient's nodule has an intermediate risk for malignancy. Accordingly, further evaluation is recommended. Positron emission tomography (PET) can determine if the nodule is metabolically active and should be considered for the evaluation of low-risk or intermediate-risk nodules, which are ≥ 8 mm. FDG-avid nodules should undergo biopsy for histopathological examination. FDG-nonavid nodules should be monitored with a follow-up CT scan. Alternatively, patients with intermediate- or high-risk nodules can proceed directly to biopsy.

If a biopsy specimen is needed to further evaluate centrally located lesions, transbronchial biopsy is recommended. For peripherally located lesions, CT-guided transcutaneous biopsy is preferred.
A follow-up chest x-ray is not appropriate for reevaluating an incidental solitary solid pulmonary nodule; the best imaging modality for follow-up is a CT scan.

A follow-up CT scan in 12 months is the most appropriate next step in management for an incidental solitary solid pulmonary nodule that is 4–8 mm in size. However, this patient has a 10-mm pulmonary nodule that has an intermediate risk for malignancy.

Surgical resection with histopathologic examination of tissue can yield a definitive diagnosis of a pulmonary nodule and can be curative in the case of malignancy. However, the benefits of this procedure must be weighed against the risks; oftentimes, a less invasive procedure (e.g., biopsy) or radiological evaluation may be preferable. Surgical resection is typically reserved for large lesions (> 30 mm) or smaller lesions with concerning features based on other modalities that assess risk. Surgical resection may be needed after additional evaluation of this patient, who has a 10-mm incidental solitary solid pulmonary nodule with intermediate risk, but it is not the most appropriate next step at this time.

Reassurance without further evaluation is appropriate for incidental solitary solid pulmonary nodules that have a low risk for malignancy. It is not appropriate for this patient, who has a 10-mm solid pulmonary nodule with intermediate risk for malignancy.

question_text: Positron emission tomography is conducted and indicates a malignant nodule. Bronchoscopy with transbronchial biopsy is performed and a specimen sample of the centrally located nodule is sent for frozen section analysis. Microscopic examination of the tissue sample is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: Positron emission tomography is conducted and indicates a malignant nodule. Bronchoscopy with transbronchial biopsy is performed and a specimen sample of the centrally located nodule is sent for frozen section analysis. Microscopic examination of the tissue sample is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Smoking is especially associated with a particular kind of lung cancer.
learning_objective: Recognize lung squamous cell carcinoma, and recall its histological features.

answers.explanation_why: Large cell carcinoma of the lung is a peripheral tumor characterized by late metastases, and it has a poor prognosis. Although this condition is associated with smoking, it is less common than other types of cancer caused by smoking. Furthermore, this patient's centrally-located nodule suggests another diagnosis. On histology, large cell carcinoma is characterized by poorly differentiated pleomorphic giant cells.

Bronchial carcinoid tumor is typically characterized by hilar or perihilar opacities. Patients can develop carcinoid syndrome characterized by diarrhea, flushing, dyspnea, and wheezing. These symptoms are absent in this patient. Additionally, he has a positive smoking history and carcinoid bronchial carcinoma is usually not associated with smoking.

Lung adenocarcinoma is the most common lung cancer. However, it typically affects the peripheral parts of the lungs, rather than the central parts. Moreover, lung adenocarcinoma is more commonly seen in nonsmokers. On histology, adenocarcinoma appears as a glandular tumor with mucin-producing cells.

Lung squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. SCC is strongly associated with smoking and typically affects the central parts of the lung. On histology, SCC is a solid, epithelial tumor that can have intercellular bridges and keratin pearls. SCC is associated with hypercalcemia of malignancy due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) from tumor cells. SCC was the most common type of lung cancer prior to the mid-1980s. Nowadays, lung adenocarcinoma is the most common lung cancer.

See “WHO classification of lung cancers” table.

images.title: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
images.description: Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E staining; high magnification)There are several nests (example indicated by yellow overlay) composed of large, polygonal, atypical squamous cells with polymorphic nuclei, intercellular bridges (examples indicated by arrowheads) and evidence of keratinization (examples indicated by blue circles).These are the classic features of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with keratinization. In lung tissue, the presence of SCC can represent primary SCC of the lung or metastasis of an extrapulmonary SCC (more common). Therefore, initial diagnosis in biopsy material requires clinical exclusion of a primary extrapulmonary SCC (e.g., pharyngolaryngeal or anogenital).

answers.explanation_why: Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) typically affects the central parts of the lungs. It is a very aggressive tumor with early metastases. On histology, SCLC is characterized by small, dark blue tumor cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scarce cytoplasm. Although SCLC is strongly associated with smoking, it is not the most common lung cancer seen in smokers.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) can metastasize hematogenously to the liver, lungs, bone, and brain, and it can spread lymphatically to mesenteric, paraaortic, and pelvic lymph nodes. However, this patient has no symptoms suggestive of CRC (e.g., constitutional symptoms, iron deficiency anemia, changes in bowel habits, blood-streaked stools). Additionally, although single nodules may be seen on imaging, pulmonary metastasis is typically associated with multiple nodules.

question_text: One week after an aortic valve replacement surgery, a 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after the onset of severe, sharp chest pain. He appears pale and dyspneic but is alert, oriented, and speaks in full sentences. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 192/min and thready, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. On pulmonary examination, faint rales can be heard in the lower lung fields on both sides on auscultation. There is a midline thoracotomy scar with mild reddening but without warmth or discharge. A portion of an ECG is shown. The pattern remains unchanged after 1 minute. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
content_preview: One week after an aortic valve replacement surgery, a 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after the onset of severe, sharp chest pain. He appears pale and dyspneic but is alert, oriented, and speaks in full sentences. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 192/min and thready, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. On pulmonary examination, faint rales can be heard in the lower lung fields on both sides on auscultation. There is a midline thoracotomy scar with mild reddening but without warmth or discharge. A portion of an ECG is shown. The pattern remains unchanged after 1 minute. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
hint: The first step in the management of arrhythmias is to check heart rhythm and hemodynamic stability. This patient's ECG shows monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) lasting > 30 seconds, indicating a sustained rhythm, while chest pain, tachycardia, and hypotension suggest hemodynamic instability.
learning_objective: Recognize hemodynamically unstable ventricular tachycardia, and choose the most appropriate intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Dobutamine is a positively inotropic agent commonly used to maintain adequate blood pressure and therefore perfusion of vital organs in conditions like cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and other causes of reversible acute heart failure. Although this patient has hypotension, dobutamine is not used for acute life-threatening arrhythmia because it may worsen the tachycardia.

Epinephrine is commonly used in cases of cardiac arrest if the patient's heart rhythm would not benefit from defibrillation (asystole or pulseless electrical activity). Even though the patient is pale and dyspneic, he is still able to speak in full sentences, which rules out cardiac arrest. Because epinephrine can itself cause arrhythmia; administering it would not only be ineffective but also potentially dangerous!

Synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice for hemodynamically unstable cardiac arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and monomorphic VT with a palpable pulse. This patient has chest pain, a pulse of 192/min, and a blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg, all of which indicate hemodynamic instability due to sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. Therefore, synchronized cardioversion is the most appropriate next step in management.

Vagal maneuvers, such as the Valsalva maneuver and carotid massage, can slow down the heart rate by activating the vagus nerve to trigger a parasympathetic effect on the atrioventricular node. They are the first-line treatment in hemodynamically stable supraventricular tachycardia but would not have an effect on this patient's VT, which has an origin of impulse below the atrioventricular node.

Magnesium sulfate is only used in the management of polymorphic VT or torsades de pointes. This patient's ECG findings are suggestive of monomorphic VT, which originates from a single focus within the ventricles and is a regular, wide complex tachycardia that produces uniform QRS complexes within each lead. Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia originates from multiple ventricular foci with resultant QRS complexes varying in amplitude, axis, and duration. Magnesium sulfate would not be effective in treating this patient's arrhythmia.

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug that can be used as a second-line agent in cardiac arrest and in patients with VT who are hemodynamically stable. This patient's high heart rate (192/min), chest pain, and low blood pressure (80/50 mm Hg) indicate hemodynamic instability, which is a contraindication for amiodarone.

Defibrillation (i.e., unsynchronized cardioversion) is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with pulseless VT or with polymorphic VT and a palpable pulse. This patient is hemodynamically unstable but presents with sustained monomorphic VT, which requires a different treatment.

images.title: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia
images.description:
Single-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Rate: 192/min
– Regular rhythm
– No P or T waves are discernible because of the high ventricular rate.
– QRS complexes are broad (> 120 ms) and monomorphic (there is a similar QRS morphology in all beats).These features are characteristic of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT persisting for ≥ 30 seconds is considered sustained VT (this strip does not show the full 30-second interval).

question_text:
A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of acute shortness of breath and chest pain. The chest pain is retrosternal in nature and does not radiate. She feels nauseated but has not vomited. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Current medications include insulin, aspirin, metoprolol, and hydrochlorothiazide. She is pale and diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98°F), pulse is 136/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and absence of a radial pulse during inspiration. Crackles are heard at the lung bases bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows distant heart sounds. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
8.3 g/dL

Serum

Glucose
313 mg/dL

Urea nitrogen
130 mg/dL

Creatinine
6.0 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of acute shortness of breath and chest pain. The chest pain is retrosternal in nature and does not radiate. She feels nauseated but has not vomited. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Current medications include insulin, aspirin, metoprolol, and hydrochlorothiazide. She is pale and diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98°F), pulse is 136/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and absence of a radial pulse during inspiration. Crackles are heard at the lung bases bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows distant heart sounds. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 8.3 g/dL Serum Glucose 313 mg/dL Urea nitrogen 130 mg/dL Creatinine 6.0 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This hemodynamically unstable patient presents with Beck triad (hypotension, distant heart sounds, and jugular venous distention), pulsus paradoxus (absent pulse during inspiration), and chest pain, all of which indicate cardiac tamponade.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiac tamponade, and choose the most appropriate initial intervention.

answers.explanation_why:
Severe pericardial effusion and subsequent cardiac tamponade are life-threatening conditions that require immediate decompression with pericardiocentesis. Pericardiocentesis is indicated for hemodynamic stabilization and symptom relief before treatment of the underlying condition (e.g., with hemodialysis) can be started. This patient with diabetes has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD), likely as a result of inadequately managed hyperglycemia. CKD leads to elevation of both serum creatinine and BUN, which can result in chronic pericardial effusion due to uremia. The patient's anemia (due to decreased EPO levels) and bilateral crackles indicating pulmonary edema (due to fluid retention) also likely result from CKD.

In hemodynamically stable patients with pericardial effusion, the underlying cause should be treated first. If an effusion is due to underlying malignancy, a pericardial window is performed to continuously drain the fluid.

images.title: Ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis
images.description: Echocardiography transthoracic (apical view; A: without needle; B and C: with needle)Anechoic pericardial effusion (PE) was identified. Needle position (arrows) was continuously monitored while the pericardial space was entered to drain the effusion.Arrowheads: myocardium

answers.explanation_why: Hemodialysis is commonly performed in patients with end-stage renal disease. This patient has chronic kidney disease that has resulted in uremia and pericardial effusion. The patient should undergo hemodialysis, but she is hemodynamically unstable and presents with signs of cardiac tamponade, which makes a different procedure more appropriate at this time.

NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin) are used in the treatment of viral pericarditis. While patients with viral pericarditis can develop pericardial effusion and in some cases even cardiac tamponade, they usually present with additional symptoms such as fever, leukocytosis, and a history of respiratory and/or gastrointestinal symptoms. This patient has none of these findings, making viral pericarditis an unlikely diagnosis. Furthermore, she is hemodynamically unstable, which requires a more urgent intervention.

IV fluid infusion is likely indicated in this patient since she is hemodynamically unstable. However, she has cardiac tamponade; fluid resuscitation can only provide temporary relief and should not delay the treatment of the cardiac tamponade. Moreover, the patient has chronic kidney disease and shows signs of end-stage renal disease such as uremia, which means that fluids should only be administered with extreme caution.

Although this patient is hemodynamically unstable and presents with low blood pressure, norepinephrine is not indicated in this case. She most likely has cardiac tamponade, which necessitates a different procedure first. Additionally, it is not clear if norepinephrine infusion is beneficial in patients with cardiac tamponade.

While this patient likely has fluid overload due to reduced renal function, she is hemodynamically unstable. Administration of furosemide will further decrease her blood pressure and is therefore contraindicated. Moreover, diuretics are usually insufficient to remove excess fluids in patients with end-stage renal disease.

question_text:
A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He is obtunded on arrival. He is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. The ventilator is set at an FiO_2 of 60%, tidal volume of 440 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 7 cm H_2O. On the third day of intubation, his temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 103/60 mm Hg. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:

pH
7.49

pCO_2

29 mm Hg

pO_2

73 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

20 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
89%

Monitoring shows a sudden increase in the plateau airway pressure. An x-ray of the chest shows deepening of the costophrenic angle on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He is obtunded on arrival. He is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. The ventilator is set at an FiO2 of 60%, tidal volume of 440 mL, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 7 cm H2O. On the third day of intubation, his temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 103/60 mm Hg. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Arterial blood gas analysis shows: pH 7.49 pCO2 29 mm Hg pO2 73 mm Hg HCO3- 20 mEq/L O2 saturation 89% Monitoring shows a sudden increase in the plateau airway pressure. An x-ray of the chest shows deepening of the costophrenic angle on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Decreased breath sounds, increased airway pressure, respiratory alkalosis, and deep sulcus sign on chest x-ray in a mechanically ventilated patient indicate a pneumothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize the signs of pneumothorax in a mechanically ventilated patient, and choose the most appropriate intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Immediate insertion of a large-bore needle into the 2^nd intercostal space along the midclavicular line or the 4^th–5^th intercostal space between the anterior and midaxillary line is indicated for tension pneumothorax. Although tension pneumothorax may also manifest with decreased oxygen saturation and deep sulcus sign, further findings such as contralateral tracheal deviation, distended neck veins, cyanosis, and hemodynamic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension) are commonly seen.

Respiratory fluoroquinolones such as levofloxacin are the first-line treatment in patients with hospital-acquired pneumonia who do not have risk factors for multiresistant pathogens (e.g., prior antibiotic treatment, structural lung disease). Pneumonia typically manifests with high fever and chills, productive cough, tachypnea, and dyspnea. Chest x-ray usually shows extensive opacities restricted to one pulmonary lobe, poorly defined patchy infiltrates, or diffuse reticular opacity. These features are not present in this patient.

Increasing the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is often necessary when treating acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Patients with ARDS typically present with acute onset tachypnea, tachycardia, cyanosis, dyspnea, diffuse crackles, and possibly fever, cough, and chest pain. Chest x-ray of patients with ARDS usually reveals diffuse bilateral infiltrates, air bronchogram, atelectasis, and pleural effusions. This patient's x-ray indicates a pneumothorax, most likely due to increased pressures during mechanical ventilation. Increasing the PEEP is contraindicated as it would exacerbate his condition.

Insertion of a chest tube into the 4^th–5^th intercostal space between the anterior and midaxillary line (safe triangle) is the most appropriate next step for treating pneumothorax in a mechanically ventilated patient. Mechanical ventilation (especially with a high positive end-expiratory pressure) is considered a risk factor for developing pneumothorax. High ventilatory pressure can damage the lung tissue, causing a leak that allows air to enter the pleural cavity. Because the air entering the pleural space comes from the lung rather than the exterior, it is known as a closed pneumothorax. Following completion of the procedure, another chest x-ray to control the position of chest tube placement should be performed. To prevent further lung damage, the ventilatory pressure should be decreased.

Pneumothorax is often hard to diagnose in ventilated patients. Since the x-ray is obtained in the supine position, less air collects apically, making the pneumothorax less obvious.

Indications to obtain a CT scan include uncertain diagnosis despite chest x-ray, suspected underlying lung disease (to determine likelihood of recurrent disease), and presurgical workup. The patient had a chest x-ray that showed deepening of the costophrenic angle, indicating a pneumothorax. Further workup with a chest CT is not needed at this time.

Close observation would be the most appropriate next step in the management of asymptomatic patients with a small primary spontaneous pneumothorax (rim between the lung edge and chest wall < 2–3 cm). Such a pneumothorax usually resolves spontaneously within ∼ 10 days and symptomatic treatment and serial follow-up with repeat chest x-ray are sufficient. This patient is symptomatic, presenting with iatrogenic pneumothorax most likely due to mechanical ventilation, and requires treatment.

question_text: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of an intermittent burning sensation in his chest. The sensation becomes prominent when he is lying in bed and is also present after eating heavy meals. He also states that his breath has an unpleasant odor in the morning. He has not lost any weight during this period. He has hypertension. His father died of colon cancer and his mother has hypothyroidism. He drinks 2–3 beers on weekends; he does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His medications include ramipril and an over-the-counter multivitamin. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of an intermittent burning sensation in his chest. The sensation becomes prominent when he is lying in bed and is also present after eating heavy meals. He also states that his breath has an unpleasant odor in the morning. He has not lost any weight during this period. He has hypertension. His father died of colon cancer and his mother has hypothyroidism. He drinks 2–3 beers on weekends; he does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His medications include ramipril and an over-the-counter multivitamin. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The burning sensation in this patient's chest, exacerbated by consuming heavy meals and lying down, is consistent with heartburn, which, along with halitosis, is suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
learning_objective: Recognize gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and choose the initial step in management for recent-onset GERD without alarm symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Endoscopic examination of the esophagus to screen for adenocarcinoma is reserved for patients with GERD and alarm symptoms (e.g., dysphagia, odynophagia, anemia, GI bleeding, unintentional weight loss). It is also indicated to screen for Barrett esophagus in patients with chronic GERD symptoms (weekly for ≥ 5 years) and three or more additional risk factors: male sex, age > 50 years, White ethnicity, obesity, smoking, family history of Barrett esophagus or esophageal adenocarcinoma in a first-degree relative. This patient does not meet the criteria for endoscopy at this time.

H. pylori testing via urea breath test is indicated in patients with dyspepsia (i.e., epigastric pain or burning that lasts for ≥ 1 month) if they are < 60 years of age and do not have red flags for dyspepsia. This patient, however, has typical heartburn (intermittent retrosternal pain exacerbated by eating and lying down), the classic symptom of GERD. H. pylori testing is not recommended in the workup of typical GERD (i.e., in patients without dyspepsia in whom neither PUD nor gastritis is suspected). The prevalence of H. pylori infection among patients with GERD is not greater than in the general population. Test results would not help in the decision for or against the treatment of H. pylori infection in this patient group. Other indications for H. pylori testing include active peptic ulcer disease (PUD), a past history of PUD, atrophic gastritis, and/or gastric MALT lymphomas.

Empiric therapy with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is the most appropriate initial step in the management of recent-onset GERD with no red flag symptoms of GERD (e.g., dysphagia, odynophagia, anemia, GI bleeding, unintentional weight loss, persistent vomiting, aspiration pneumonia) and little to no risk factors for Barrett esophagus. Of all medications that are used to treat GERD, PPIs are associated with the greatest reduction in symptoms and relapse rates. In addition to a trial of PPIs for 8 weeks, certain lifestyle modifications (e.g., smoking cessation, weight loss, elevating the head of the bed while sleeping, avoiding late-night meals) should be recommended.

H_2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs) is the second-line treatment for patients with GERD because they are less effective than first-line drugs in providing symptomatic relief, reducing relapse rates, and promoting healing of erosive lesions of the esophagus. H2RAs also have a shorter duration of action (about 12 hours) than first-line drugs.

Bedtime administration of H2RAs may be considered as adjunctive therapy for patients with symptoms refractory to first-line therapy. However, this patient has not yet received the first-line therapy and should therefore not be given an H2RA.

A barium swallow is the confirmatory test for esophageal diverticula (e.g., Zenker diverticulum), which can manifest with halitosis and retrosternal discomfort, mimicking GERD. However, Zenker diverticulum is more common in men > 60 years of age; moreover, additional symptoms, such as dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food, are also expected in patients with an esophageal diverticulum.

Studies have shown that barium swallows have a very low sensitivity (approx. 25%) for diagnosing gastroesophageal reflux, and therefore, should not be used for the diagnosis of GERD when a patient presents with typical symptoms of uncomplicated GERD in the absence of dysphagia.

images.title: Esophageal barium swallow with barium sulfate in two phases in Zenker diverticulum
images.description: The predominantely left-sided, dorsal contrast-filled structure in the upper esophagus most likely indicates Zenker diverticulum.

answers.explanation_why: Amoxicillin and clarithromycin are used in combination with proton pump inhibitors as a part of the triple therapy eradication regimen in patients with H. pylori infection. However, treatment of H. pylori infection is not indicated in patients with GERD alone, since the prevalence of H. pylori infection among patients with GERD is not greater than in the general population. In fact, the prevalence of H. pylori is actually lower in patients with complicated or severe GERD.

Antacids, such as calcium carbonate, can be used for symptomatic relief in patients with mild GERD symptoms that occur less than once a week. However, because of their short duration of action, they are not used for the prevention of GERD-related symptoms. This patient, who experiences persistent symptoms, should receive a more effective form of therapy.

question_text: A 39-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath over the past 3 months. He has been unable to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment. Six years ago, he was diagnosed with HIV. He is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy, but he says that he often misses doses. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6° F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 160/70 mm Hg. There is a grade 4/6 holodiastolic murmur heard best at the right sternal border. The pupils are 4 mm, round, and not reactive to light. When a pen tip is advanced closer to the face, the pupils constrict. Extraocular movements are intact. When asked to stand, hold his arms in front of him, and close his eyes, he loses his balance and takes a step backward. An x-ray of the chest shows widening of the mediastinum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 39-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath over the past 3 months. He has been unable to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment. Six years ago, he was diagnosed with HIV. He is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy, but he says that he often misses doses. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6° F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 160/70 mm Hg. There is a grade 4/6 holodiastolic murmur heard best at the right sternal border. The pupils are 4 mm, round, and not reactive to light. When a pen tip is advanced closer to the face, the pupils constrict. Extraocular movements are intact. When asked to stand, hold his arms in front of him, and close his eyes, he loses his balance and takes a step backward. An x-ray of the chest shows widening of the mediastinum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: Pupils that accommodate but are not reactive to light are called Argyll Robertson pupils.
learning_objective: Recognize tertiary syphilis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Fibrillin gene mutation testing would be used to diagnose Marfan syndrome, which typically manifests with tall stature, joint hypermobility, and musculoskeletal abnormalities (e.g., pectus excavatum). While Marfan syndrome increases the risk of aortic aneurysm, which this patient most likely has, it would not cause fever or this patient's neurologic abnormalities. Moreover, there is no other evidence of Marfan syndrome on physical examination of this patient.

Antinuclear antibody testing is a first-line screening test for many rheumatological diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can cause fever and, rarely, thoracic aortic aneurysms. Moreover, SLE can cause a broad range of neuropsychiatric abnormalities, including peripheral neuropathy (which could cause a positive Romberg test). However, common neurologic symptoms of SLE include headache, seizure, delirium, and stroke, none of which are present in this patient. Additionally, the patient does not have a history of lupus, and no other clinical features of SLE (e.g., cutaneous lesions, polyarthralgia, malar rash) are present.

Antistreptolysin O is the first-line test for recent S. pyogenes infection, which can result in rheumatic fever (RF) and subsequent rheumatic heart disease. RF would explain this patient's heart failure, murmur, and fever. However, this patient has neither a history of RF, nor evidence of acute RF (i.e., positive Jones criteria). Additionally, RF may cause chorea in acute illness, but it would not explain this patient's positive Romberg test and pupillary findings. Finally, RF would not explain his widened mediastinum on x-ray.

Blood cultures are indicated to diagnose bacteremia/fungemia, which could cause fever, infective endocarditis (IE) and/or mycotic aneurysm, and consequent heart murmur and heart failure. This patient is at increased risk for IE given his HIV infection. Although vegetations from IE can embolize and cause end-organ infarction such as stroke, neither Argyll Robertson pupils nor a positive Romberg test (which indicates involvement of the dorsal columns and/or peripheral neuropathy) are associated with stroke.

The frataxin level can be used to confirm Friedreich ataxia (FA), although the disease is usually diagnosed clinically. While patients with FA often develop heart failure, it is due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Based on the murmur (holodiastolic, best heard at the right sternal border) and the x-ray findings (showing mediastinal widening), this patient's heart failure is most likely due to thoracic aortic aneurysm with resulting aortic regurgitation. FA can manifest with sensory ataxia (and a positive Romberg test) and can lead to optic atrophy (presenting with loss of vision), but it would not explain this patient's fever or pupillary abnormality. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of FA (e.g., foot deformity, scoliosis).

Treponemal tests (TTs), such as the fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) and the treponema pallidum particle agglutination test (TPPA), are used in the diagnosis of syphilis. Diagnosis is confirmed using a serial testing strategy. In the standard testing algorithm, a nontreponemal test (NTT), such as VDRL or plasma reagin test, is performed first. If the result is positive or equivocal, a TT is performed. In the reverse testing algorithm, a TT is performed first, followed by an NTT test. A positive result for both tests strongly supports the diagnosis of syphilis. This patient likely has tertiary syphilis as he shows signs of both neurosyphilis (positive Romberg test suggesting tabes dorsalis, Argyll Robertson pupil) and cardiac syphilis (ascending aortic aneurysm with consequent heart failure). Since the advent of antibiotics, neurosyphilis has become much less common. Patients with HIV (especially untreated) are at greatest risk of the disease. Tertiary syphilis usually occurs decades after infection with Treponema pallidum, but immunocompromised patients (e.g., due to HIV) may develop symptoms more rapidly. First-line treatment for neurosyphilis is IV penicillin G for 10–14 days.

question_text: A 26-year-old medical student comes to the physician for a chest x-ray to rule out active pulmonary tuberculosis. He needs a medical and radiological report before starting a medical internship in South Africa in 6 weeks. He says he feels well. He has no history of serious illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 6 years. He does not drink alcohol. He is 190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (170 lb); BMI is 20.8 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The x-ray of the chest shows a small pneumothorax (rim of < 2 cm) between the upper left lung margin and the chest wall. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
content_preview: A 26-year-old medical student comes to the physician for a chest x-ray to rule out active pulmonary tuberculosis. He needs a medical and radiological report before starting a medical internship in South Africa in 6 weeks. He says he feels well. He has no history of serious illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 6 years. He does not drink alcohol. He is 190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (170 lb); BMI is 20.8 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The x-ray of the chest shows a small pneumothorax (rim of < 2 cm) between the upper left lung margin and the chest wall. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
hint: The x-ray shows a small pneumothorax (rim of < 2 cm) between the lung margin and the chest wall as an incidental finding. In a tall, fit, and smoking young adult this is suspicious of a primary spontaneous pneumothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize primary spontaneous pneumothorax, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery would be indicated as an alternative treatment for tension pneumothorax, or for the recurrence of a spontaneous pneumothorax. Because this patient only has a small pneumothorax and is hemodynamically stable, he requires a different approach.

Emergent needle thoracostomy would be indicated in the case of a tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax would cause sudden chest pain, dyspnea, cyanosis, absent breath sounds, hemodynamic instability, and tracheal deviation on chest x-ray.

Observation with follow-up serial chest x-rays are the recommended treatment for small primary spontaneous pneumothoraces with an apex-to-cupola distance < 3 cm that does not compromise the gas exchange function. A small pneumothorax is likely to resolve spontaneously within a few days (∼ 10 days).

This patient's smoking history, male sex, young age, and physical features (tall stature, low body weight) put him at increased risk for primary spontaneous pneumothorax.
Immediate intubation and assisted ventilation is not indicated for the management of pneumothorax (and may even worsen tension pneumothorax, which requires decompression).

A chest CT is useful for the evaluation of pneumothorax when the chest x-ray fails to point to a clear diagnosis, as it can provide detailed information about the cause of the condition. However, this patient's diagnosis has already been established and further diagnostic evaluation is not indicated at this time.

Urgent chest tube placement is indicated for a symptomatic or large pneumothorax (i.e, a rim of > 2 cm between the lung margin and the chest wall on chest x-ray), but this patient has a small primary spontaneous pneumothorax and is asymptomatic.

question_text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of increasing weakness and chills. She also notes difficulty breathing for the last 3 days. Eight weeks ago, she underwent a left hemicolectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon. She subsequently developed a severe urinary tract infection, was treated in the intensive care unit for 4 days, and was discharged from the hospital 3 weeks ago. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoporosis with lumbar pain, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. She does not drink alcohol and has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include warfarin, metformin, lisinopril, and aspirin. She appears lethargic and has a large conjunctival hemorrhage in her left eye. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 126/79 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new holosystolic murmur over the apex. Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the upper quadrants and a well-healed 12-cm paramedian scar. There are multiple tender nodules on the palmar surface of her fingertips. Fundoscopic examination shows retinal hemorrhages with pale centers. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of increasing weakness and chills. She also notes difficulty breathing for the last 3 days. Eight weeks ago, she underwent a left hemicolectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon. She subsequently developed a severe urinary tract infection, was treated in the intensive care unit for 4 days, and was discharged from the hospital 3 weeks ago. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoporosis with lumbar pain, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. She does not drink alcohol and has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include warfarin, metformin, lisinopril, and aspirin. She appears lethargic and has a large conjunctival hemorrhage in her left eye. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 126/79 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new holosystolic murmur over the apex. Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the upper quadrants and a well-healed 12-cm paramedian scar. There are multiple tender nodules on the palmar surface of her fingertips. Fundoscopic examination shows retinal hemorrhages with pale centers. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient has definite subacute infective endocarditis (IE) according to the Duke criteria: she fulfills 1 major criterion (new valvular regurgitation on auscultation) and 3 minor criteria (fever, vascular abnormalities (conjunctival hemorrhage), and immunologic manifestations (Osler nodes, Roth spots). Her history of a nosocomial urinary tract infection (UTI) indicates infection with a certain pathogen.
learning_objective: Recognize Enterococcus faecalis infection as a cause of infective endocarditis.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary metastases from her colorectal cancer could explain this patient's difficulty breathing. Carcinomas of the lower rectum are known to metastasize to the lungs and her history of colon cancer should raise concern. However, pulmonary metastatic disease would not explain her fever, new murmur, Osler nodes, or Roth spots.

Viridans streptococci such as Streptococcus sanguinis are the most common cause of subacute IE, especially in compromised native valves and prosthetic valves. IE caused by viridans streptococci is associated with dental procedures, as these organisms are a normal part of the oral flora. Although IE due to S. sanguinis would fit this patient's timeline, she has no prior history of valvular disease and has not undergone any recent dental work.

Cardiobacterium hominis belongs to the group of HACEK organisms, a group of fastidious gram-negative bacilli that were previously difficult to isolate on routine blood cultures. HACEK organisms are only responsible for about 3% of IE cases and are now more readily identified with the use of automated blood culture systems. While IE with a HACEK organism could certainly cause a similar presentation, this patient's history makes an alternative etiology more likely.

Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) is a rare form of noninfectious endocarditis that is characterized by sterile thrombi deposition on the heart valves. NBTE is associated with malignancy and certain autoimmune conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, SLE), and most commonly affects the aortic and mitral valves. Patients are usually asymptomatic until there is evidence of thromboembolic phenomena. This patient's history of colon cancer and new murmur could be consistent with NBTE; however, fever and other systemic symptoms would not be expected.

IE is rarely caused by a fungal infection, with Aspergillus fumigatus accounting for approximately one-third of all cases. The vast majority of Aspergillus endocarditis cases occur among patients with prosthetic valves, those who have undergone cardiosurgical interventions, or those who are significantly immunocompromised. Given this patient's history, a different etiology is more likely.

Enterococci are a common cause of IE following nosocomial UTIs. E. faecalis is especially virulent and is more likely than E. faecium to progress to bacteremia and endocarditis. Because penicillin resistance varies within the group of enterococci, combination therapy (e.g., ampicillin plus gentamicin) is recommended in the treatment of enterococcal endocarditis.

See “Characteristics of selected causes of infective endocarditis” table.
