question_text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-week history of productive cough, swelling of the legs and feet, and fatigue. He has had progressive dyspnea on exertion for the past 2 months. Twelve years ago, he received a porcine valve replacement for severe mitral valve regurgitation. He has coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include aspirin, simvastatin, ramipril, metoprolol, metformin, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale. He is 179 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 127 kg (279.9 lb); BMI is 41 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg. Bilateral basilar rales are heard on auscultation of the lungs. Cardiac examination shows a laterally displaced apical heartbeat. A grade 3/6, crescendo-decrescendo diastolic murmur is heard over the apex. There is bilateral pitting edema of the feet and ankles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-week history of productive cough, swelling of the legs and feet, and fatigue. He has had progressive dyspnea on exertion for the past 2 months. Twelve years ago, he received a porcine valve replacement for severe mitral valve regurgitation. He has coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include aspirin, simvastatin, ramipril, metoprolol, metformin, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale. He is 179 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 127 kg (279.9 lb); BMI is 41 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg. Bilateral basilar rales are heard on auscultation of the lungs. Cardiac examination shows a laterally displaced apical heartbeat. A grade 3/6, crescendo-decrescendo diastolic murmur is heard over the apex. There is bilateral pitting edema of the feet and ankles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's cough, swelling of the lower extremities, fatigue, progressive dyspnea on exertion, and pitting edema in addition to bilateral basilar rales (suggestive of pulmonary edema) and a laterally displaced apical heartbeat (suggestive of an enlarged heart), are consistent with congestive heart failure (CHF).
learning_objective: Recognize valve degeneration as a cause of CHF symptoms post valve replacement.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with prosthetic valves are at increased risk of developing infective endocarditis (IE), especially subacute IE, which can manifest with a heart murmur. IE may lead to CHF over a span of days to weeks. Although this patient has a murmur and signs of CHF, he does not have a fever nor any other Duke criteria, making IE unlikely.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) manifests with dyspnea and chronic productive cough (≥ 3 months in 2 consecutive years) and may lead to tachypnea, cyanosis, and pulmonary hypertension in later stages. Physical examination typically shows wheezing and a prolonged expiratory phase. Although this patient has a cough and a positive smoking history, he has only had a cough for 3 weeks and no obstruction on lung auscultation, making COPD unlikely.

Typical pneumonia manifests with a sudden onset of malaise, fever, productive cough, and crackles and bronchial breath sounds on auscultation. Atypical pneumonia, on the other hand, manifests with a gradual onset of unproductive cough, dyspnea, extrapulmonary manifestations, and often unremarkable findings on pulmonary examination. Although this patient presents with a productive cough, he has no fever and his pulmonary examination shows bilateral basilar rales, both of which are indicative of CHF rather than pneumonia.

The patient underwent a porcine valve replacement for severe mitral valve regurgitation 12 years ago. Biological valves (both bovine and porcine) typically have a short lifespan due to sclerotic degeneration. If the prosthetic valve becomes dysfunctional, the patient may have to undergo open-heart surgery for valve replacement again. Possible complications of the biological prosthetic valve include obstruction/stenosis, as seen in this patient, and regurgitation, both of which may manifest with signs of CHF.

Biological prosthetic valves are preferred over mechanical prosthetic valves in patients > 65 years of age because the degeneration process is slower than in younger patients and they typically do not need further surgery to replace the valve again. In addition, anticoagulation is only needed for 3 months following the surgery. Thus, biologic prosthetic valves are also preferred in patients with a high risk of bleeding, and in women with a desire to have children, since certain anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are teratogenic.

images.title: Biological prosthetic heart valve
images.description: A stented bioprosthetic valve, consisting of xenograft material (most commonly porcine aortic valve leaflets or bovine pericardium) mounted on a manufactured supporting stent.

answers.explanation_why: The clinical presentation of pulmonary embolism (PE) is variable. Patients can present with chest pain, coughing, dyspnea, tachycardia, or even cardiogenic shock. Risk factors include immobility, inherited hypercoagulability disorders, pregnancy, and recent surgery. This patient presents with coughing and dyspnea, which may mimic PE. However, the patient does not have a history of recent immobilization. Furthermore, he has mitral valve stenosis and bilateral pitting edema of the feet and ankles, which makes CHF more likely than pulmonary embolism.

question_text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness during the past 6 months. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gout. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He drinks 3 cans of beer daily. His current medications include aspirin, metformin, enalapril, simvastatin, and febuxostat. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Auscultation of the right side of the neck shows a bruit. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference ranges. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness during the past 6 months. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gout. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He drinks 3 cans of beer daily. His current medications include aspirin, metformin, enalapril, simvastatin, and febuxostat. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Auscultation of the right side of the neck shows a bruit. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference ranges. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's occasional episodes of weakness and slurred speech are consistent with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). This history, in combination with his peripheral vascular disease, multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia), and carotid bruit indicate symptomatic carotid artery stenosis (CAS) due to atherosclerosis.
learning_objective: Recognize symptomatic carotid artery stenosis, and choose the initial diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why:
Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is typically the first-line imaging modality for patients with symptomatic CAS (e.g., TIA, amaurosis fugax, ischemic stroke). Some guidelines also recommend ultrasonography of the neck to screen for CAS in asymptomatic patients with a carotid bruit and multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease. In patients with CAS, ultrasonography shows a focally-increased velocity of blood flow. Duplex ultrasonography is an inexpensive, noninvasive test with high specificity and sensitivity for the detection of CAS. It can also quantify the degree of stenosis.

Antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, blood pressure control, and lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking cessation, weight control, regular exercise) are the mainstays of treatment in CAS. Carotid revascularization (typically with carotid endarterectomy) is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease and severe stenosis (≥ 70%).

Echocardiography is used to identify cardiogenic sources of emboli in patients with symptomatic ischemic neurological disease (e.g., TIA) without a clear intracranial or extracranial vascular etiology. However, this patient's physical exam revealed a carotid bruit that is likely secondary to CAS. Echocardiography would not be the next best step for evaluating CAS.

In patients with CAS, anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are not used for stroke prevention. Instead, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel) are used. Warfarin is used for stroke prevention only in patients with certain risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, prosthetic heart valves).

CT angiography and MR angiography are not first-line imaging modalities in the workup of CAS, but they can be used to confirm the diagnosis if the first-line modality shows findings consistent with the condition or yields inconclusive results (e.g., due to significant carotid artery calcification). Angiography also plays a role in preoperative risk stratification and intervention planning.

answers.content: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck
answers.explanation_why: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck, which requires arterial catheterization, used to be the preferred test for evaluating CAS but it has been replaced by other modalities because it is an invasive and costly procedure that carries a ∼ 4% risk of iatrogenic neurological complications (e.g., stroke). Although it may have some utility in select patient groups (e.g., if the initial imaging modalities reveal discordant results or additional anatomic detail is needed), it would not be used as a first-line diagnostic test.

question_text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest. On arrival, he has rapid, shallow breathing and appears anxious. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min and shallow, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. Examination shows no active external bleeding. There is a 2.5-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4^th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest. On arrival, he has rapid, shallow breathing and appears anxious. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min and shallow, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. Examination shows no active external bleeding. There is a 2.5-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck triad) following penetrating chest trauma are consistent with cardiac tamponade.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiac tamponade, and recall its characteristic hemodynamic finding during inspiration.

answers.content: Tracheal deviation toward the right side
answers.explanation_why: Tracheal deviation toward the contralateral side of a lesion can occur with a tension pneumothorax or a massive hemothorax. Although both of these conditions can be caused by penetrating chest trauma and result in tachycardia, hypotension, and jugular venous distention, this patient does not have reduced breath sounds, which is a characteristic auscultatory finding in both of these conditions.

answers.content: A drop in systolic blood pressure of 14 mm Hg during inspiration
answers.explanation_why: In cardiac tamponade, outward expansion of the ventricles is limited because of fluid in the pericardial space. During inspiration, increased venous return leads to increased right ventricular volume. As outward expansion is limited, the right ventricle expands via the interventricular septum, which bulges into the left ventricle. This effect leads to further reduction in left ventricular filling during inspiration, resulting in decreased stroke volume and a subsequent drop in blood pressure. A drop in systolic blood pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration is known as pulsus paradoxus, a sign characteristically seen in moderate and severe cardiac tamponade but also in some cases of severe asthma, tension pneumothorax, and constrictive pericarditis.

answers.content: Herniation of the stomach into the chest
answers.explanation_why: Herniation of the stomach into the chest indicates diaphragmatic injury. This condition may also result after a penetrating chest trauma. Although shallow breathing is a feature consistent with diaphragmatic injury, this patient is lacking other key findings of this condition, such as chest or abdominal pain, reduced breath sounds, and bowel sounds in the chest on auscultation. In addition, muffled heart sounds would not be expected in this condition.

Subcutaneous emphysema or crepitus suggests either bronchial rupture, esophageal rupture, or pneumothorax, which also may be caused by penetrating trauma. None of these conditions cause muffled heart sounds.

answers.content: Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing
answers.explanation_why: Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing suggests flail chest, which is usually caused by severe blunt thoracic trauma rather than penetrating chest trauma. Although this patient has shallow breathing, which may be a feature of flail chest, the condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention, and it is unlikely that a single stab wound would cause several rib fractures.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

question_text:
A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, she is semiconscious and incoherent. She has shortness of breath and is cyanotic. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration on the forehead and multiple abrasions over the thorax and abdomen. There is crepitation on palpation of the thorax on the right. Auscultation of the lung shows decreased breath sounds on the right side. A crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat is heard best over the precordium. There is dullness on percussion of the right hemithorax. The lips and tongue have a bluish discoloration. There is an open femur fracture on the left. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.31

PCO_2

55 mm Hg

PO_2

42 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

22 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
76%

The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, she is semiconscious and incoherent. She has shortness of breath and is cyanotic. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 128/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration on the forehead and multiple abrasions over the thorax and abdomen. There is crepitation on palpation of the thorax on the right. Auscultation of the lung shows decreased breath sounds on the right side. A crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat is heard best over the precordium. There is dullness on percussion of the right hemithorax. The lips and tongue have a bluish discoloration. There is an open femur fracture on the left. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.31 PCO2 55 mm Hg PO2 42 mm Hg HCO3- 22 mEq/L O2 saturation 76% The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with subcutaneous emphysema (crepitation on palpation), decreased breath sounds, and crunching sounds synchronous with the heartbeat (Hamman sign) following blunt chest trauma. These findings are consistent with pneumomediastinum.
learning_objective: Recognize bronchial rupture.

answers.explanation_why: An aortic dissection can be idiopathic, associated with underlying diseases, or traumatic, following blunt chest trauma. Patients with an aortic dissection can present with an acute onset of severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, hypertension (though hypotension is also seen when the dissection is complicated by cardiac tamponade or aortic rupture), weak or asymmetric peripheral pulses, and different blood pressures in the upper extremities. Pneumomediastinum is not a feature of aortic dissection.

Cardiac tamponade can occur following blunt chest trauma. A patient with cardiac tamponade would experience cardiogenic shock and classically present with Beck triad. This patient's symptoms are not typical of cardiac tamponade.

Tracheobronchial injuries such as a bronchial rupture can occur after a high-speed trauma. A bronchial rupture can present with Hamman sign (as a result of the pneumomediastinum) and respiratory acidosis (due to alveolar hypoventilation from airway obstruction and atelectasis). The dullness on percussion in the right hemithorax suggests a fluid collection. In the context of recent trauma, this finding likely represents an associated hemothorax. Patients with a tracheobronchial injury may develop a pneumothorax or a pneumomediastinum which reaccumulates even after a thoracostomy.

Flail chest can be caused by blunt chest trauma. The flail segment, consisting of multiple adjacent ribs broken in multiple places, would be evident on physical examination. Additionally, paradoxical breathing (the flail segment moves opposite to the chest wall as the patient breaths) would be present. Although this patient may have rib fractures due to the high-speed trauma, the examination is inconsistent with a flail chest.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

answers.explanation_why: Tension pneumothorax is often caused by high-speed trauma such as a motor vehicle collision. Patients usually exhibit hyperresonance on percussion (instead of dullness) and present with hemodynamic compromise. Because this patient is relatively hemodynamically stable, tension pneumothorax is an unlikely diagnosis.

Myocardial rupture can be caused by blunt chest trauma. Patients with a myocardial rupture experience acute hemodynamic deterioration with jugular venous distention on exam, but this patient's blood pressure is stable. Because of the high mortality associated with myocardial rupture, it would also be unlikely that this patient would have survived such trauma 30 minutes later.

Pulmonary embolism can be caused by embolism of fat following a femoral fracture and typically presents with nonspecific findings including pleuritic chest pain and pleural effusion. While chest pain cannot be excluded in this patient and the dullness on percussion may represent an effusion, pulmonary embolism would not manifest with the crepitus on palpation, Hamman sign, and decreased breath sounds, and is, therefore, an unlikely diagnosis.

question_text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain 35 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the helmeted driver of a scooter hit by a truck. On arrival, he is alert and oriented with a Glasgow Coma Scale rating of 14. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his anterior abdomen and extremities. There is a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. Bowel sounds are normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9110/mm^3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm^3. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain 35 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the helmeted driver of a scooter hit by a truck. On arrival, he is alert and oriented with a Glasgow Coma Scale rating of 14. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his anterior abdomen and extremities. There is a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. Bowel sounds are normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9110/mm3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm3. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient, who has just been in a car accident, is in respiratory distress and has chest pain, decreased breath sounds over his left lung, and a chest x-ray that is typical for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize diaphragmatic rupture.

answers.explanation_why:
Diaphragmatic rupture is most commonly caused by penetrating injuries, followed by blunt trauma, both of which can be caused by a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Clinical features include chest/abdominal wall bruises, decreased breath sounds due to herniation of abdominal contents into the chest, and respiratory distress. Chest auscultation may reveal bowel sounds. Chest x-ray may show disturbed contour of the hemidiaphragm, displaced abdominal organs, and mediastinal shift, as well as an hourglass sign if abdominal contents are constricted at the defect. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Diaphragmatic ruptures more commonly occur on the left side because the right diaphragm is protected by the liver. Patients may initially be asymptomatic, so this condition is often not diagnosed immediately.

Esophageal perforation may occur in a variety of clinical scenarios, including Boerhaave syndrome, blunt and penetrating chest trauma, and iatrogenic esophageal perforation (e.g., following endoscopy). Patients with esophageal perforation present with chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea. However, this condition is often associated with additional findings such as fever and crepitus over the chest due to mediastinal emphysema. Unlike in this patient, a chest x-ray typically shows a widened mediastinum. Herniation of the stomach into the thorax is not typically associated with esophageal perforation.

Flail chest can cause respiratory distress due to detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall, which results from three or more adjacent ribs fractured in two or more places. While flail chest can occur following high-velocity trauma, the absence of rib fractures on this patient's chest x-ray rules this condition out.

images.title: Flail chest
images.description: X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of traumaMultiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.White overlay: ribs

answers.explanation_why: A pneumothorax can occur spontaneously or following trauma such as a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Patients typically present with tachypnea, dyspnea, chest pain, and unilaterally reduced breath sounds. However, a chest x-ray usually shows a pleural line, a sudden change in radiolucency, and an abrupt stop in pulmonary vascular markings. This patient's x-ray findings are not consistent with a pneumothorax.

images.title: Pneumothorax without tension
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A thin white line represents the visceral pleura of the left lung (dotted line). No lung markings are seen peripheral to the visceral pleura (green overlay).The appearance is consistent with a left pneumothorax. There is no evidence of contralateral mediastinal shift, diaphragmatic depression, or ipsilateral intercostal space widening to suggest tension pneumothorax.

answers.explanation_why: The phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm via the nerve roots C3, C4, and C5. Phrenic nerve palsy is often iatrogenic (e.g., following supraclavicular block) and may occasionally occur following trauma. This condition leads to ipsilateral elevation of the diaphragm, which affects pulmonary and cardiac function. Patients can present with dyspnea. However, x-ray usually shows elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side and not herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.

images.title: Elevation of the left hemidiaphragm from phrenic nerve paralysis 2/2
images.description: X-ray chest (lateral view)There is elevation of the left hemidiaphragm (dashed line) with adjacent atelectasis (yellow overlay) of lung parenchyma and underlying dilated bowel (B).Blue overlay: hardware left humerus; solid line: right hemidiaphragm

images.title: Posttraumatic diaphragmatic hernia simulating diaphragm elevation
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient following thoracic traumaA gas bubble on the left (green overlay) is positioned higher than normal and contains an air-fluid level (line). Additionally, the left hemidiaphragm is elevated, lobulated, and not sharply delineated in its entirety (dashed line).Elevation of a hemidiaphragm can result from abnormalities above, below, or involving the diaphragm. Diaphragmatic rupture can simulate elevation and must be considered in the differential diagnosis of elevation in a trauma setting. A CT scan of this patient confirmed diaphragmatic rupture with the stomach located in the left hemithorax.

question_text: The x-ray findings suggest a diaphragmatic rupture. A trauma 'huddle' is called, and morphine is administered for pain. Low-flow oxygen and infusion with 0.9% saline are begun. Five minutes later, pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: The x-ray findings suggest a diaphragmatic rupture. A trauma 'huddle' is called, and morphine is administered for pain. Low-flow oxygen and infusion with 0.9% saline are begun. Five minutes later, pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
learning_objective: Recognize suspected traumatic diaphragmatic rupture, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: A barium swallow may be used to confirm suspected diaphragmatic rupture by showing abdominal contents above the diaphragm. However, a barium swallow test is not routinely used in the diagnosis of traumatic diaphragmatic rupture, as the procedure is lengthier and less precise than other procedures and requires the patient's cooperation. Moreover, traumatic diaphragmatic ruptures are often associated with other injuries such as esophageal tears. If barium, a water-insoluble contrast media, enters the mediastinum through a perforation, it may lead to mediastinitis and subsequent fibrosis. A barium study should therefore only be performed after perforations of the gastrointestinal tract have been ruled out.

Chest fluoroscopy may be indicated for suspected phrenic nerve palsy or conditions involving decreased lung elasticity (e.g., interstitial lung diseases). However, this patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of diaphragmatic rupture, and his chest x-ray should be followed by a different and more specific imaging technique to confirm the diagnosis.

answers.content: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
answers.explanation_why: A CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient, who is suspected of having a traumatic diaphragmatic rupture. X-ray findings alone are not sufficient to establish diaphragmatic rupture as the definitive diagnosis, as x-rays only show indirect signs of the injury. Moreover, concomitant injuries should be ruled out. A CT would be able to directly visualize the discontinuity of the affected hemidiaphragm and confirm the diagnosis. Indirect findings include thickening of the diaphragm, elevation of abdominal organs, and herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.

images.title: Diaphragmatic rupture (1/2)
images.description: Chest CT scan after IV contrast medium administration in the lung window, arterial phase, axial section, at the level of the junction at which the superior vena cava meets the right atrium: There is herniation of the abdominal organs into the left thoracic cavity. These are most likely sections of the stomach (St, with air-fluid levels = green areas) and the spleen (Sp). Parts of the parenchyma of the left lung are still visible in the ventral region. The ground-glass opacified, diffuse areas in the right lung (red areas) most likely indicate a small ventilatory disturbance. In addition, there is either a small hemothorax or pleural effusion visible in the right dorsal field (red hatched area). (AA=ascending aorta, DA=descending aorta, LA=left atrium, LV=left ventricle, RA=right atrium, RV=right ventricle, V=superior vena cava)

answers.explanation_why: ICU admission and observation without any further intervention would be an inappropriate decision for this patient, who requires confirmation of the diaphragmatic rupture and subsequent surgery.

Emergency surgery is the treatment of choice in patients with confirmed diaphragmatic rupture or those who are hemodynamically unstable. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and only had an x-ray of the chest, which is not sufficient to establish a definite diagnosis. Therefore, he should undergo further diagnostic testing to confirm the diagnosis before undergoing surgery.

Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) may be performed to obtain a biopsy, resect thoracic masses, or even to repair a diaphragmatic rupture in some cases. However, the diagnosis should be confirmed in this patient before treatment is initiated.

MRI of the chest and abdomen can be performed for suspected diaphragmatic injury, as this test is able to directly visualize the discontinuity of the affected hemidiaphragm, which would confirm the diagnosis. However, MRI is not the gold standard in trauma patients since there are other imaging techniques that are faster and almost as precise. MRI is the preferred confirmatory test for pregnant women.

question_text: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was a restrained passenger. On arrival, she is lethargic and incoherent. She is in respiratory distress. Her pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 88/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows multiple facial lacerations. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.1 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows a fractured left second rib, depression of the left main bronchus, deviation of the nasogastric tube to the right, left pleural effusion, and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was a restrained passenger. On arrival, she is lethargic and incoherent. She is in respiratory distress. Her pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 88/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows multiple facial lacerations. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.1 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows a fractured left second rib, depression of the left main bronchus, deviation of the nasogastric tube to the right, left pleural effusion, and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This condition should always be considered in patients presenting with respiratory distress and signs of developing shock after trauma from rapid deceleration (e.g., high-speed motor vehicle collision). The x-ray findings are highly suggestive of the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize thoracic aortic rupture.

answers.explanation_why: Flail chest can manifest with respiratory distress. However, paradoxical chest movement is not present in this patient. Additionally, the chest x-ray shows only one fractured rib, and a widened mediastinum is not associated with flail chest, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

answers.explanation_why: Diaphragmatic rupture commonly results from blunt or penetrating trauma and occurs more often on the left than on the right side (as the liver protects against a rupture on the right). The condition can manifest with respiratory distress and decreased breath sounds. However, x-ray findings typically show herniation of abdominal organs like the stomach and colon, causing an “hourglass” appearance rather than a widened mediastinum.

images.title: Diaphragmatic rupture
images.description: AP chest X-ray of a 29-year-old patient with chest trauma after a motor-vehicle crash: the tip of the central venous catheter on the right side (black arrows) projects onto the right atrium. The left hemidiaphragm (black dotted line) is much higher than the right one. The stomach is located within the thorax, as can be seen by the circled gastric bubble. The lung tissue shows streaky densities, which hints towards intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The combination of these findings most likely indicates a ruptured diaphragm with a stomach herniated into the thoracic cavity.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary contusion typically occurs after blunt trauma and can manifest with tachycardia, respiratory distress, and hypoxia. However, it does not commonly present with dullness on percussion. Additionally, the chest x-ray typically shows patchy alveolar infiltrates and not a widened mediastinum, as described above.

images.title: Pulmonary trauma
images.description: CT chest (axial plane; lung window) following trauma to the chestAreas of ground glass and consolidation in both lungs are the result of pulmonary contusion (green overlay). Ovoid traumatic lacerations in the left lung contain opaque blood (red overlay). Two of the lacerations also contain air, producing air-fluid levels (dashed line). A pneumothorax is present anteriorly in the right hemithorax (blue overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Traumatic bronchial rupture often results from high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma and can manifest with respiratory distress. However, it is typically associated with pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema – features not present in this woman.

images.title: Traumatic pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum with subcutaneous emphysema
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

answers.explanation_why: A widened mediastinum, esophageal deviation, depression of the left main bronchus, and hemothorax (suggested by left pleural effusion) are consistent with thoracic aortic rupture (TAR). TAR can be traumatic (e.g., due to high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma) or spontaneous (e.g., following aortic dissection). Only around 20% of patients with blunt traumatic aortic injuries survive long enough to reach the hospital; therefore, immediate resuscitation and prompt surgical repair of the thoracic aorta is required in patients with suggestive findings (e.g., symptoms of respiratory distress, features of hemorrhagic shock).

images.title: Nontraumatic rupture of the thoracic aorta
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)There is extravasation of contrast (red overlay) from the nonaneurysmal atherosclerotic descending thoracic aorta (bright green overlay), with surrounding hematoma (green striped overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Cardiac tamponade results from conditions such as pericarditis, chest trauma, malignancies, or kidney dysfunction. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with respiratory distress. This patient has hypotension, but she does not have the jugular venous distention or muffled heart sounds that would be expected in an individual with cardiac tamponade (Beck’s triad). Additionally, in contrast to this vignette, x-ray findings of cardiac tamponade would typically include an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

images.title: Enlarged cardiac silhouette
images.description: Chest X-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of pericarditis and clinical findings of tamponadeThe cardiac silhouette is enlarged (globular water bottle-shape; enlargement highlighted by green-hatched overlay) due to pericardial effusion.

answers.explanation_why: While a tension pneumothorax can manifest with tachycardia and hypoxia, the lung is typically hyperresonant and not dull to percussion. Additionally, although mediastinal shift is seen on the chest x-ray of tension pneumothorax, absent lung markings would also be expected and there would not be a widened mediastinum.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A large pneumothorax (green overlay) has resulted in collapse of the right lung along the mediastinum (edge marked by white dashed line). No bronchovascular markings are seen in the right hemithorax. Additionally, the mediastinum has shifted to the contralateral left side (blue line and arrows), the right hemidiaphragm is depressed (red line and arrow), and the right intercostal spaces are widened (example indicated by white arrows).These findings are characteristic of tension pneumothorax.

question_text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after falling and hitting his left flank on a concrete block. On arrival, he has severe left-sided chest pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 32 years. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and a multivitamin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 17/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows multiple abrasions on his left flank and trunk. The left lateral chest wall is tender to palpation and bony crepitus is present. The remainder of the examination, including cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination, shows no abnormalities. Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative. An x-ray of the chest shows nondisplaced fractures of the left 4^th and 5^th ribs and clear lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after falling and hitting his left flank on a concrete block. On arrival, he has severe left-sided chest pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 32 years. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and a multivitamin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 17/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows multiple abrasions on his left flank and trunk. The left lateral chest wall is tender to palpation and bony crepitus is present. The remainder of the examination, including cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination, shows no abnormalities. Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative. An x-ray of the chest shows nondisplaced fractures of the left 4th and 5th ribs and clear lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has traumatic fracture of two ribs and requires treatment to prevent atelectasis.
learning_objective: Recognize traumatic rib fractures, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Continuous positive airway pressure is indicated for refractory atelectasis following rib fractures. It is not needed as an initial preventive measure for rib fractures without refractory atelectasis, especially since it can cause patient discomfort, gastric distention, hypoventilation, and barotrauma.

Prophylactic antibiotic therapy could be considered for prevention of wound infection if the patient's rib fractures involved open, dirty wounds. However, there is no mention of these findings in the vignette, and antibiotic prophylaxis does not play a role in the prevention of pneumonia following rib fractures.

Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary in the treatment of severe or complicated rib fracture cases, especially in cases involving flail chest. But flail chest is a complication involving three or more rib fractures. In addition, this patient does not show the paradoxical chest movement typical of flail chest, nor does he have evidence of respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxemia). Although he has shallow breathing, it is most likely due to the pain he is experiencing.

answers.content: Admission and surveillance in the intensive care unit
answers.explanation_why: Admission and surveillance in the intensive care unit may be warranted in older patients with ≥ 6 rib fractures, or in those with evidence of complications such as pneumothorax or hemothorax. This patient's chest x-ray shows only two fractured ribs and clear lung fields bilaterally, ruling out pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Conservative fracture management is recommended for patients who have < 3 rib fractures and no evidence of fracture displacement, complications of rib fractures, or other traumatic fractures. In patients with a rib fracture, the pain accompanying chest wall expansion can cause reflex hypoventilation and cough reflex suppression. Adequate pain control is important in preventing hypoventilation and its sequelae (e.g., atelectasis). NSAIDs are most commonly used in these patients, and can also be combined with opioids or intercostal nerve blocks if necessary.

Hospital admission is generally warranted in patients with ≥ 3 rib fractures, displaced rib fractures, signs of flail chest, or other complications of rib fractures (e.g., severe pulmonary contusions, renal laceration, splenic laceration). Rib fractures that cause pneumothorax or hemothorax may warrant tube thoracostomy. For falls in older individuals, a workup to identify risk factors for falls would be required.

Open reduction and internal fixation may be considered for treatment of some rib fractures, particularly those that cause flail chest or chest wall deformities. But flail chest is a complication involving three or more rib fractures. In addition, this patient does not show the paradoxical chest movement typical of flail chest, nor does he have evidence of respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxemia). Although he has shallow breathing, it is most likely due to the pain he is experiencing.

question_text:
A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is alert, has mild chest pain, and minimal shortness of breath. He has one episode of vomiting in the hospital. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his trunk and right upper extremity. There are coarse breath sounds over the right lung base. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallop. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. He subsequently develops increasing shortness of breath. Arterial blood gas analysis on 60% oxygen shows:

pH
7.36

pCO2
39 mm Hg

pO_2
68 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

18 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
81%

An x-ray of the chest shows patchy, irregular infiltrates over the right lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is alert, has mild chest pain, and minimal shortness of breath. He has one episode of vomiting in the hospital. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his trunk and right upper extremity. There are coarse breath sounds over the right lung base. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallop. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. He subsequently develops increasing shortness of breath. Arterial blood gas analysis on 60% oxygen shows: pH 7.36 pCO2 39 mm Hg pO2 68 mm Hg HCO3- 18 mEq/L O2 saturation 81% An x-ray of the chest shows patchy, irregular infiltrates over the right lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient developed dyspnea and hypoxia that worsens after giving fluids, indicating damage to the pulmonary vasculature.
learning_objective: Recognize pulmonary contusion.

answers.explanation_why: Blunt trauma to the thorax (e.g., mild chest pain and mild dyspnea on admission) can result in rib fractures or injury to lobar bronchi, and thereby cause a pneumothorax, which also manifests with dyspnea and hypoxemia. However, the classic findings in pneumothorax (e.g., decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance on the affected side, increased radiolucency on chest x-ray) are missing.

Tracheobronchial injury (TBI) has many causes, including trauma to the chest or neck, deceleration injury, and/or inhalation of hot smoke and noxious gases (usually in association with burns). In the case of TBI due to blunt trauma, injury usually occurs within 2 cm of the carina or at the origin of lobar bronchi. In such a scenario, TBI would manifest with acute dyspnea, as well as clinical features of subcutaneous emphysema (e.g., palpable crepitus), pneumomediastinum (e.g., Hamman crunch), and/or pneumothorax (e.g., decreased breath sounds, hyperresonant percussion note). The absence of characteristic clinical and radiological findings, as well as the delayed onset of dyspnea in this patient, makes the diagnosis of TBI unlikely.

images.title: Traumatic pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum with subcutaneous emphysema
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary contusion is the most common lung injury following blunt injury to the chest wall (e.g., during a motor vehicle accident). Damage to the capillaries in the lung parenchyma results in pulmonary edema and/or bleeding within contused lung tissue, which appears as a patchy infiltrate on chest x-ray. Excessive fluid administration worsens pulmonary edema, as the damaged capillaries leak fluid into the lungs.

Patients with pulmonary embolism may present with acute dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia, hypotension, and a localized patchy infiltrate on a chest x-ray. In the case of this 19-year-old man who was involved in a car accident, the most likely cause of pulmonary embolism is a fat embolus, which usually arises following a pelvic or long bone fracture. But the absence of a fracture makes a fat embolism unlikely. The x-ray findings of pulmonary embolism also tend to appear 12–24 hours after the event, not within an hour of trauma.

The most important risk factor for aspiration pneumonia in a polytrauma patient is loss of consciousness, which impairs the gag and cough reflexes. However, this patient never lost consciousness. Patients with aspiration pneumonia may also present with dyspnea, hypoxemia, and a patchy infiltrate on chest x-ray. Moreover, clinical and radiological features of acute aspiration pneumonia usually develop over the course of 12–24 hours after aspiration and not immediately upon arrival at the hospital.

A massive hemothorax can manifest with acute dyspnea, hypoxemia, tachycardia, and hypotension. However, a hemothorax appears on a chest x-ray as a singular and continuous collection of fluid in the dependent portion of the thorax, not as patchy infiltrates.

Acute respiratory distress (ARDS) also manifests with acute dyspnea, hypoxemia, and alveolar or interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray. However, ARDS arises within the context of a severe inflammatory reaction that typically develops over the course of 12–36 hours after the initial insult. The appearance of dyspnea and hypoxia within an hour of the event, as well as the localization of the infiltrate in the right lung base (ARDS affects the entire lung parenchyma), makes ARDS highly unlikely. ARDS can occur as a complication of this patient's condition.

question_text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-hour history of worsening chest pain and dyspnea. Six days ago, he fell in the shower and since then has had mild pain in his left chest. He appears pale and anxious. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the left lung base. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) hematoma over the left lower chest. An x-ray of the chest shows fractures of the left 8^th and 9^th rib, increased opacity of the left lung, and mild tracheal deviation to the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-hour history of worsening chest pain and dyspnea. Six days ago, he fell in the shower and since then has had mild pain in his left chest. He appears pale and anxious. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the left lung base. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) hematoma over the left lower chest. An x-ray of the chest shows fractures of the left 8th and 9th rib, increased opacity of the left lung, and mild tracheal deviation to the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Chest pain, dyspnea, decreased breath sounds, and dullness to percussion over the left lung base following a rib fracture in conjunction with this patient's x-ray findings (increased opacity and tracheal deviation to the contralateral side) suggest a large hemothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize a large hemothorax, and choose the most appropriate intervention for chest drainage.

answers.content: Admission to the ICU and observation
answers.explanation_why: Most patients with a hemothorax will require admission to the ICU. However, a large hemothorax must be drained immediately because blood in the pleural cavity may clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection).

answers.content: Needle thoracostomy in the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line
answers.explanation_why: Insertion of a needle in the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line can be used as an emergency treatment for tension pneumothorax because it allows the trapped air in the pleural cavity to escape. Tension pneumothorax may develop if a rib fracture causes a pulmonary laceration that fails to seal and can manifest with chest pain, dyspnea, decreased breath sounds, and contralateral deviation of the trachea. However, a patient with pneumothorax would have hyperresonant lung fields on percussion instead of dullness on the affected site. Also, a chest x-ray would show increased radiolucency and decreased lung markings rather than increased opacity.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A large pneumothorax (green overlay) has resulted in collapse of the right lung along the mediastinum (edge marked by white dashed line). No bronchovascular markings are seen in the right hemithorax. Additionally, the mediastinum has shifted to the contralateral left side (blue line and arrows), the right hemidiaphragm is depressed (red line and arrow), and the right intercostal spaces are widened (example indicated by white arrows).These findings are characteristic of tension pneumothorax.

answers.content: Needle thoracentesis in the eighth intercostal space at the posterior axillary line
answers.explanation_why: Needle thoracocentesis in the eighth intercostal space at the posterior axillary line, with the patient in a supine position, is used for diagnostic pleural taps. Needle aspiration is not the treatment of choice for a hemothorax because a drain with a larger caliber is required for complete evacuation of blood from the pleural cavity. Incomplete evacuation of blood may lead to clot formation and subsequently a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection).

In a patient with a hemothorax, urgent thoracotomy is indicated if more than 1500 mL of blood has been drained from the pleural cavity, if the rate of blood loss exceeds 200 mL/hour for 2–4 hours, and/or if multiple transfusions are required. However, thoracotomy is not the first-line therapy because a different procedure should first be employed to improve lung expansion and to assess the amount of blood loss.

Pericardiocentesis is the treatment of choice for cardiac tamponade, which can result from hemopericardium following thoracic trauma and manifests with dyspnea and chest pain. However, a hemopericardium usually develops following penetrating injuries to the chest wall and is unlikely in a patient with low-energy blunt chest trauma. Moreover, this patient has none of the classical clinical manifestations of cardiac tamponade, which include low systolic blood pressure (due to decreased stroke volume), distention of neck veins (due to impaired right ventricular filling), and/or muffled heart sounds. Tracheal deviation and increased lung opacity are not associated with isolated cardiac tamponade. Instead, a chest x-ray is likely to reveal an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

answers.content: Chest tube insertion in the fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line
answers.explanation_why:
Chest tube insertion into the 4^th to 5^th intercostal space at the midaxillary line is the treatment of choice for all patients with moderate to large hemothoraces. Alternatively, the chest tube can be inserted into lower intercostal spaces with ultrasound guidance. The chest tube should be placed posteriorly for optimal fluid drainage. A hemothorax must be drained in most cases because blood in the pleural cavity will clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection). Conservative management may be considered to treat small hemothoraces in consultation with a specialist but has a significant failure rate.

Thoracotomy is indicated if chest tube output is > 1500 mL directly after placement, 200 mL/hour for 2–4 hours, or if multiple transfusions are required.

images.title: Hemothorax following rib fracture
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of patient with history of rib fracture from a fall 10 days prior and left-sided chest pain accompanied by new dyspnea and orthopneaThe margins of the descending thoracic aorta (dashed line) and left hemidiaphragm are obscured by extensive air space disease (green overlay) and pleural effusion; a meniscus (red line) helps confirm the presence of the effusion. In view of the trauma history, the likely causes are pulmonary contusion and hemothorax. The slightly high position of the gastric bubble (GB) also suggests the presence of left lower lobe atelectasis. The right lung and cardiac silhouette are normal.Circle: fracture of the anterior left seventh rib

question_text: A 69-year-old man is scheduled to undergo a total pancreatectomy in one month. He has a history of chronic pancreatitis, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and severe osteoarthritis in both knees. He is unable to climb the stairs because of knee pain and only walks indoors around his house. He has severe abdominal pain due to chronic pancreatitis but does not report any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes and consumed 4–6 beers daily for 25 years but quit smoking and alcohol consumption 5 years ago. Current medications include insulin, metoprolol, lisinopril, rosuvastatin, ibuprofen, and pregabalin. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination and a 12-lead ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for assessing this patient's perioperative cardiac risk?
content_preview: A 69-year-old man is scheduled to undergo a total pancreatectomy in one month. He has a history of chronic pancreatitis, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and severe osteoarthritis in both knees. He is unable to climb the stairs because of knee pain and only walks indoors around his house. He has severe abdominal pain due to chronic pancreatitis but does not report any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes and consumed 4–6 beers daily for 25 years but quit smoking and alcohol consumption 5 years ago. Current medications include insulin, metoprolol, lisinopril, rosuvastatin, ibuprofen, and pregabalin. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination and a 12-lead ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for assessing this patient's perioperative cardiac risk?
hint: The combination of high-risk surgery (major intraabdominal surgery) and multiple cardiovascular risk factors (insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia) indicates a high risk of myocardial infarction in the intra- and postoperative periods.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for preoperative cardiac risk assessment, and choose the most appropriate stress test.

answers.explanation_why: Ambulatory ECG monitoring is indicated when standard ECG fails to provide information about symptoms such as palpitations or unexplained syncope, but it is not used to assess preoperative cardiac risk. Additionally, this patient has no history of rhythm or conduction abnormalities.

The goal of preoperative cardiac stress testing (CST) is to identify patients who might require cardiac revascularization before nonemergent surgeries. Preoperative CST should be considered for a patient who has a high major adverse cardiac event risk and poor or unknown functional capacity. CST is performed using ECG or cardiac imaging (e.g., stress echocardiography, myocardial perfusion imaging). An exercise stress test can be performed if the patient is able to achieve ≥ 5 metabolic equivalents using the chosen exercise modality. For patients who are unable to do so, pharmacological stress testing (i.e., with adenosine, dipyridamole, regadenoson, or dobutamine) is the most appropriate option. If a stress test is abnormal, preoperative revascularization (percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting) can be considered to decrease the risk of major adverse cardiac events.

Nonstress echocardiography is not routinely indicated for the preoperative evaluation of patients undergoing noncardiac surgery, but it may be performed if there are specific indications for the test, such as heart failure, new onset (or exacerbation) of cardiac symptoms, or known valvular heart disease.

Coronary CT angiography (CCTA) is performed in patients who are symptomatic (with angina or angina equivalents) and have an intermediate to high pretest probability of coronary artery disease (CAD). Coronary angiography, regardless of whether performed noninvasively (with a CT scan) or invasively (using cardiac catheterization), should not be performed as the first step to assess perioperative cardiac risk in asymptomatic patients without known CAD.

answers.content: Serial troponin and natriuretic peptide measurement
answers.explanation_why: Serial troponin measurement is important when a patient is suspected to have an acute coronary syndrome (ACS) but plays no role in preoperative risk assessment for asymptomatic patients without evidence of ACS. While natriuretic peptide B is a biomarker that is increasingly being used to assess perioperative risk, its measurement is typically for patients known to have cardiovascular disease or suspected to have heart failure.

question_text:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.29

PCO_2

33 mm Hg

PO_2

65 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

15 mEq/L

A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.29 PCO2 33 mm Hg PO2 65 mm Hg HCO3- 15 mEq/L A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
hint: There are many ways that physicians monitor volume status, but some are more reliable than others in the absence of confounding medications or illnesses.
learning_objective: Recognize indicators of inadequate fluid resuscitation, and recall the expected urine output for adequate end-organ perfusion.

answers.explanation_why: High pulse pressure is usually caused by an increase in stroke volume (e.g., normal exercise, aortic regurgitation) or a decrease in arterial compliance (e.g., atherosclerosis) and would likely increase following fluid resuscitation. However, pulse pressure is an indicator of stroke volume and not a direct indicator of end-organ perfusion. Fluid resuscitation aims to achieve adequate end-organ perfusion, so a change in pulse pressure is not the best indicator to evaluate fluid resuscitation.

answers.content: Urine output of 25 mL in 3 hours
answers.explanation_why:
The goal of fluid resuscitation is to maintain adequate end-organ perfusion and to restore intravascular volume. Since renal blood flow (and therefore GFR) is highly sensitive to changes in blood pressure and intravascular volume, urine output can serve as a surrogate measure to determine if fluid resuscitation is adequate. Ideally, urine output in adults should be greater than 0.5 mL/kg/hr. Therefore, a 70-kg man should have a urine output of 35–70 mL/hr. A urine output of 25mL in 3 hours suggests that his kidneys are not receiving adequate blood flow and therefore that he has not received adequate fluid resuscitation.

With adequate fluid resuscitation, an increase in some of the other indices, such as pulse pressure and Glasgow coma scale, might occur before a change in urine output is apparent. However, these parameters are not specific indicators of end-organ perfusion. Other parameters, such as lactate and a base deficit, are more useful for determining the prognosis than for guiding fluid therapy.

Confusion, lethargy, and even coma can be seen in patients with severe shock. However, a low Glasgow coma score (GCS) following trauma may be caused by a number of factors, including hypotension, hypoxia, and intracranial hemorrhage. Therefore, the GCS should not be used as a guide for fluid therapy.

An increase in serum lactate (> 4 mEq/L) may indicate tissue hypoxia due to inadequate tissue perfusion. However, serum lactate levels are not used to determine whether fluid resuscitation is inadequate because, even after adequate fluid resuscitation and correction of tissue hypoperfusion, lactate levels may not reach normal levels (< 2 mEq/L) for a few hours. Lactate clearance may take even longer in critically ill patients as a result of a prolonged lactate half-life (due to hepatic and/or renal dysfunction) and/or increased glycolysis. In trauma patients, elevated lactate levels are associated with increased mortality and are used to evaluate the prognosis.

A prolonged capillary refill time (≥ 3 seconds) is seen as a result of peripheral vasoconstriction in patients with hypotension. However, capillary refill is not the most direct measure of organ perfusion and adequate volume resuscitation, as it can be affected by confounding factors (e.g., ambient temperature, lighting, physical exam techniques, peripheral artery disease, blood viscosity).

This patient has an increased base deficit (> 2 mEq/L), which indicates metabolic acidosis (most likely due to lactic acidosis from inadequate perfusion and fluid resuscitation). Normalization of the base deficit (< 2 mmol/L) following fluid resuscitation would suggest an improvement in tissue perfusion and a more favorable prognosis, not inadequate fluid resuscitation.

question_text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-day history of fever and chills. During this period, he has had generalized weakness, chest pain, and night sweats. He has a bicuspid aortic valve and recurrent migraine attacks.  He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. He does not drink alcohol. He has experimented with intravenous drugs in the past but has not used any illicit drugs in the last 2 months. Current medications include propranolol and a multivitamin. He appears ill. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 150/50 mm Hg. On pulmonary examination, diffuse crackles are heard. A grade 3/6 high-pitched, early diastolic, decrescendo murmur is best heard along the left sternal border. An S_3 gallop is heard. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
13,300/mm^3

Platelet count
270,000/mm^3

Serum

 Glucose
92 mg/dL

 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL

 Total bilirubin
0.4 mg/dL

 AST
25 U/L

 ALT
28 U/L

Three sets of blood cultures are sent to the laboratory. Transthoracic echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. In addition to antibiotic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-day history of fever and chills. During this period, he has had generalized weakness, chest pain, and night sweats. He has a bicuspid aortic valve and recurrent migraine attacks. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. He does not drink alcohol. He has experimented with intravenous drugs in the past but has not used any illicit drugs in the last 2 months. Current medications include propranolol and a multivitamin. He appears ill. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 150/50 mm Hg. On pulmonary examination, diffuse crackles are heard. A grade 3/6 high-pitched, early diastolic, decrescendo murmur is best heard along the left sternal border. An S3 gallop is heard. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 13,300/mm3 Platelet count 270,000/mm3 Serum Glucose 92 mg/dL Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL Total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL AST 25 U/L ALT 28 U/L Three sets of blood cultures are sent to the laboratory. Transthoracic echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. In addition to antibiotic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient with a history of bicuspid aortic valve and IV drug use presents with infective endocarditis (IE). The widened pulse pressure and early diastolic murmur along the left sternal border suggest acute aortic regurgitation as a complication, with the S_3 gallop and pulmonary edema indicating left-sided heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize infective endocarditis with acute aortic regurgitation and left-sided heart failure, and choose the most appropriate surgical intervention.

answers.content: Mechanical valve replacement of the tricuspid valve
answers.explanation_why: Mechanical valve replacement of the tricuspid valve is indicated for IE of the tricuspid valve causing congestive heart failure. However, tricuspid valve endocarditis would lead to right-sided heart failure, leading to distention of the neck veins and lower extremity edema. Additionally, this patient's murmur, widened pulse pressure, and acute left-sided heart failure are suggestive of aortic valve endocarditis.
Because the patient has an acute, life-threatening illness, urgent intervention is required. After acute intervention, echocardiography is indicated before discharge and in subsequent follow-ups.

answers.content: Mechanical valve replacement of the aortic valve
answers.explanation_why: The patient has acute aortic regurgitation and subsequent left-sided heart failure from IE, which together are an indication for surgical intervention. Further indications for surgical treatment of IE include uncontrolled infection, systemic embolization, prosthetic valve endocarditis, or fungal endocarditis. Mechanical valve replacement is the treatment of choice in a young (< 65 years of age) patient without contraindications for anticoagulation. Patients with current bleeding, history of intracranial hemorrhage, coagulopathy, or severe thrombocytopenia (< 50,000/mm^3) should be evaluated for porcine valve replacement as mechanical valves require lifelong anticoagulation.

images.title: Heart murmur in aortic and pulmonary insufficiency
images.description: Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

answers.content: Porcine valve replacement of the aortic valve
answers.explanation_why: Porcine valves are less durable than mechanical valves and have a 60–70% failure rate at 20 years if implanted in patients younger than 65 years of age. For this reason, porcine valve replacement is preferred in older patients (> 65 years) or in patients with contraindications to anticoagulation (e.g., bleeding, coagulopathy, severe thrombocytopenia). Since this patient is 25 years of age and has no such contraindications, a porcine valve is not indicated.

Cardiac MRI can provide high-quality images of the heart but is not always available and takes more time than other imaging modalities. As the diagnosis of acute aortic regurgitation is unambiguous, has been confirmed by echocardiography in this patient, and urgent intervention is required, cardiac MRI is not indicated.

answers.content: Surgical repair of the mitral valve
answers.explanation_why: Surgical repair of the mitral valve is indicated for IE of the mitral valve causing heart failure. This patient's early diastolic murmur heard best along the left sternal border and widened pulse pressure are consistent with aortic regurgitation, though, not a mitral valve pathology.
answers.explanation_but: Endocarditis of the mitral valve can cause mitral stenosis, which can also lead to left-sided heart failure. Mitral stenosis presents with a delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, but it is best heard at the heart apex and does not lead to a widened pulse pressure.

images.title: Heart murmur in mitral stenosis
images.description: Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

answers.explanation_why: Cardiac catheterization would be appropriate in patients who are undergoing workup for acute coronary syndrome. This patient has IE and acute left-sided heart failure, which necessitates another intervention.

Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) is indicated in patients who require aortic valve replacement but are poor surgical candidates for open repair. As it is indicated for patients with severe aortic stenosis, it would not be useful for this patient's acute aortic regurgitation. Additionally, active IE is an absolute contraindication for TAVI.

images.title: Heart murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis
images.description: A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.
