question_text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine medical check-up. The patient feels well. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and recurrent panic attacks. He had a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. He underwent a left inguinal hernia repair at the age of 25 years. A colonoscopy 2 years ago was normal. He works as a nurse at a local hospital. He is married and has two children. His father died of prostate cancer at the age of 70 years. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit following his myocardial infarction. He drinks one to two beers on the weekends. He has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, fluoxetine, metformin, and a multivitamin. He appears well-nourished. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur that is best heard at the apex. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine medical check-up. The patient feels well. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and recurrent panic attacks. He had a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. He underwent a left inguinal hernia repair at the age of 25 years. A colonoscopy 2 years ago was normal. He works as a nurse at a local hospital. He is married and has two children. His father died of prostate cancer at the age of 70 years. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit following his myocardial infarction. He drinks one to two beers on the weekends. He has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, fluoxetine, metformin, and a multivitamin. He appears well-nourished. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur that is best heard at the apex. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This type of murmur will typically occur earlier during systole and with increased intensity when the patient abruptly stands up from a squatting position or performs the Valsalva maneuver.
learning_objective: Recognize mitral valve prolapse.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, blowing murmur during diastole heard best at the 2^nd left intercostal space. The location of the murmur at the apex and the occurrence during systole make this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Heart murmur in aortic and pulmonary insufficiency
images.description: Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

answers.explanation_why: Mitral valve stenosis manifests as a low-frequency, mid-diastolic rumble and a loud S1 heard best at the apex. This patient has a systolic murmur, making this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Heart murmur in mitral stenosis
images.description: Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

answers.explanation_why: Tricuspid valve stenosis manifests as a low-frequency, mid-diastolic rumble heard best at the lower parasternal region. This patient has a systolic heart murmur, making this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Heart murmur in tricuspid stenosis
images.description: Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo

answers.explanation_why: Mitral valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that may radiate to the axilla and is best heard at the apex. While the location and the occurrence during systole of this patient's murmur may suggest mitral regurgitation, the timing (mid-to-late systole) makes this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Heart murmur in ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation, and tricuspid regurgitation
images.description: Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

answers.explanation_why: Tricuspid valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur heard best at the lower parasternal region. While the occurrence during systole of this patient's murmur may suggest tricuspid regurgitation, the character, point of maximum intensity, and timing make this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Heart murmur in ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation, and tricuspid regurgitation
images.description: Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

answers.explanation_why: Aortic valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is best heard at the left sternal border or the apex. This patient has a systolic murmur, suggesting a different answer option.

images.title: Heart murmur in aortic and pulmonary insufficiency
images.description: Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

answers.explanation_why: Aortic valve stenosis manifests as a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is typically heard best at the right upper sternal border, not at the apex.

images.title: Heart murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis
images.description: A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary valve stenosis primarily manifests during early childhood as a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the 2^nd left intercostal space. In adults, it may result from carcinoid syndrome or chronic rheumatic fever. The location of the murmur at the apex suggests another diagnosis.

images.title: Heart murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis
images.description: A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

answers.explanation_why:
Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in the US and is usually asymptomatic, as in this patient. It typically manifests as a high-frequency, midsystolic click combined with a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur heard best at the apex, which is consistent with this patient's auscultatory findings. Mitral valve prolapse is most often idiopathic, but can also be secondary to conditions such as rheumatic heart disease, infectious endocarditis, connective tissue disorders, or myocardial infarction (MI). Following MI, ischemia of the papillary muscles and subsequent rupture of the chordae tendinae may cause one or both mitral valve leaflets to prolapse into the left atrium, which leads to acute symptoms of regurgitation. Even though this patient has a history of MI, his asymptomatic presentation 3 years later suggests an idiopathic etiology.

See “Auscultation in valvular defects” table.

images.title: Heart murmur in mitral valve prolapse
images.description: High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

question_text:
A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of worsening upper abdominal pain that he first noticed this morning after waking up. The pain is of tearing and burning quality and radiates to his back. Yesterday, he underwent an upper endoscopy and was diagnosed with gastritis and a large hiatal hernia. He has hypertension, hypercholesteremia, and a left bundle branch block that was diagnosed 5 years ago. The patient's mother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years, and his father died of aortic dissection at the age of 65 years. The patient smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks three beers daily. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, amlodipine, atorvastatin, and pantoprazole. The patient appears to be in mild distress. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 135/89 mm Hg in the left arm and 132/90 mm Hg in the right arm. Cardiopulmonary examination shows crackling with every heartbeat. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
16.0 g/dL

Leukocyte count
11,000/mm^3

Na^+

140 mEq/L

K^+

4.2 mEq/L

Cl^-

101 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

25 mEq/L

Creatinine
1.3 mg/dL

Alanine aminotransferase
21 U/L

Aspartate aminotransferase
38 U/L

Lipase

40 U/L (N = 14–280)

Troponin I
0.02 ng/mL

Chest x-ray shows a large hiatal hernia and mediastinal lucency. A 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia and a left bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

The pain is of tearing and burning quality and radiates to his back. Yesterday, he underwent an upper endoscopy and was diagnosed with gastritis and a large hiatal hernia. He has hypertension, hypercholesteremia, and a left bundle branch block that was diagnosed 5 years ago. The patient's mother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years, and his father died of aortic dissection at the age of 65 years. The patient smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks three beers daily. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, amlodipine, atorvastatin, and pantoprazole. The patient appears to be in mild distress. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 135/89 mm Hg in the left arm and 132/90 mm Hg in the right arm. Cardiopulmonary examination shows crackling with every heartbeat. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 16.0 g/dL Leukocyte count 11,000/mm3 Na+ 140 mEq/L K+ 4.2 mEq/L Cl- 101 mEq/L HCO3- 25 mEq/L Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL Alanine aminotransferase 21 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase 38 U/L Lipase 40 U/L (N = 14–280) Troponin I 0.02 ng/mL Chest x-ray shows a large hiatal hernia and mediastinal lucency. A 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia and a left bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: This patient underwent an upper endoscopy yesterday and now presents with upper abdominal pain, tachycardia, and crackling with every heartbeat associated with lucency of the mediastinum, indicating mediastinal emphysema (Hamman sign). The combination of these findings suggests iatrogenic esophageal perforation.
learning_objective: Recognize iatrogenic esophageal perforation, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Coronary angiography may be indicated in the workup of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) if elevated troponins confirm a myocardial infarction. As this patient's troponin level is normal despite epigastric pain lasting over one day, a myocardial infarction that might warrant coronary angiography is very unlikely. Additionally, ACS would not explain the mediastinal emphysema present on examination.

A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the aorta can be used to evaluate for aortic pathologies (e.g., aortic dissection). Although this patient has several risk factors for aortic dissection (e.g., hypertension, smoking) and tearing pain that radiates to his back, mediastinal emphysema would not be an expected finding in a patient with aortic dissection. Also, patients with aortic dissection often have asymmetrical blood pressure and pulse readings between the limbs. This patient's symptoms after upper endoscopy suggest another diagnosis.

images.title: Aortic dissection (Stanford B)
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis (with IV contrast; venous phase, axial plane)A Stanford type B (DeBakey type III) aortic dissection extends from the origin of the left subclavian artery into both iliac arteries. The great arteries arise from the true lumen (green). The celiac trunk (CT), superior mesenteric artery (SMA), and right renal artery (ARD) also arise from the true lumen. The left renal artery (ARS) and inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) arise from the false lumen. The malrotated kidneys (K) show perfusion irregularities.Additional findings include bilateral basal atelectasis (blue overlay), pleural effusions (yellow overlay), right renal cyst, colonic and gallbladder contrast (from a previous CT), foley catheter, and postoperative changes with left periiliac and anterior abdominal wall hematomas. A right internal jugular catheter (red overlay) is well-positioned and terminates in the superior vena cava. The left brachiocephalic vein (BCV) is occluded and a left internal jugular catheter (red overlay) terminates in a small vein anterior to the aortic arch.

answers.explanation_why: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) should be delayed in this patient with suspected iatrogenic esophageal perforation as the endoscope and/or air insufflation may cause further dissection of the perforation. If an esophageal rupture is suspected, diagnostic endoscopy is reserved for patients with a poorly localized esophageal perforation on standard imaging and in whom endoscopic treatment is indicated. EGD should be considered if this patient's symptoms of burning epigastric pain were due to worsening gastritis – however, mediastinal emphysema is highly suggestive of esophageal perforation. If esophageal perforation is suspected during upper endoscopy (not on the next day, as in this patient), careful endoscopic inspection without insufflation is warranted to localize the esophageal defect.

Abdominal ultrasound is the most useful initial test for diagnosing acute pancreatitis. Although this patient's radiating upper abdominal pain and history of alcohol use may suggest acute pancreatitis, his normal lipase level makes pancreatic involvement highly unlikely. In addition, pancreatitis does not explain subcutaneous emphysema present on exam. An abdominal ultrasound would have limited utility in establishing the diagnosis in this case.

Iatrogenic trauma is the most common etiology of esophageal perforation (e.g., following upper endoscopy). While this patient's x-ray findings and Hamman sign already suggest pneumomediastinum, gastrografin contrast esophagography is indicated as a confirmatory test to visualize the potential defect and assess its size and exact location. Gastrografin is preferred over barium as a contrast agent because it is water-soluble and less irritating; extravasation of barium may cause mediastinitis and subsequent fibrosis. There is no free air under the diaphragms on CXR, thus gastric perforation is unlikely.

If Boerhaave syndrome is suspected, a chest x-ray is conducted first, which may show lucency from mediastinal and/or subcutaneous air. While gastrografin contrast esophagography is usually the preferred confirmatory test, there may be false negatives in up to 20% of cases. The ease of a CT scan has made CT a popular alternative in hemodynamically unstable patients and/or if x-ray and contrast esophagogram are inconclusive. In a patient with esophageal perforation, the CT may demonstrate intramural swelling/hematoma and periesophageal air collections tracking into the surrounding tissues.

Although a barium swallow is commonly used to detect changes of the esophageal wall (e.g., strictures, dilations, neoplastic growths), water-insoluble barium entering the mediastinum through a perforation (e.g., traumatic perforation, as suspected in this patient, Boerhaave syndrome) can induce inflammation, causing mediastinitis and subsequent mediastinal fibrosis. Another test is more appropriate for the initial diagnosis of esophageal perforation.

question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling 7 feet onto a flat-top wooden post. On arrival, he is in severe pain and breathing rapidly. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. There is an impact wound in the left fourth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Auscultation shows tracheal deviation to the right and absent breath sounds over the left lung. There is dullness to percussion over the left chest. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray is shown. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling 7 feet onto a flat-top wooden post. On arrival, he is in severe pain and breathing rapidly. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. There is an impact wound in the left fourth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Auscultation shows tracheal deviation to the right and absent breath sounds over the left lung. There is dullness to percussion over the left chest. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray is shown. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's chest x-ray shows left-sided opacity and blunting of the costophrenic angle.
learning_objective: Recognize a hemothorax.

answers.explanation_why: Cardiac tamponade may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed, and heart sounds would be muffled on auscultation. Also, tracheal deviation would not be present in an isolated case of cardiac tamponade.

Bronchial rupture would manifest with subcutaneous emphysema and hemoptysis. Clinical features of a pneumothorax such as hyperresonant lung fields would also be present in distal tracheobronchial tree injuries. The absence of any of these findings suggests a different diagnosis.

images.title: Traumatic pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum with subcutaneous emphysema
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

answers.explanation_why: Tension pneumothorax may manifest with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, decreased breath sounds on the affected side, and deviation of the trachea to the opposite side. However, neck veins would be distended instead of collapsed because the mediastinal shift that occurs with a tension pneumothorax compresses the superior vena cava. Also, lung fields on the affected side would be hyperresonant instead of dull on percussion.

A flail chest could manifest with respiratory distress and tachypnea. A patient with flail chest classically exhibits paradoxical movement of a part of the chest wall on respiration. Although this sign may be absent due to respiratory splinting, a mediastinal shift (tracheal deviation), decreased breath sounds, and a dull note on percussion are not characteristic signs of a flail chest. The absence of bony crepitus also suggests that the patient does not have a rib fracture. A different diagnosis must be considered.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

answers.explanation_why: Hemothorax can develop following blunt chest trauma. This patient exhibits all the signs and symptoms of a massive hemothorax, i.e., tachycardia, hypotension, tachypnea, flat neck veins, decreased breath sounds, and dullness on percussion on the affected side, as well as tracheal deviation to the opposite side. A hemothorax must be drained in most cases because blood in the pleural cavity may clot if not evacuated, resulting in a trapped lung (impaired lung expansion due to the clot) or an empyema (due to clot infection). Treatment usually consists of chest tube insertion into the 4^th–5^th intercostal space at the midaxillary line in order to allow the blood to drain away and improve lung ventilation. Conservative management may be considered to treat small hemothoraces in consultation with a specialist but has a significant failure rate.

images.title: Pleural effusion and passive atelectasis
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)There is marked opacification (green overlay) of the middle and lower left hemithorax from pleural effusion and passive atelectasis of the adjacent lung. No gastric air bubble is seen projecting over the lower left hemithorax to suggest marked elevation of the left hemidiaphragm from a large amount of atelectasis, but concave upper lateral borders, or menisci (white dashed lines), help confirm the presence of effusion extending to the mid thorax.The margins of the cardiac silhouette and left hemidiaphragm are obscured. Additionally, the cardiac silhouette is shifted slightly to the right (indicated by blue line and arrow) and the left bronchial tree is slightly elevated (indicated by black lines and arrow).In the right hemithorax, a small meniscus from effusion is seen laterally (indicated by red line). Additionally, increased opacification projects through the right hemidiaphragm indicating effusion in the posterior sulcus (red overlay).

question_text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and is in severe pain. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Examination shows superficial abrasions and diffuse crepitus at the left shoulder level. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The upper part of the left chest wall moves inward during inspiration. Breath sounds are absent on the left. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and is in severe pain. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Examination shows superficial abrasions and diffuse crepitus at the left shoulder level. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The upper part of the left chest wall moves inward during inspiration. Breath sounds are absent on the left. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Mechanical ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure helps counter the paradoxical breathing described here.
learning_objective: Recognize flail chest as a cause of paradoxical chest movement.

answers.explanation_why: Diaphragmatic rupture can occur after high-energy trauma and, in case of herniation of abdominal organs into the chest, cause respiratory distress with decreased breath sounds in the affected hemithorax. However, in such a scenario, bowel sounds would be heard during auscultation of the affected hemithorax. In addition, diaphragmatic rupture would not explain the paradoxical motion of a segment of the left chest wall.

Phrenic nerve damage may be caused by trauma, malignancy, or surgery and result in partial or complete paralysis of the diaphragm. Phrenic nerve paralysis may be asymptomatic or manifest with dyspnea. Unilateral phrenic nerve paralysis leads to the paradoxical upward movement of the affected hemidiaphragm. The condition would not explain the paradoxical motion of a segment of the left chest wall.

Cardiac tamponade typically presents with hypotension, tachycardia, jugular venous distention, and pulsus paradoxus. Although this patient is hypotensive and tachycardic, no other signs of cardiac tamponade are present. In addition, cardiac tamponade would not explain the paradoxical motion of the chest wall.

Sternal fracture classically occurs after blunt anterior chest trauma such as that caused by a motor vehicle collision. It is often associated with myocardial contusions. Although this patient may have an associated sternal fracture, this type of injury does not sufficiently explain his respiratory distress and the paradoxical movement of the chest wall.

A flail chest is the detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall as a result of ≥ 3 adjacent rib fractures in ≥ 2 places. This floating rib cage segment is decoupled from the chest wall and causes paradoxical chest movement. Upon inspiration, as the intrathoracic pressure drops, the unstable segment will be pulled inwards by the negative pressure, and during expiration, the floating segment moves outward. This condition usually results from high-energy blunt trauma to the chest (e.g., motor vehicle collision). Patients with flail chest commonly present with features of respiratory distress (e.g., dyspnea, tachypnea), which can be due to hypoventilation (as a result of pain), pulmonary contusions, pneumothorax, and/or hemothorax.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

question_text: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left shoulder pain after falling from a height of approximately 10 feet while rock climbing 5 hours ago. He initially thought the pain would resolve with rest but it became more severe over the last 2 hours. Last year while rock climbing he fell onto his right shoulder and “needed a sling to fix it.” He has psoriasis. His only medication is topical clobetasol. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/70 mm Hg. Examination shows full passive and active range of motion of the left shoulder. There is no tenderness to palpation at the acromioclavicular joint. There are silvery plaques over both knees and elbows. Abdominal examination shows severe tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant with voluntary guarding. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes are within the reference range. Chest x-ray is normal. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no evidence of free intraperitoneal fluid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left shoulder pain after falling from a height of approximately 10 feet while rock climbing 5 hours ago. He initially thought the pain would resolve with rest but it became more severe over the last 2 hours. Last year while rock climbing he fell onto his right shoulder and “needed a sling to fix it.” He has psoriasis. His only medication is topical clobetasol. His pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/70 mm Hg. Examination shows full passive and active range of motion of the left shoulder. There is no tenderness to palpation at the acromioclavicular joint. There are silvery plaques over both knees and elbows. Abdominal examination shows severe tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant with voluntary guarding. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes are within the reference range. Chest x-ray is normal. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no evidence of free intraperitoneal fluid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Left upper quadrant abdominal pain, voluntary guarding, and referred shoulder pain (Kehr sign) in a patient who has fallen from a significant height indicates splenic injury.
learning_objective: Recognize splenic injury, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.content: Serial vital signs for at least nine hours
answers.explanation_why: The severity of abdominal injury determines whether hemodynamically stable patients can be managed nonoperatively with serial monitoring of vital signs. Although unsupported by high-quality evidence, serial monitoring of vital signs for a period of 9 hours without imaging may be a reasonable approach following trauma for hemodynamically stable patients with a low risk of abdominal injury. This patient, however, has fallen from a height of 10 feet and has left upper quadrant pain and guarding, as well as a positive Kehr sign, all of which indicate a splenic injury that requires additional abdominal imaging.

Abdominal CT with contrast is the most appropriate next step, following a negative FAST scan, in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with a suspected splenic injury. CT scan has greater specificity than ultrasonography for diagnosing splenic lacerations because it can visualize the vasculature and parenchyma of the spleen in high resolution. Findings on the CT scan are used to grade splenic injury and guide further management. CT scan can also rule out other concomitant injuries in cases of abdominal trauma, especially injuries involving retroperitoneal structures.

images.title: Lacerated spleen
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane; portal venous phase) of a 24 year-old patient after a high-speed front-impact crashThe spleen has an irregular contour (dashed outline) and heterogeneous enhancement. Intrasplenic low-attenuation rounded and linear areas are sites of laceration and hematoma formation. Multiple small high-density foci along the inferior aspect of the spleen indicate contrast extravasation (arrows) from active bleeding.Hemorrhage (green overlay) into the peritoneal space extends from the spleen inferiorly along the paracolic gutter. Hemorrhagic fluid is also seen along the liver (yellow overlay) and within the right paracolic gutter and pelvis (yellow overlay).Multiple thoracic spine fractures (examples indicated by arrowheads) are accompanied by paravertebral hematoma (red overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is a procedure that can be used in patients with blunt abdominal trauma to determine the presence of blood within the peritoneum. DPL should only be considered in hemodynamically unstable patients who have an inconclusive FAST scan. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and a FAST scan was negative for free intraperitoneal fluid. In addition, although highly sensitive, DPL has largely fallen out of favor because it is an invasive procedure; it may, however, be necessary in some cases (e.g., in resource-poor settings).

Shoulder radiographs are the first-line imaging modality in the diagnostic workup of traumatic shoulder injury (i.e., clavicle, proximal humerus, or scapula fractures; acromioclavicular or glenohumeral dislocations). However, the combination of left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, and a normal shoulder joint examination indicates that this patient's acute shoulder pain is most likely the result of referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign) rather than a traumatic shoulder injury.

An exploratory laparotomy is a surgical procedure that encompasses examination and treatment of the intraabdominal cavity for sources of bleeding in patients with blunt abdominal trauma. It is typically performed in hemodynamically unstable patients following the confirmation of free intraperitoneal fluid. This patient is hemodynamically stable and initial diagnostic imaging shows no evidence of intraabdominal bleeding. Therefore, an exploratory laparotomy is not appropriate at this time.

Left upper quadrant tenderness and guarding, the onset of left shoulder pain a few hours after the initial trauma, as well as a normal shoulder joint examination, indicate that the shoulder pain in this patient most likely results from referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation (Kehr sign), and is not the result of a traumatic shoulder injury. If shoulder injury were suspected, a shoulder MRI could be useful to image soft tissue of the shoulder such as the rotator cuff and acromioclavicular ligaments. However, MRI is not the first-line of imaging in a patient with a suspected traumatic shoulder injury.

question_text: A 74-year-old Hispanic man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of dizziness upon standing and a brief loss of consciousness one hour ago. The patient suddenly collapsed on his way to the bathroom after waking up in the morning. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and gout. The patient's mother died of a grand mal seizure at the age of 53 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. Current medications include ranitidine, dutasteride, tamsulosin, and allopurinol. He is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); 23 kg/m^2. He appears pale. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. A plopping sound is heard on auscultation, immediately followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 74-year-old Hispanic man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of dizziness upon standing and a brief loss of consciousness one hour ago. The patient suddenly collapsed on his way to the bathroom after waking up in the morning. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and gout. The patient's mother died of a grand mal seizure at the age of 53 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. Current medications include ranitidine, dutasteride, tamsulosin, and allopurinol. He is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); 23 kg/m2. He appears pale. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. A plopping sound is heard on auscultation, immediately followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with syncope, orthostatic hypotension (a drop of ≥ 20 mm Hg in systolic pressure from supine to standing), and a diastolic murmur over the apex, all of which suggest an obstruction of the blood flow into the left ventricle.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiac myxoma.

answers.explanation_why: Cardiac myxomas are most commonly located in the left atrium. They may be pedunculated, in which case they often present with position-dependent symptoms of obstructed blood flow through the atrioventricular valves, or they may embolize systemically. Additionally, patients may present with constitutional findings (e.g., weight loss, fever, or anemia). The typical auscultatory finding (also present in this patient) is an early diastolic “plop”, caused by a movement of the mobile tumor mass, followed by a mid-diastolic rumbling murmur best heard at the apex that results from the obstructed blood flow through the mitral valve, and mimics the murmur of mitral stenosis. Echocardiography is the diagnostic test of choice to visualize the tumor and to assess its location, size, attachment, and mobility. The only definitive treatment of cardiac myxoma is surgical resection.

images.title: Left atrial myxoma
images.description: Echocardiography (transthoracic; apical 4-chamber view)A rounded mass (green overlay) arises from the wall of the left atrium (LA).LV: left ventricle; RA: right atrium; RV: right ventricle

answers.explanation_why: Dilated cardiomyopathy is most commonly idiopathic, but can also be alcohol-induced. It usually manifests with signs of heart failure. While this patient consumes critical levels of alcohol and displays symptoms that may suggest impaired pump function of the heart (syncope, hypotension), dilated cardiomyopathy does not manifest with a position-dependent diastolic heart murmur.

Aortic valve stenosis is the most common valvular heart disease and may also manifest with dizziness and syncope. It should always be considered as a differential diagnosis in an older patient with a heart murmur, such as this one. The auscultatory finding of aortic valve stenosis is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur heard best over the 2^nd right intercostal space. However, this patient has a rumbling diastolic murmur heard best at the apex, which is not consistent with aortic valve stenosis.

Infective endocarditis should be suspected in any patient presenting with fever and a new heart murmur. While this patient has a murmur on auscultation, he is afebrile, making an infectious origin of his symptoms less likely. The occurrence of position-dependent symptoms and a peculiar plopping sound suggest another diagnosis.

Various drugs can cause (orthostatic) hypotension and may lead to syncope, including alpha-1 blockers. This patient is taking an alpha-1 blocker and presents with orthostatic hypotension. However, among the alpha-1 blockers, tamsulosin is the agent with the lowest potential of inducing hypotension because of its increased selectivity for alpha-1 receptors of the bladder neck and the prostatic urethra. The peculiar heart murmur of a diastolic “plop” followed by a rumble suggests a different diagnosis.

question_text: A 27-year-old soldier is brought to the emergency department of a military hospital 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle accident during a training exercise. He was an unrestrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and chest pain. He appears anxious. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows bruising on the chest, extremities, and abdomen. The lungs are clear to auscultation. He has normal heart sounds and flat neck veins. The abdomen is flat, soft, and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. High-flow oxygen and intravenous fluid therapy are initiated. A focused ultrasonographic assessment (FAST scan) shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 27-year-old soldier is brought to the emergency department of a military hospital 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle accident during a training exercise. He was an unrestrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and chest pain. He appears anxious. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows bruising on the chest, extremities, and abdomen. The lungs are clear to auscultation. He has normal heart sounds and flat neck veins. The abdomen is flat, soft, and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. High-flow oxygen and intravenous fluid therapy are initiated. A focused ultrasonographic assessment (FAST scan) shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The patient sustained a deceleration injury and has mediastinal widening on chest x-ray, suggesting blunt thoracic aortic injury.
learning_objective: Recognize blunt thoracic aortic injury, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test in a hemodynamically stable patient.

answers.explanation_why: Pericardiocentesis is indicated for the treatment of cardiac tamponade, which can occur following trauma (due to a hemopericardium) and cause chest pain, dyspnea, and a widened mediastinum. However, patients with cardiac tamponade typically have muffled heart sounds, hemodynamic instability, and distended (rather than flat) neck veins. The normal FAST scan and the absence of an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray make a hemopericardium unlikely.

Blunt force aortic injuries range from small intimal tears and intramural hematomas to aortic rupture. Contrast-enhanced CT angiography (CECT angiography) is indicated for the diagnosis of aortic injury in hemodynamically stable patients and should be performed if the patient has symptoms suggestive of aortic injury (e.g., chest pain), a history of high-energy trauma, or features that suggest aortic injury on the FAST scan (e.g., hemothorax) or chest x-ray (e.g., mediastinal widening, aortic knob loss). CECT angiography has high sensitivity and specificity, can screen for additional vascular injuries (e.g., abdominal aortic injury), and provides anatomical information for planning surgical management. Patients who are hemodynamically unstable should be urgently evaluated with transesophageal echocardiography in the operating room.

Although aortography, which is performed using vascular catheterization, was previously used to evaluate for aortic pathology, less invasive modalities that are more readily available are now preferred.

A transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) to identify thoracic aortic injury is indicated in patients who are hemodynamically unstable and cannot be transported safely for other imaging modalities. A hemodynamically stable patient requires a different imaging modality that provides more detailed anatomical information.
A chest tube can be used to treat patients with a pneumothorax or hemothorax. However, this patient's chest x-ray and FAST scan do not indicate the presence of either of these conditions.

Intubation with positive pressure ventilation may be indicated if the patient has evidence of a flail chest or is developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This patient's chest x-ray finding suggests a different diagnosis.

images.title: Widened mediastinum secondary to traumatic thoracic aortic injury
images.description: X-ray chest (AP view) of a patient with a recent history of a motor vehicle crashA lobulated convexity projects along the left superior mediastinum (green overlay and arrows) in the region of the aortic knob.The differential for the mediastinal widening includes a range of mediastinal soft tissue masses; however, traumatic mediastinal injury (particularly involving the thoracic aorta) is the primary concern in view of the trauma setting. CT angiography is the appropriate next imaging study in a hemodynamically stable patient.Green dashed line: normal margin of the aorta

question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to a small community health center after being stabbed in the abdomen during an altercation. The physician is working alone. The patient has shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and bleeding. He is alert and active. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 89/61 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm wound at the right subcostal region with active bleeding. The knife is still in the wound. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to a small community health center after being stabbed in the abdomen during an altercation. The physician is working alone. The patient has shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and bleeding. He is alert and active. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 89/61 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm wound at the right subcostal region with active bleeding. The knife is still in the wound. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: This hemodynamically unstable patient presents to a small community health center after a penetrating abdominal trauma that requires immediate surgery.
learning_objective: Recognize penetrating abdominal trauma with hemodynamic instability, and choose the most appropriate initial action.

answers.explanation_why: Bilateral tube thoracostomy is indicated in a patient with pneumothorax, pleural effusion, or intrathoracic hemorrhage. These conditions are associated with absent or decreased breath sounds, whereas this patient's lungs are clear to auscultation. Additionally, the stab wound is below the costal margin and therefore less likely to injure the lungs.

answers.content: Remove the knife carefully and apply pressure to the wound
answers.explanation_why: The knife might be acting as a tamponade on the wound, thereby concealing vascular damage and preventing further hemorrhage. Although emergency surgery is indicated, impaled foreign bodies should be removed under direct visualization in an operating room where bleeding can be controlled.

answers.content: Type and cross for transfusion of packed red blood cells
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient shows signs of active bleeding and will likely need blood transfusions, a type and cross is a blood test that takes time and would not address his primary problem of intraabdominal bleeding from a stab wound.

Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is the preferred method of endotracheal intubation in emergency settings because it obviates the need for bag valve mask ventilation and decreases the risk of vomiting and aspiration in patients who have not fasted. Although RSI may be indicated in this patient prior to undergoing surgery, immediate RSI is not indicated as he is conscious, has a patent airway, and is not at impending risk of respiratory failure or aspiration.

answers.content: Arrange for transport to the nearest trauma center
answers.explanation_why: In this patient with penetrating abdominal trauma, hypotension and tachycardia suggest intraabdominal hemorrhage, which needs to be controlled immediately. Although other lifesaving measures (i.e., fluid resuscitation) should also be conducted as soon as possible and might be done in parallel if more personnel were present, this physician is working alone. To prevent the patient from potentially bleeding to death, immediate transfer to an operating room is indicated. Establishing IV access and setting up fluids may be conducted after arranging transport or on the way to a trauma center. Once the patient is transferred, an exploratory laparotomy should be performed.

question_text: A 4-hour-old male newborn has perioral discoloration for the past several minutes. Oxygen by nasal cannula does not improve the cyanosis. He was delivered by cesarean delivery at 37 weeks' gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus that was well-controlled during the pregnancy. She has not received any immunizations since her childhood. The newborn's temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a 2/6 holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Echocardiography shows pulmonary arteries arising from the posterior left ventricle, and the aorta rising anteriorly from the right ventricle. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-hour-old male newborn has perioral discoloration for the past several minutes. Oxygen by nasal cannula does not improve the cyanosis. He was delivered by cesarean delivery at 37 weeks' gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus that was well-controlled during the pregnancy. She has not received any immunizations since her childhood. The newborn's temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a 2/6 holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Echocardiography shows pulmonary arteries arising from the posterior left ventricle, and the aorta rising anteriorly from the right ventricle. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Echocardiography findings are consistent with the diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA): In TGA, the systemic circulation is disconnected from pulmonary circulation and venous blood that is received by the right ventricle is pumped to the rest of the body without being oxygenated. TGA is more commonly associated with infants born to diabetic mothers.
learning_objective: Recognize transposition of the great arteries, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Without treatment, transposition of the great vessels is fatal. If the disease is allowed to follow its natural course, the mortality rate within the first year alone is about 90%.

TGA results in rapidly worsening hypoxemia and cyanosis shortly after birth, and relies on a patent ductus arteriosus. The ductus arteriosus is kept patent in fetal circulation by the effect of low partial pressure of oxygen in fetal circulation, as well as by endogenously produced prostaglandin E. After birth, the ductus arteriosus begins to close in response to an increase in the partial pressure of oxygen. Intravenously administered prostaglandin E1 keeps the ductus arteriosus open and allows mixing of blood between the pulmonary and systemic circulation. This effect is crucial for initial survival of infants with TGA because it is the only way to maintain oxygenation of the arterial blood until surgical repair can be performed.

images.title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
images.description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

answers.explanation_why: The ductus arteriosus is kept patent in fetal circulation by the low partial pressure of oxygen in fetal circulation, as well as by endogenously produced prostaglandin E. Indomethacin, a nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitor, closes the ductus arteriosus by decreasing prostaglandin synthesis. Because a patent ductus arteriosus is vital for this newborn's survival, administering indomethacin would be a grave mistake.

An arterial switch operation is required in all neonates with transposition of the great arteries. This procedure is usually delayed for 2–3 days until the high pulmonary vascular resistance of fetal circulation decreases. A different therapeutic measure is required immediately to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus while preparations for surgery are made.
A CT angiography is not indicated in this newborn with transposition of the great vessels because it would not alter the clinical management and echocardiography has already confirmed the diagnosis.

question_text:
A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of a nonproductive cough and fatigue. During this period, she also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Three months ago, she was in India for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Her current medications include enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 90 mg/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L, and serum protein of 6.3 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion. Thoracentesis shows 250 mL of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows:

Erythrocyte count
0,000001 million/mm^3

Leukocyte count
4000/mm^3

Glucose
59 mg/dL

Lactate dehydrogenase
248 U/L

Protein
3.8 g/dL

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?
content_preview: A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of a nonproductive cough and fatigue. During this period, she also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Three months ago, she was in India for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Her current medications include enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 90 mg/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L, and serum protein of 6.3 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion. Thoracentesis shows 250 mL of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows: Erythrocyte count 0,000001 million/mm3 Leukocyte count 4000/mm3 Glucose 59 mg/dL Lactate dehydrogenase 248 U/L Protein 3.8 g/dL Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?
hint: This patient presents with chronic fatigue, nonproductive cough, weight loss, and nodular pleural lesions on x-ray, the combination of which raises concern for malignancy. Her work as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years is a risk factor for asbestos exposure. Based on Light's criteria (effusion protein: serum protein ratio > 0.5 and effusion LDH: serum LDH ratio > 0.6), this patient has an exudative pleural effusion.
learning_objective: Recognize mesothelioma as a cause of exudative pleural effusion.

answers.explanation_why: Bronchial adenocarcinoma could manifest with an exudative malignant pleural effusion, and smoking and asbestos exposure both increase the risk of lung cancer. However, the x-ray shows pleural lesions rather than a parenchymal lung lesion, making the diagnosis of lung cancer less likely.

images.title: Spiculated lung mass
images.description: X-ray chest (A: PA view) and CT chest (B: coronal plane; lung window) of a patient with pulmonary adenocarcinomaA spiculated nodule is seen in the upper lobe of the right lung (white arrows).RULB = Right upper lobe bronchus

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's x-ray findings (nodular pleural lesions) and history of asbestos exposure suggest mesothelioma, a neoplastic process of the mesothelium that can manifest with malignant pleural effusion. Malignant effusion is caused by cancer-related barrier dysfunction of the capillary walls, which leads to increased permeation of plasma protein, blood cells, and tumor cells. These effusions are usually exudative and cell-rich, with a cloudy or straw-like appearance, abnormal cytology, a glucose concentration < 60 mg/dL, pH < 7.2, and high concentrations of LDH (> 0.45 x normal serum LDH) and amylase (> 200 mg/dL).

In addition to addressing the underlying malignancy, symptomatic malignant pleural effusions can be treated with therapeutic thoracocentesis and, if the effusion is expected to reaccumulate rapidly or frequently, an indwelling pleural catheter or chemical pleurodesis.

images.title: Diffuse nodular pleural thickening
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with malignant mesotheliomaNodular pleural thickening (hatched green overlay) encases the left lung and the volume of the left hemithorax (red dashed line) is reduced compared to the right (green dashed line). Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are present (red overlay).The findings are compatible with malignant mesothelioma, although confluent pleural metastatic disease can have a similar appearance. Both primary and secondary pleural malignancies can cause pleural nodules, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural effusion.AO: aorta; LV: left ventricle; PA: pulmonary artery

answers.explanation_why: Nephrotic syndrome would result in a clear, transudative pleural effusion from decreased oncotic pressure, not a turbid, exudative pleural effusion. Furthermore, other findings commonly seen in nephrotic syndrome, such as edema, frothy urine, hypertension, or signs of hypocalcemia, are absent in this patient.

Cough, weight loss, travel to a country with high tuberculosis (TB) incidence, and exudative pleural effusion are consistent with TB. However, isolated, unilateral, nodular pleural lesions are not common x-ray findings in TB. Typical x-ray findings include consolidation, hilar lymphadenopathy, and, in reactivation TB, fibrocaseous cavitary lesions.

images.title: Cavitary lung lesion
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view; insert: axial CT, lung window) of a patient with postprimary tuberculosisA thick-walled irregularly shaped cavity (green overlay) in the left lung apex is surrounded by micronodular opacities (examples indicated by dotted lines), which are better seen on the CT image than on the chest radiograph.The differential diagnosis for a cavitary lung lesion includes both infectious (bacterial, fungal, and occasionally parasitic) and noninfectious (malignant, inflammatory, vascular, and traumatic) etiologies. In postprimary tuberculosis, the apicoposterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes are common sites of involvement. A thick-walled cavity accompanied by consolidation or nodular opacities can signify active disease.

answers.explanation_why: Although the patient has congestive heart failure (CHF), CHF would typically manifest with a clear, transudative effusion from increased hydrostatic pressure in pulmonary capillaries.

images.title: Hydrostatic pulmonary edema
images.description: X-ray chest (AP view)The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (hatched green overlay) and the perihilar air space opacities (green overlay) have a bat wing, or butterfly, configuration. Linear interstitial opacities representing Kerley A lines (orange dashed lines) radiate from the hila to the apices and Kerley B lines (white dashed lines) are seen in the lateral mid zones. The costophrenic angles are blunted (arrows) from bilateral pleural effusions.These features are characteristically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath for 1 month. Initially, he was able to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment, but he now needs several breaks to catch his breath. He has no chest pain. He has rheumatic heart disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He emigrated from India about 25 years ago. His current medications include carvedilol, torsemide, and insulin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows bilateral crackles at the lung bases. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Echocardiography shows no valvular calcifications, atrial clots, or atrioventricular regurgitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath for 1 month. Initially, he was able to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment, but he now needs several breaks to catch his breath. He has no chest pain. He has rheumatic heart disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He emigrated from India about 25 years ago. His current medications include carvedilol, torsemide, and insulin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows bilateral crackles at the lung bases. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Echocardiography shows no valvular calcifications, atrial clots, or atrioventricular regurgitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
hint: A low-pitched diastolic murmur with an opening snap in a patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease is characteristic of mitral valve stenosis. These findings in combination with exertional dyspnea and bibasilar crackles without chest pain indicate cardiogenic pulmonary edema and heart failure due to valvular disease.
learning_objective: Recognize mitral valve stenosis, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Aortic valve repair is indicated for symptomatic or severe aortic valve disease. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease. Both aortic regurgitation (AR) and aortic stenosis (AS) can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, unlike this patient's murmur, AR causes a blowing early diastolic murmur heard best at the left midsternal border and AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space.

images.title: Cardiomegaly and prominent thoracic aorta in aortic regurgitation
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of aortic regurgitationThe cardiac silhouette is enlarged. The left ventricle, ascending aorta, and aortic arch are prominent as a result of dilatation.

answers.explanation_why: Mitral valve replacement is indicated for patients with mitral valve stenosis who are not candidates for the first-line treatment. Although mitral replacement is a potential treatment for this patient's mitral valve stenosis, replacement would require open surgery that is associated with considerable morbidity and mortality. Other less invasive treatment options would be preferred, as they offer similar symptomatic improvement with lower risk.

Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC) is the treatment of choice for many cases of symptomatic mitral stenosis because it improves valve function and symptoms, is less invasive, and the morbidity and mortality rates are lower than with other surgical treatment options. This patient has a favorable valve morphology (no calcifications) and no evidence of a left atrial thrombus or mitral regurgitation, which makes him a good candidate for PMBC. If the patient's echocardiography were less benign, open valvular replacement would be indicated.

images.title: Heart murmur in mitral stenosis
images.description: Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

answers.explanation_why: Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) is the treatment of choice for most cases of symptomatic or severe aortic stenosis (AS) in patients who are not suited to surgery. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease, with AS being less common than aortic regurgitation. AS can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

images.title: Heart murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis
images.description: A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

answers.explanation_why: Warfarin therapy would be indicated if this patient had evidence of atrial fibrillation (e.g., irregular heart rhythm), evidence of left atrial thrombus (e.g., echocardiographic finding or embolic stroke), or a mechanical heart valve. Although this patient is at risk for all of these conditions given his mitral valve stenosis and may require warfarin in the future, there is no clear indication for warfarin at this time.

ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) are indicated for patients with heart failure because they have been shown to reduce mortality (likely via aldosterone reduction, which decreases myocardial remodeling, among other mechanisms). Although this patient has symptoms of heart failure, ACE inhibitors (and other afterload reduction agents) are contraindicated in mitral valve stenosis, which decreases the preload available for the left ventricle to pump into the systemic circulation, meaning that the ability to maintain perfusion of vital organs is already compromised. If the ability of peripheral arteries to constrict is downregulated (e.g., by an ACE inhibitor), then perfusion may be insufficient and end-organ damage may occur.

question_text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. On questioning by the paramedics, he reported severe chest pain and mild dyspnea. On arrival, he is confused and unable to provide a history. His pulse is 93/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 91/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. He is able to move his extremities in response to commands. He opens his eyes spontaneously. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises over the trunk and extremities. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) wound at the left fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. There is jugular venous distention. Decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion are noted on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. On questioning by the paramedics, he reported severe chest pain and mild dyspnea. On arrival, he is confused and unable to provide a history. His pulse is 93/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 91/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. He is able to move his extremities in response to commands. He opens his eyes spontaneously. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises over the trunk and extremities. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) wound at the left fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. There is jugular venous distention. Decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion are noted on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has unilaterally decreased breath sounds, chest pain, and dyspnea after a high-speed injury involving the thorax. He now presents with tachypnea and impending hemodynamic instability (low blood pressure and elevated heart rate). This, along with jugular venous distention, which is a sign of impaired blood flow to the heart, indicates tension pneumothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize tension pneumothorax, and choose the most appropriate initial intervention.

answers.explanation_why: CT scan of the chest is an important imaging modality for assessing intrathoracic injuries in trauma patients and can be used to diagnose simple pneumothorax, hemothorax, and tension pneumothorax, all of which may occur after high-energy chest trauma. However, this patient is at high risk of hemodynamic compromise (blood pressure of 91/65 mm Hg, heart rate of 93/min) and presents with jugular venous distention and decreased breath sounds. Delaying intervention to conduct imaging might result in his death.

Bronchoscopy is useful in the management of respiratory distress secondary to high-energy chest trauma (e.g., motor vehicle collision), which may involve airway lacerations or blood aspiration. This patient is in respiratory distress; however, there is no evidence of hemoptysis, which would be suggested in the case of airway laceration. The patient's low blood pressure (91/65 mm Hg) and jugular venous distention call for immediate life-saving intervention, but bronchoscopy does not enable decompression and would thus not help to restore hemodynamic stability.

Emergency thoracotomy may be considered in patients with severe blunt or penetrating chest trauma, who display worsening hypotension despite volume resuscitation or loss of vital signs in the emergency department. This intervention may be indicated when exsanguinating hemorrhage, cardiac tamponade, or air emboli are suspected causes and all other measures have failed. Although this patient shows signs of impending hemodynamic compromise (blood pressure of 91/65 mm Hg, heart rate of 93/min) and requires urgent intervention, thoracotomy is not an appropriate treatment for tension pneumothorax.

Pericardiocentesis would be indicated for the management of a pericardial effusion causing cardiac tamponade. While cardiac tamponade may also be a result of trauma and manifests with hypotension, tachycardia, and jugular venous distention due to impaired blood flow into the right ventricle, this condition would also cause muffled heart sounds and retrosternal chest pain. In addition, cardiac tamponade would not explain this patient's decreased breath sounds over the left hemithorax. This patient has suffered a tension pneumothorax that warrants urgent decompression.

Immediate needle thoracostomy is indicated in this patient who has developed a tension pneumothorax. Progressive accumulation of air in the pleural cavity leads to compression of the contralateral lung, heart, and vena cava, thereby reducing venous return to the heart, cardiac output, and blood oxygenation and eventually resulting in cardiopulmonary arrest. Successful placement of a needle thoracostomy allows the air to leave the thoracic cavity and results in immediate decompression of thoracic organs and resolution of hemodynamic compromise.

Needle thoracostomy is a temporizing measure and should always be followed by chest tube insertion in order to resolve the simple pneumothorax that results from needle insertion. In a hospital setting, chest tube placement may be preferable to needle decompression, if immediately available.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: A tension pneumothorax develops secondary to one-way valve mechanism, which is caused by an injury to the lung parenchyma or chest wall and allows air to enter the pleural space during inspiration (valve open) but not escape during expiration (valve closed). Progressive accumulation of air within the pleural space causes an ipsilateral increase in intrapleural pressure, leading to ipsilateral lung collapse and mediastinal shift to the contralateral side. The mediastinal shift compresses the vena cavae, trachea, and the contralateral lung, leading to hemodynamic instability and hypoxia.

answers.explanation_why: Transthoracic echocardiography can be used to diagnose suspected cardiac tamponade. Although this patient shows signs of impending hemodynamic compromise (blood pressure of 91/65 mm Hg, heart rate of 93/min) and presents with jugular venous distention, which may suggest cardiac tamponade, muffled heart sounds, retrosternal chest pain, and symptoms of heart failure would also be expected. Furthermore, the decreased breath sounds on the left hemithorax are not consistent with this diagnosis. The hypotension, elevated heart rate, and jugular venous distention indicate impending hemodynamic shock, which warrants urgent intervention.

Chest x-ray is indicated for the diagnosis of simple pneumothorax, hemothorax, and tension pneumothorax, all of which may occur after high-energy chest trauma. Tension pneumothorax would be seen on x-ray as a collapsed lung with absence of peripheral lung markings and shift of the mediastinum towards the unaffected side. However, this patient is at high risk of hemodynamic shock (blood pressure of 91/65 mm Hg, heart rate of 93/min), and delaying intervention to conduct imaging might lead to his death.
