question_text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) results are negative. An ECG shows absent P waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) results are negative. An ECG shows absent P waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
hint: While hypotension following acute trauma should raise concern for blood loss, this patient's negative FAST exam makes intraabdominal or intrathoracic bleeding less likely. Instead, his profound hypotension despite an apparently normal volume status, the bibasilar lung crackles, and elevated jugular venous pressure potentially indicate cardiogenic shock.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiac contusion.

answers.explanation_why: Tracheobronchial injuries can occur as a result of severe blunt chest trauma and also present with hypotension, dyspnea, or tachypnea. However, they are usually associated with bloody oral secretions, subcutaneous emphysema, and/or pneumothorax with a positive Hamman's sign.

In the context of a serious motor vehicle collision, this patient's hypotension and tachycardia refractive to fluid resuscitation, including vasopressors, combined with atrial fibrillation on ECG and a negative FAST, are highly suspicious for cardiac contusion. Cardiac contusions may manifest with clinical features ranging from asymptomatic arrhythmias to rapidly fatal cardiac rupture. Blunt chest trauma and/or sudden deceleration can lead to decreased contractility and arrhythmias due to injury to cardiac myocytes and pacemaker cells. Decreased contractility directly contributes to cardiogenic shock with decreased cardiac output and hypotension, as in this patient.

Splenic rupture most often occurs in the setting of blunt abdominal trauma and can result in hemodynamic instability secondary to massive intraabdominal blood loss. However, an intraabdominal hemorrhage large enough to lead to deterioration would be seen on the FAST exam.

A hemothorax might manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, diminished/absent breath sounds, decreased tactile fremitus, dullness on percussion, and flat neck veins. It may also be associated with a raised jugular venous pressure. In severe cases of hemothorax, blood loss into the thoracic cavity can lead to hemorrhagic shock, with subsequent tachycardia and hypotension. However, a hemothorax is distinctly identifiable on chest x-ray or on ultrasound as part of the FAST exam. No signs of internal bleeding are apparent on this patient's FAST exam and the physical exam findings (bibasilar crackles, soft abdomen) make a significant hemothorax even more unlikely.

An aortic dissection may occur as the result of rapid deceleration (e.g., in a motor vehicle accident) and typically manifests with severe tearing chest pain that may radiate to different parts of the body. Aortic dissection is associated with hypotension either if the dissection involves the ascending aorta resulting in cardiac tamponade and/or aortic regurgitation, or if it results in aortic rupture and hemorrhage into the mediastinum. On the FAST exam, however, aortic rupture would be apparent as free fluid above the diaphragm, with secondary cardiac tamponade as fluid accumulates in the pericardium. Moreover, secondary aortic regurgitation severe enough to affect the patient's vitals would be heard on auscultation.

Pulmonary contusions can occur in the setting of chest trauma and result in chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypoxia as “bruising” of the lung impairs gas exchange. Symptoms may then worsen following fluid administration as fluid accumulates in the damaged lung. While this patient does have chest pain and tachypnea and deteriorated after receiving fluids, pulmonary contusion would be less likely to cause the arrhythmia or fluid- and vasopressor-resistant hypotension that proved fatal in this patient.

Cardiac tamponade due to hemopericardium can occur after chest trauma due to cardiac wall rupture or aortic dissection of the ascending aorta, with accumulation of blood around the heart. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with rapidly developing hypotension and tachycardia following chest trauma, and show elevated jugular venous pressure (as part of Beck triad). However, patients with a cardiac tamponade will have a pulsus paradoxus, characteristically muffled heart sounds, and the FAST exam will show fluid around the heart.

question_text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of diffuse weakness for the past several months. A lateral x-ray of the chest that was recently obtained as part of a preemployment medical evaluation shows an anterior mediastinal mass. He has gastroesophageal reflux disease. His only medication is rabeprazole. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no splenomegaly. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of diffuse weakness for the past several months. A lateral x-ray of the chest that was recently obtained as part of a preemployment medical evaluation shows an anterior mediastinal mass. He has gastroesophageal reflux disease. His only medication is rabeprazole. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no splenomegaly. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Thymic lesions, including thymoma, are the most common cause of anterior mediastinal masses, accounting for approx. 50% of cases.
learning_objective: Recognize an anterior mediastinal mass associated with myasthenia gravis, and recall the diagnostic antibody.

answers.content: Fever, night sweats, and weight loss
answers.explanation_why: B symptoms are classically associated with malignancies such as lymphoma, which may manifest with an anterior mediastinal mass usually due to lymph node metastasis. However, the most common cause of an anterior mediastinal mass is thymoma. Furthermore, this patient's generalized muscle weakness suggests a condition that is often associated with thymomas.

Smoking is a significant risk factor for many types of bronchogenic carcinoma. Most mediastinal manifestations of bronchogenic carcinoma are due to lymph node metastases, which occur in the middle mediastinum, not the anterior mediastinum, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Alpha-fetoprotein is a tumor marker that can be elevated in some types of germ cell tumors – especially in nonseminomatous germ cell tumors. This malignant germ cell tumor typically occurs in younger men (age 20–30 years). Although a germ cell tumor can cause an anterior mediastinal mass, it is not the most likely cause.

Acetylcholine receptor antibodies are used to diagnose myasthenia gravis, a condition that is present in about 30% of patients with thymoma and manifests with fatigable weakness of skeletal muscles. Almost all patients with thymoma and myasthenia gravis are seropositive for these antibodies, which target postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors of normal muscle cells and inhibit signal transduction at the neuromuscular junction. Thymectomy can improve muscle weakness and even cure myasthenia gravis.

Patients with thymoma may be asymptomatic or present with thoracic symptoms (e.g., chest pain, cough, dyspnea, superior vena cava syndrome) or paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., myasthenia gravis).

images.title: Thymoma in myasthenia gravis
images.description: Chest CT (axial section; IV contrast)A large, hypointense anterior mediastinal mass (B; green overlay), which is likely a thymoma, is visible adjacent to the left pulmonary artery (C).A: ascending aorta; D: left main bronchus; E: descending aorta; F: superior vena cava (marked in overlay only)

answers.content: Elevated TSH and a nodular anterior cervical mass
answers.explanation_why: A nodular anterior cervical mass with associated elevated TSH is consistent with goiter. Chronic, untreated goiter can grow into the substernal space, causing an anterior mediastinal mass. However, substernal goiter typically manifests with compressive symptoms (i.e, dysphagia, exertional dyspnea). Another condition is more likely to cause an anterior mediastinal mass and generalized weakness.

Urinary catecholamines are elevated in some neural tumors such as neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma is rare in adults and would manifest with a posterior mediastinal mass rather than an anterior mediastinal mass.

question_text: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of epigastric pain and multiple episodes of vomiting for 4 hours. Initially, the vomit was yellowish in color, but after the first couple of episodes it was streaked with blood. He had 2 episodes of vomiting that contained streaks of frank blood on the way to the hospital. He has been hospitalized twice in the past year for acute pancreatitis. He drinks 2 pints of vodka daily but had over 4 pints during the past 12 hours. He takes naproxen for his “hangovers.” He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (99.1°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and a tremor of his hands. The abdomen is soft and shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; there is no organomegaly. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Rectal examination is unremarkable. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.3 g/dL and hematocrit concentration is 40%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of epigastric pain and multiple episodes of vomiting for 4 hours. Initially, the vomit was yellowish in color, but after the first couple of episodes it was streaked with blood. He had 2 episodes of vomiting that contained streaks of frank blood on the way to the hospital. He has been hospitalized twice in the past year for acute pancreatitis. He drinks 2 pints of vodka daily but had over 4 pints during the past 12 hours. He takes naproxen for his “hangovers.” He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (99.1°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and a tremor of his hands. The abdomen is soft and shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; there is no organomegaly. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Rectal examination is unremarkable. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.3 g/dL and hematocrit concentration is 40%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
hint: In an individual with a significant history of heavy alcohol use, the combination of acute epigastric pain and hematemesis following multiple episodes of vomiting raises concern for Mallory-Weiss syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Mallory-Weiss syndrome.

answers.content: Superficial ectatic artery in the gastric cardia
answers.explanation_why: A Dieulafoy lesion manifests with signs of upper GI bleeding, including hematemesis and epigastric pain. This rare condition is typically not preceded by multiple episodes of vomiting, and the hemorrhage would likely be more severe, making the diagnosis unlikely.

answers.content: Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus
answers.explanation_why: Esophageal varices are the most common cause of esophageal bleeding. Heavy drinking increases the risk of alcohol-associated liver disease and cirrhosis, which may eventually lead to the formation of esophageal varices and subsequent variceal bleeding. Variceal bleeding usually manifests with sudden onset of hematemesis. However, this patient had multiple episodes of nonbloody vomiting before the bleeding started and has only been vomiting a small amount of blood, whereas variceal bleeding would typically manifest with severe hemorrhage. Because his physical examination did not show any signs of liver disease or portal hypertension, a different diagnosis is more likely.

answers.content: Transmural tear of the lower esophagus
answers.explanation_why: The patient's history of epigastric pain following multiple episodes of vomiting due to heavy alcohol use may raise concern for a transmural tear of the lower esophagus, as seen in Boerhaave syndrome. However, hematemesis is not characteristic of this condition. In addition, patients with Boerhaave syndrome typically present with excruciating retrosternal chest pain rather than epigastric pain and can develop dyspnea, crepitus on palpation of the chest wall (due to mediastinal emphysema), and signs of mediastinitis.

A pseudoaneurysm of the gastroduodenal artery is a possible complication of recurrent pancreatitis, which is most commonly seen in men with a history of heavy alcohol use. In rare cases, a pseudoaneurysm can manifest with upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to drainage into the pancreatic duct. However, most patients with pseudoaneurysm of the gastroduodenal artery are asymptomatic and have a history of pancreatic pseudocysts, making it an unlikely diagnosis here

answers.content: Ulcerative damage to the posterior wall of the duodenum
answers.explanation_why: Although patients with bleeding from a duodenal ulcer may present with epigastric pain and hematemesis, the bleeding usually occurs spontaneously and is not preceded by multiple episodes of nonbloody vomiting. While this patient has multiple risk factors for peptic ulcer disease (e.g., heavy alcohol use, prolonged use of NSAIDs), it is not the most likely cause of his symptoms.

Severe esophagitis is a rare cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Bleeding from esophagitis usually occurs in patients with prolonged and severe reflux episodes, particularly older and bedridden patients with gastric motility disorders, making this diagnosis unlikely.

answers.content: Mucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction
answers.explanation_why: In Mallory-Weiss syndrome, a sudden and severe rise in the esophageal intraluminal pressure, e.g., due to repeated forceful vomiting, leads to longitudinal lacerations of the mucous membrane as well as the submucosal vessels at the gastroesophageal junction. Esophageal injury may result in epigastric pain and hematemesis, both of which this patient is experiencing. Heavy alcohol use is the most important predisposing condition for Mallory-Weiss syndrome.

answers.content: Abnormal connection between gastric arteries and veins
answers.explanation_why: Bleeding from arteriovenous malformations of the upper GI tract (e.g., of the stomach) is a rare cause of hematemesis that mainly affects older individuals, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this 38-year-old patient.

answers.content: Neoplastic growth at the gastroesophageal junction
answers.explanation_why: Hematemesis and abdominal pain in a patient with a history of heavy alcohol use could be explained by bleeding of a gastric tumor. Gastric cancer often progresses slowly and is associated with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss) and symptoms of upper gastrointestinal malignancy (e.g., prolonged course of abdominal pain, early satiety). Although a neoplastic growth at the gastroesophageal junction cannot be fully excluded, a different diagnosis is more likely.

question_text: A 22-year-old man who is on active duty in the US Army sustains a stab wound to his chest during a military attack. He is brought to the combat medic by his unit for a primary survey. The soldier reports shortness of breath. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His pulse is 99/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound at the left fourth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Bubbling of blood is seen with each respiration at the wound site. There is no jugular venous distention. There is hyperresonance to percussion and decreased breath sounds on the left side. The trachea is at the midline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man who is on active duty in the US Army sustains a stab wound to his chest during a military attack. He is brought to the combat medic by his unit for a primary survey. The soldier reports shortness of breath. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His pulse is 99/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound at the left fourth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Bubbling of blood is seen with each respiration at the wound site. There is no jugular venous distention. There is hyperresonance to percussion and decreased breath sounds on the left side. The trachea is at the midline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The presence of dyspnea and tachypnea with decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion after a penetrating chest wound with bubbling of blood indicates an open pneumothorax. The absence of hemodynamic instability, tracheal deviation, and jugular venous distention make a tension pneumothorax unlikely.
learning_objective: Recognize an open pneumothorax, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Emergency thoracotomy is indicated for patients with penetrating chest injury who are hemodynamically unstable and unresponsive to fluid resuscitation, or who have been pulseless and receiving CPR for < 15 minutes. Because this patient is hemodynamically stable, thoracotomy is not indicated.

A partially occlusive dressing (such as clear plastic film taped at 3 out of 4 sides of the lesion) is a temporary treatment for open pneumothorax, used to prevent further expansion of the pneumothorax until the diagnosis has been confirmed and definitive treatment is available. This dressing creates a flutter valve effect (i.e., air is free to escape from the gap in the dressing during exhalation while the dressing occludes the wound during inhalation), preventing the entry of further air via the wound into the thoracic cavity. Once the patient has been fully stabilized, a chest tube would be placed for definitive treatment of his pneumothorax. The tube should be placed through intact skin in one of the recommended anatomical locations, not through the preexisting injury.

Chest tubes alone are sufficient treatment for pneumothorax in ∼ 85% of cases; surgery is required for the remainder.

images.title: Open and closed pneumothorax
images.description:
Open pneumothorax: The entry of air into the pleural cavity through an unsealed defect in the thoracic wall (e.g., following penetrating trauma).
Closed pneumothorax: The entry of air into the pleural cavity through a breach in the visceral pleura (e.g., ruptured pulmonary bulla).

answers.explanation_why: Emergency pericardiocentesis is indicated for pericardial effusions causing hemodynamic instability (i.e., cardiac tamponade.) Although this patient is at risk for cardiac tamponade because of his penetrating thoracic trauma, he is hemodynamically stable and he has no evidence of tamponade (Beck triad: hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck veins). Therefore, emergency pericardiocentesis is not indicated at this time.

images.title: Pericardial effusion with water bottle configuration
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lupus pericarditisThe cardiac silhouette is enlarged and demonstrates a globular, or water bottle, configuration due to pericardial effusion (green hatched overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Echocardiography is part of the FAST exam, which is used in the penetrating trauma primary examination. The ATLS-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation follows the ABCDE algorithm; Airway → Breathing → Circulation → Disability → Exposure → adjunctive tests (e.g., FAST exam). This patient has airway/breathing injuries that require treatment before resuscitation can continue to the adjunctive treatments. Although echocardiography would likely be performed on this patient at a later point, this test is not readily available in a combat field and this patient has another injury that takes precedence in trauma resuscitation.

Needle thoracostomy is a temporary, stabilizing treatment for tension pneumothorax, as it causes hemodynamic instability. Although this patient is at risk for tension pneumothorax given his penetrating chest wound, he is currently hemodynamically stable. Additionally, tension pneumothorax is caused by a chest wound acting as a one-way valve, allowing air into the pleural space but not allowing it to escape, which builds up pressure. Blood is seen bubbling from this patient's wound, which means that air is escaping from the wound.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Much of the left hemithorax is hyperlucent, with a lack of vascular markings when compared to the right hemithorax. Lobulated opacities that project through the cardiac silhouette and along the left heart border represent collapsed lobes of the left lung (green overlay).Accompanying depression of the left hemidiaphragm (arrowheads), mass effect on the mediastinum, and widening of some intercostal spaces (double-headed arrows) are signs of tension pneumothorax, which requires immediate intervention.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, she is unconscious. Her pulse is 140/min, respirations are 12/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 76/55 mm Hg. 0.9% saline infusion is begun. A focused assessment with sonography shows blood in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.6 g/dL and hematocrit is 22%. The surgeon decides to move the patient to the operating room for an emergency explorative laparotomy. Packed red blood cell transfusion is ordered prior to surgery. A friend of the patient asks for the transfusion to be held as the patient is a Jehovah's Witness. The patient has no advance directive and there is no documentation showing her refusal of blood transfusions. The patient's husband and children cannot be contacted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, she is unconscious. Her pulse is 140/min, respirations are 12/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 76/55 mm Hg. 0.9% saline infusion is begun. A focused assessment with sonography shows blood in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.6 g/dL and hematocrit is 22%. The surgeon decides to move the patient to the operating room for an emergency explorative laparotomy. Packed red blood cell transfusion is ordered prior to surgery. A friend of the patient asks for the transfusion to be held as the patient is a Jehovah's Witness. The patient has no advance directive and there is no documentation showing her refusal of blood transfusions. The patient's husband and children cannot be contacted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Even though this patient's friend claims the patient is a Jehovah's Witness, there is no documentation to verify this claim nor the patient's wishes under these circumstances. In such emergency situations without a suitable surrogate decision-maker, the physician can make a decision based solely on the patient's safety and well-being.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management in the absence of an advance directive or appropriate surrogate decision-maker.

answers.explanation_why: Hydroxyethyl starch is a volume expander formerly used in patients requiring volume resuscitation. Most regulatory bodies worldwide have moved towards suspending the use of hydroxyethyl starch since multiple studies have shown increased risks of death because of coagulopathy and acute kidney injury. For this patient in need of emergency medical intervention, other therapeutic options are safer, cheaper, and more likely to increase chances of survival.

answers.content: Transfusion of packed red blood cells
answers.explanation_why: While a surrogate decision-maker, such as a family member, can make treatment decisions on the patient's behalf if no advance directive exists, a friend is usually not an appropriate surrogate. In some states, a “close friend” may be considered as a surrogate. Physicians must make their decisions with consideration for the patient's preferences. However, as this patient's preferences are not clearly documented, it would be inappropriate to withhold lifesaving treatment based on the unverifiable claims of a friend. This patient is in shock from internal bleeding and transfusion with packed red blood cells is the best means of restoring volume and stabilizing the patient.

Consulting the hospital ethics committee can be useful in navigating ethical conflicts between providers, patients, families, and the law. However, this patient is in critical condition and delaying emergent treatment for a consult could endanger the patient further.

Iron therapy in patients with chronic anemia can help promote erythrogenesis. Iron would not provide any benefit to this critically ill patient who requires immediate repletion of intravascular volume and blood.

A blood transfusion would maximize this trauma patient's chances of survival. While a surrogate decision maker can make treatment decisions on the patient's behalf, decisions should still be made with consideration to the patient's preferences and the best interests of this patient. As this patient's preferences are not clearly documented, it would be inappropriate to withhold life-saving treatment based on the claims of a surrogate that cannot be verified and may result in the patient's death.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician with a 12-year history of recurrent heartburn. He has also had a cough, which is worse at night, for the past year. He has not seen a physician for 8 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His only medication is an over-the-counter antacid. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (209 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. An upper endoscopy shows dark pink mucosa up to 2 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy samples of the mucosa show columnar epithelium with goblet cells and low-grade dysplasia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician with a 12-year history of recurrent heartburn. He has also had a cough, which is worse at night, for the past year. He has not seen a physician for 8 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His only medication is an over-the-counter antacid. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (209 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. An upper endoscopy shows dark pink mucosa up to 2 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy samples of the mucosa show columnar epithelium with goblet cells and low-grade dysplasia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient with obesity and a long-standing history of smoking and heartburn underwent upper endoscopy to screen for complications of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The finding of columnar epithelium with goblet cells proximal to the gastroesophageal junction (intestinal metaplasia) indicates Barrett esophagus (BE).
learning_objective: Recognize Barrett esophagus with low-grade dysplasia, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why:
Endoscopic surveillance is an acceptable alternative to more invasive treatment options for patients with BE and confirmed low-grade dysplasia but it should be performed sooner in 6 months and yearly thereafter.

For patients who have macroscopic findings consistent with BE on endoscopy but no evidence of intestinal metaplasia on biopsy, repeat endoscopic surveillance with biopsy should be performed at 1–2 years because a third of these patients will subsequently develop intestinal metaplasia. Repeat endoscopic surveillance after a longer interval of 3–5 years is recommended for patients with BE and intestinal metaplasia but no dysplasia.

Endoscopic eradication of dysplasia via mucosal resection and concurrent eradication of intestinal metaplasia is the treatment of choice for BE because of the risk of malignant transformation to esophageal adenocarcinoma. BE with low-grade dysplasia may be managed with surveillance endoscopy after 6 months and yearly therafter, because the risk of transformation is lower in this patient group compared to patients with BE with high-grade dysplasia (approx. 0.7% per year vs. approx. 7% per year).

Endoscopic eradication therapy is also indicated in the management of certain patients with stage T1a esophageal adenocarcinoma (i.e., with intact muscularis propria).

Esophagectomy is indicated in the treatment of esophageal adenocarcinomas in suitable surgical candidates and may be combined with neoadjuvant chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy in patients with submucosal invasion. However, it is a complex surgical procedure with considerable morbidity and mortality and should thus only be performed if there is no alternative therapeutic option. Since this patient's biopsy results show low-grade dysplasia of the esophageal mucosa rather than adenocarcinoma, a less invasive treatment is indicated.

Helicobacter pylori eradication therapy (e.g., with optimized bismuth quadruple therapy) is indicated in all patients who test positive for H. pylori infection. Although H. pylori infection cannot be definitively excluded without testing, it is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's BE. Therefore, H. pylori eradication therapy is not the most appropriate next step in management at this point.

Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) such as omeprazole prevent the expansion of intestinal metaplasia and reduce the risk of malignant transformation to invasive carcinoma. Therefore, monotherapy with PPIs plays an important role in maintenance therapy for complications of GERD such as BE.

External beam radiation therapy (EBRT) in combination with chemotherapy can be considered in the treatment of esophageal cancer. This approach can either be used in a neoadjuvant setting, prior to esophagectomy, or in a palliative setting in patients with metastatic esophageal cancer. EBRT plays no role in the management of patients with BE.

Antireflux surgery, such as Nissen fundoplication, is used for the long-term management of certain patients with chronic GERD (e.g., those with persistent symptoms despite appropriate medical treatment). However, it cannot prevent malignant transformation in patients who already have BE with dysplastic changes.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for the evaluation of mild retrosternal pain for the last 7 hours after several episodes of self-induced vomiting. The patient was diagnosed with bulimia nervosa 9 months ago. Her only medication is citalopram. She appears pale. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (136.6 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly. The remainder of the physical examination shows swelling of the salivary glands, dry skin, and brittle nails. An ECG and an x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities. Contrast esophagram with gastrografin shows mild leakage of contrast from the lower esophagus into the mediastinum without contrast extravasation into the pleural and peritoneal cavities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for the evaluation of mild retrosternal pain for the last 7 hours after several episodes of self-induced vomiting. The patient was diagnosed with bulimia nervosa 9 months ago. Her only medication is citalopram. She appears pale. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (136.6 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly. The remainder of the physical examination shows swelling of the salivary glands, dry skin, and brittle nails. An ECG and an x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities. Contrast esophagram with gastrografin shows mild leakage of contrast from the lower esophagus into the mediastinum without contrast extravasation into the pleural and peritoneal cavities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient with bulimia presents with retrosternal pain and leakage of contrast from the lower esophagus after several episodes of vomiting, which suggest transmural esophageal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome). The patient does not have signs of sepsis, pneumothorax, pleural effusion, or mediastinal emphysema, and the leak appears to be contained to the mediastinum.
learning_objective: Recognize contained transmural esophageal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome), and choose the most appropriate management for a stable patient.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous octreotide is a component of therapy for the treatment of esophageal variceal hemorrhage. Variceal hemorrhage presents with hematemesis, which is not seen here. Moreover, this patient has no other signs of portal hypertension, which is the typical predisposing condition for variceal bleeds.

Surgical repair of a ruptured esophagus is indicated for Boerhaave syndrome patients who either fail conservative treatment or do not satisfy the criteria for it. This patient has a small perforation contained to the mediastinum, no major comorbidities, and no signs of sepsis. Therefore, she is eligible for a trial of conservative therapy prior to more invasive measures.

Intravenous labetalol can be used for the medical management of an aortic dissection because it decreases blood pressure by lowering systemic vascular resistance. While aortic dissection typically manifests with retrosternal pain, it more commonly occurs in older patients with hypertension, in patients with connective tissue disorders, or after blunt chest trauma. Aortic dissection would not explain contrast extravasation from the lower esophagus.

Diagnostic endoscopy is not typically indicated for patients with Boerhaave syndrome, as the procedure may worsen the tear. Endoscopy may be performed if a therapeutic intervention such as stent placement, injection of a fibrin sealant, or endoscopic clipping is being considered.

Conservative therapy is indicated for generally healthy patients in a stable medical condition with a small, contained perforation and no signs of sepsis. Components of conservative therapy for Boerhaave syndrome include nothing by mouth with parenteral nutrition if required, IV proton pump inhibitors, analgesia, broad-spectrum antibiotic prophylaxis (e.g., ampicillin/sulbactam), percutaneous drainage of any fluid collections, and cardiopulmonary monitoring. Prior to restarting oral intake, a contrast esophagogram with gastrografin is indicated to confirm healing of the perforation.

images.title: Esophageal perforation
images.description: Fluoroscopy (Gastrografin swallow; frontal view) of patient after transesophageal echocardiographyExtravasated oral contrast (green overlay) through a perforation (red overlay) of the mid-esophagus parallels the distal esophagus in the mediastinum.E: esophagus

answers.explanation_why: A contrast-enhanced CT scan is indicated in patients with suspected Boerhaave syndrome whose x-rays and/or contrast esophagram are inconclusive, those who are unstable, and in patients who are otherwise unable to cooperate with a gastrografin swallow study. Because this patient is clinically stable and recent imaging clearly visualized the lesion, she should not be exposed to CT contrast and radiation without a clear diagnostic motive.

images.title: Esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome)
images.description: CT thorax (IV contrast; axial section at the height of aortic arch)Mediastinal air (pneumomediastinum) is visible as radiolucent shadows (green overlay) surrounding the aortic arch (1) and in the left tracheoesophageal groove, between the trachea (2) and the esophagus (3).Pneumomediastinum is a characteristic feature of esophageal perforation. In a patient with a preceding history of recurrent forceful vomiting, it is diagnostic of Boerhaave syndrome.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a right breast mass that she noticed 3 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. She does not have pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 5-cm, nontender, multinodular mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth polylobulated mass. Biopsy of the mass shows papillary projections of epithelial-lined stroma with hyperplasia and atypia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a right breast mass that she noticed 3 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. She does not have pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 5-cm, nontender, multinodular mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth polylobulated mass. Biopsy of the mass shows papillary projections of epithelial-lined stroma with hyperplasia and atypia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A leaf-like architecture of papillary projections of epithelium-lined stroma is characteristic of this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize a phyllodes tumor.

answers.explanation_why: Intraductal papilloma causes single or multiple, sometimes palpable breast lesions that are associated with serous or bloody nipple discharge in 60–80% of cases. This patient's lack of discharge makes the diagnosis less likely. In addition, the biopsy findings rule out intraductal papilloma, which would show a central, branching, fibrovascular core with surrounding myoepithelial and epithelial cells.

A large (> 3 cm), rapidly growing breast mass with no associated axillary lymphadenopathy in combination with a lobular appearance on mammography raises suspicion for a phyllodes tumor. Phyllodes tumors are rare (< 1% of all breast tumors) and typically manifest with a painless breast lump, which can make it difficult to differentiate this tumor from more common benign breast tumors (e.g., fibroadenoma). Phyllodes tumors may even appear similar to fibroadenoma on imaging. A core needle biopsy is required to definitively diagnose phyllodes tumor and to rule out malignancy. (See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.)

Although most phyllodes tumors are benign, ∼ 25% of cases are malignant. Surgical excision with wide margins is required. Surgery for patients with benign phyllodes tumors is usually curative, although local recurrence can occur, which often warrants total mastectomy.

images.title: Phyllodes tumor
images.description: Photomicrograph of a breast tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)A hypercellular stroma (example indicated by blue overlay) is visible in the right half of the image. Several clefts or slit-like spaces (examples indicated by black dashed line) lined by darker stained epithelial cells are visible within the stroma, giving it a leaf-like appearance. These are characteristic features of a phyllodes tumor.Normal breast tissue is visible in the left half of the image.

answers.explanation_why: Paget disease of the breast presents with an erythematous and scaly rash affecting the nipple and areola, accompanied by pruritus, burning, nipple retraction, and possibly, blood-tinged nipple discharge. Although the underlying etiology of Paget disease of the breast (ductal carcinoma) may cause a palpable breast mass, this patient's breast exam has no evidence of Paget disease, given the absence of skin or nipple changes.

images.title: Paget disease of the breast
images.description: An erythematous, scaling rash with irregular borders and erosion of the nipple is visible on the left breast of a female patient. The pathology extends beyond the areola region.These findings are typical of Paget's disease of the breast, a rare type of ductal carcinoma that is often accompanied by nipple discharge. Age-appropriate imaging and biopsy are required for diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Fibroadenomas are the most common breast tumors in women < 35 years old, and usually manifest as a solitary, nontender, mobile mass, very similar to this patient's lesion. However, fibroadenomas are less common in women > 35 years and typically have “popcorn” calcifications on mammography. Biopsy of fibroadenoma would show benign hyperplastic stroma encapsulating ductal tissue. Additionally, the rapid growth and size of this patient's tumor are not common features of fibroadenoma.

images.title: Fibroadenoma of the breast
images.description: Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: Fibrocystic breast disease is the most common benign condition of the breast and commonly causes a palpable breast mass. However, fibrocystic breast lesions are typically associated with mastalgia, cyclic pain with menses, and clear/white nipple discharge, none of which are present in this case. On mammogram, fibrocystic disease would typically show focal regions of thick parenchyma and/or cysts. Additionally, fibrocystic disease is not associated with papillary projections on biopsy.

images.title: Fibrocystic disease of the breast
images.description: Photomicrograph of breast tissue affected by fibrocystic diseaseCystic ducts (black dashed lines) and fibrosis of mammary tissue, i.e., increased collagen fibers in the stroma (green overlay), are visible. Apocrine metaplasia can also be seen in association with the fibrocystic changes (white overlay). For comparison, the regular terminal duct lobular unit of the breast is visible on the right (white dashed lines).Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common form of breast cancer and can manifest as a painless breast mass. Although malignancy should always be considered in patients with breast masses, especially in middle-aged women, invasive ductal carcinoma is more likely to manifest with skin changes (retraction, dimpling, edema), nipple retraction, bloody nipple discharge, and/or lymphadenopathy. Moreover, mammogram typically shows microcalcifications and spiculations while biopsy shows malignant cells in the ducts with microcalcifications and stromal invasion.

images.title: Invasive breast carcinoma of no special type (invasive ductal carcinoma) 1/3
images.description: Photomicrograph of biopsy specimen (H&E stain; low magnification) from a mobile breast lump in 64-year-old female patientMain image: At low magnification, a dense irregular mass (purple/pink) with poorly circumscribed borders can be seen infiltrating the mature adipose tissue of the breast (white). The mass is composed of disorganized tubular formations of the carcinoma (dark blue/basophilic staining) and surrounding collagenous connective tissue (pink/eosinophilic staining; also known as “desmoplastic stroma”).Top right inset: very low magnification overview indicating the location of the main image on the specimen

answers.explanation_why: Invasive lobular carcinoma accounts for 10–15% of breast cancers and may manifest as a painless breast nodule. Although malignancy should always be considered in breast masses, especially in middle-aged women, invasive lobular carcinoma is associated with skin changes (retraction, dimpling, edema), nipple retraction, bloody nipple discharge, and/or lymphadenopathy. Moreover, mammogram typically shows microcalcifications and spicules, and biopsy shows malignant cells in lobules and monomorphic cells in single rows.

images.title: Invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast
images.description: Photomicrograph of a breast tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; 40x magnification)Infiltrating malignant cells can be seen as single cells, narrow chords (examples indicated by green overlay), and characteristic single-file formations (examples indicated by blue overlay). The tumor cells are seen growing between distorted ductuli (D) and lobuli (L), surrounded by conspicuously pale connective tissue. There is no tubule formation of the tumor (as is commonly seen in other types of adenocarcinomas of the breast).This is the typical appearance of invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast.Click on the microscope icon (at the top) to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

question_text:
Two days after undergoing a left total hip replacement, a 68-year-old man has sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and bilateral osteoarthritis of the hips. Prior to admission to the hospital, his medications were metformin and naproxen. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The right lower extremity is swollen. Right foot flexion in an upward direction causes pain in the right calf. Pedal pulses are palpable. Supplemental oxygen therapy and intravenous fluid resuscitation are begun. His hematocrit is 30% and serum creatinine concentration is 1.2 mg/dL. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.48

pCO_2

27 mm Hg

pO_2

68 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

23 mEq/L

An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and right axis deviation. In addition to intravenous anticoagulation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Two days after undergoing a left total hip replacement, a 68-year-old man has sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and bilateral osteoarthritis of the hips. Prior to admission to the hospital, his medications were metformin and naproxen. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The right lower extremity is swollen. Right foot flexion in an upward direction causes pain in the right calf. Pedal pulses are palpable. Supplemental oxygen therapy and intravenous fluid resuscitation are begun. His hematocrit is 30% and serum creatinine concentration is 1.2 mg/dL. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.48 pCO2 27 mm Hg pO2 68 mm Hg HCO3- 23 mEq/L An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and right axis deviation. In addition to intravenous anticoagulation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This postoperative patient has sudden-onset shortness of breath, chest pain, tachycardia, hypoxia, and hypocapnia, along with features of a lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (asymmetric leg swelling, positive Homan sign). He has a Wells score of 9 (1.5 for heart rate > 100/min, 1.5 for surgery in the last 4 weeks, 3 for clinical features of DVT, and 3 for PE being more likely than another diagnosis), which indicates a high pretest probability of pulmonary embolism (PE) (a modified Wells score of > 4 indicates that PE is likely; an original Wells score of > 6 indicates that there is a high probability of PE).
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical presentation of pulmonary embolism, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why:
Compression and color doppler ultrasonography is generally used for diagnosing underlying DVT. However, this patient is currently showing signs of PE, and given the potentially life-threatening nature of missed PEs, the next best step would be to confirm the diagnosis through another test. Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities should be considered to confirm the presence of a DVT after stabilization and treatment of this patient's PE.

Compression ultrasonography is generally not a recommended initial diagnostic test when evaluating patients with suspected PE. However, in select patients, especially those with features of DVT in which the diagnostic tests of choice are inconclusive or contraindicated, compression ultrasonography of the legs may be sufficient to diagnose PE. If compression ultrasonography confirms DVT, anticoagulation may be initiated without confirming PE.

images.title: POCUS protocol for detection of lower extremity DVT
images.description: Various POCUS (point of care ultrasound) protocols exist for the detection of lower extremity DVT (deep vein thrombosis). In contrast to the whole-leg scans performed by radiology departments, POCUS protocols typically use only 2 or 3 points of compression along the femoral and popliteal veins.– Preferred probe: linear– Patient positioning: supine; leg rotated laterally at the hip and knee bent ∼ 30º– Compression technique: Holding the probe perpendicular to the skin, apply enough downward pressure to slightly compress the pulsatile artery.– Interpretation: The pressure needed to slightly compress the artery should completely collapse a non-thrombosed vein. A non-collapsible vein is highly suggestive of a DVT. Direct visualization of an intraluminal hyperechoic mass (asterisk) confirms the diagnosis.Three-point protocol steps:1. Locate the CFV and CFA at the branch point of the GSV from the CFV. Compress.2. Move the transducer distally along the CFV, just past the branch point of the FV and DFV, where the FA is superficial to the FV. Compress.3. Reposition the probe behind the knee and locate the PV superficial to the PA. Compress.CFA: common femoral artery; CFV: common femoral vein; DFV: deep femoral vein; GSV: great saphenous vein; FA: femoral artery; FV: femoral vein; PA: popliteal artery; PV: popliteal vein

answers.explanation_why: Thrombolysis with alteplase or other recombinant tissue-type plasminogen activators (tPA) is considered in cases of massive PE that causes right heart failure or in hemodynamically unstable patients (systolic BP < 90 mm Hg) requiring resuscitation. Although this patient has a high probability of a PE and has signs of right heart strain on ECG, he is hemodynamically stable, and a confirmatory test should be performed prior to treatment. Given this patient's recent orthopedic surgery and the high risk of hemorrhage associated with it, thrombolysis would be contraindicated.

Patients with a high pretest probability of PE should receive immediate empiric anticoagulation (e.g., heparin) and a spiral CT angiography to confirm the diagnosis. CT angiography has both high sensitivity and specificity for PE and provides immediate evidence of pulmonary arterial obstruction in the form of a visible intraluminal filling defect of the pulmonary arteries. Additional findings on spiral CT may include a wedge-shaped infarction, which typically also indicates PE.

See “Wells criteria for pulmonary embolism” table.

images.title: Pulmonary embolism with infarction
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane; left: soft tissue window; right: lung window) of a patient with shortness of breathLarge filling defects consistent with pulmonary emboli (green overlay) are seen within central right and left pulmonary artery branches. A subpleural, wedge-shaped consolidative opacity (red overlay) with a central air lucency (blue overlay) and peripheral ground glass (yellow overlay) is present in the posterolateral basal right lower lobe.Pulmonary infarction typically appears as a wedge-shaped subpleural opacity. Less frequently, an infarct may be dome-shaped (Hampton hump). Lucencies seen within infarcts can represent areas of necrosis or residual viable lung tissue. Pulmonary infarction heals slowly over weeks to months, whereas pulmonary hemorrhage without infarction resolves quickly.

answers.explanation_why: D-dimer measurement is indicated to rule out venous thromboembolism in patients for whom the diagnosis is unlikely (modified Wells score ≤ 4). In patients with a low or intermediate probability of PE, normal D-dimer values rule out the diagnosis. This patient's Wells score of 9 indicates a high probability of PE, making another step more appropriate.

answers.content: Obtain an x-ray of the chest
answers.explanation_why: Although a chest x-ray is often ordered when a patient is admitted to the emergency department with symptoms of respiratory distress, this test is not sensitive or specific enough on its own to confirm a diagnosis of PE. Nonspecific findings on chest x-ray that suggest PE include atelectasis, pleural effusions, cardiomegaly, Hampton's hump, or Westermark sign. Chest x-ray is usually initially performed to rule out other causes of dyspnea, such as pneumonia, pneumothorax, pericarditis, or aortic dissection; it is never used as a confirmatory test for PE.

Echocardiography is useful in detecting abnormalities of the right heart that might arise from a PE (e.g., right ventricular dilation or hypokinesis, flattening or bowing of the intraventricular septum that reduces left ventricular preload). This test may also be useful in detecting proximal PEs. However, the main limitation of echocardiography is its poor sensitivity for detecting distal PEs. Therefore, in hemodynamically stable patients (systolic BP > 90 mm Hg) in which PE is strongly suspected, another confirmatory test is recommended. In this patient, echocardiography may be used in conjunction with this confirmatory test to examine right heart hemodynamics, especially given the abnormal right heart findings on ECG.

A ventilation-perfusion scan (V/Q scan) showing areas of normal ventilation mixed with perfusion failure suggests PE. Although V/Q scans may be used to diagnose PEs, another diagnostic test that is faster and more readily available has replaced it as the best definitive diagnostic test in most medical centers. V/Q scans take a long time to administer and require a nuclear medicine technician to perform the test. As a result, V/Q scans are reserved for patients with severe renal insufficiency who cannot tolerate IV contrast or patients with contrast allergy.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of increasing shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough. She has been unable to perform her daily activities. She has also had malaise and bilateral ankle pain during this period. She first noticed the symptoms after returning from a vacation to Arizona. She is a research assistant at the university's geology laboratory. She was born in Nigeria and visits her family there twice a year; her last trip was 3 months ago. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is no palpable cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Examination shows ciliary injection and photophobia of the left eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of increasing shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough. She has been unable to perform her daily activities. She has also had malaise and bilateral ankle pain during this period. She first noticed the symptoms after returning from a vacation to Arizona. She is a research assistant at the university's geology laboratory. She was born in Nigeria and visits her family there twice a year; her last trip was 3 months ago. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is no palpable cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Examination shows ciliary injection and photophobia of the left eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Reticular opacities and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy are visible on this patient's chest x-ray.
learning_objective: Recognize sarcoidosis.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's x-ray findings in conjunction with shortness of breath, dry cough, and constitutional symptoms (e.g., malaise) strongly suggest sarcoidosis. This condition most commonly affects the lungs; however, sarcoidosis is a multisystem disorder that can manifest in many other organs. Extrapulmonary manifestations include anterior uveitis (suggested by this patient's photophobia and ciliary injections), which occurs in approx. 25% of patients. The triad of symmetric arthritis (which is often migratory), erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is referred to as Lofgren syndrome, which is a form of acute sarcoidosis. Acute sarcoidosis is usually self-limited, resolving within approx. 2 years, and rarely progresses to chronic sarcoidosis.

Incidence is highest among women and Black individuals.

This patient comes from a geographic area where tuberculosis (TB) is endemic. Pulmonary TB also manifests with dyspnea, malaise, lymphadenopathy, and cough, but the cough would normally be productive in TB. Hilar lymphadenopathy is a common feature seen on x-ray in TB, but reticular opacities would not be expected. TB would rather cause a calcified granuloma (Ghon complex). Lastly, even though TB can affect the skeleton (primarily the spine), ankle arthralgia is extremely uncommon in TB.

images.title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
images.description:
Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis may manifest with worsening dyspnea, nonproductive cough, malaise, and reticular opacities on chest x-ray. However, arthralgia and hilar lymphadenopathy are typically not seen in hypersensitivity pneumonitis. The absence of a history of occupational and/or environmental exposure to certain allergens also makes a different diagnosis more likely.

images.title: Fibrotic hypersensitivity pneumonitis with mosaic attenuation
images.description: CT chest (inspiratory phase; axial plane; lung window) of a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP)An irregular reticular pattern of fibrosis predominates in the subpleural regions of the mid zones of the lungs. A small amount of honeycombing (example indicated by red overlay) is seen. There is a heterogeneous pattern of lung attenuation (mosaic attenuation), with areas of low attenuation (examples indicated by green overlays) in some regions with no fibrosis; expiratory phase imaging could help assess whether or not such areas represent air trapping.Fibrotic HP has a variable appearance on CT. A pattern typical of fibrotic HP shows a random axial distribution of coarse reticulation and small airway disease with minimal honeycombing and no zonal predominance. Subpleural fibrosis can be compatible with HP, as can upper zonal, lower zonal, or central predominant distributions.

answers.explanation_why: Hilar lymphadenopathy, nonproductive cough, dyspnea, and malaise may be initial signs of Hodgkin lymphoma. However, the absence of B symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, night sweats) and lymphadenopathy in other sites (e.g., axillary and cervical nodes), as well as the presence of a normal complete blood count and arthralgia (not typically associated with Hodgkin lymphoma) suggest a different diagnosis.

Histoplasmosis may manifest with dyspnea, nonproductive cough, malaise, and hilar lymphadenopathy. Arthralgia may also be present in about 5–10% of cases. However, this patient does not come from an endemic area (e.g., Ohio, Mississippi) and does not have a history of exposure to bats or birds (e.g., cave exploration). Additionally, anterior uveitis would not be expected. The history of travel to Africa might suggest a risk of African histoplasmosis caused by Histoplasma duboisii. However, African histoplasmosis typically manifests only as skin and bone disease without pulmonary involvement.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) may manifest with cough, dyspnea, malaise, and arthralgias. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and renal disease suggests a different diagnosis. Moreover, hilar lymphadenopathy is typically absent in patients with GPA.

images.title: Thoracic sarcoidosis
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view)The lungs have a pattern of innumerable small nodular opacities. The hila are enlarged and lobulated (red overlay) and the right paratracheal stripe is widened (green overlay).Bilateral hilar and right mediastinal adenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis and is referred to as the “Garland triad” or “1-2-3 sign.”

question_text: Two days after an uncomplicated laparoscopic abdominal hernia repair, a 46-year-old man is evaluated for palpitations. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a ventricular septal defect that closed spontaneously as a child. His father has coronary artery disease. Prior to admission, his only medications were hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. He currently also takes hydromorphone/acetaminophen for mild postoperative pain. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min and irregular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 139/85 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a normal S_1 and S_2 without murmurs and clear lung fields. The abdominal incisions are clean, dry, and intact. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the lower quadrants. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ECG findings?
content_preview: Two days after an uncomplicated laparoscopic abdominal hernia repair, a 46-year-old man is evaluated for palpitations. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a ventricular septal defect that closed spontaneously as a child. His father has coronary artery disease. Prior to admission, his only medications were hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. He currently also takes hydromorphone/acetaminophen for mild postoperative pain. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min and irregular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 139/85 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a normal S1 and S2 without murmurs and clear lung fields. The abdominal incisions are clean, dry, and intact. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the lower quadrants. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ECG findings?
hint: The ECG shows premature ventricular contractions (PVC) in bigeminy.
learning_objective: Recognize hypokalemia as a cause of postoperative arrhythmias.

answers.explanation_why:
Postoperative arrhythmia (e.g., PVCs) is a common finding following cardiac and noncardiac surgery. The underlying pathophysiology is often complex but contributing factors may include high levels of catecholamines (endogenously due to the perioperative stress state; exogenous in the case of cardiovascular support), electrolyte or acid-base imbalances (e.g., hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia), reduced ventilation (leading to hypoxia and/or hypercarbia), and certain drugs. This patient takes a thiazide diuretic (hydrochlorothiazide), which is associated with an increased risk of hypokalemia. In cardiac cells, hypokalemia inhibits cardiac Na-K ATPase and causes prolonged ventricular repolarization, which predisposes to arrhythmias.

Most patients with PVCs are asymptomatic and treatment (e.g., with antiarrhythmics or catheter ablation) is only required if PVCs are frequent or significantly symptomatic.

An accessory pathway in the heart is seen in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, a possible cause of arrhythmia. However, typical ECG findings in WPW syndrome include a shortened PR interval and a "slurred" upstroke in the QRS complex known as a delta wave, neither of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, WPW syndrome is a congenital defect that most commonly manifests during childhood or adolescence and would therefore be unlikely in a 46-year-old patient without a prior history of arrhythmias.

images.title: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

answers.explanation_why: While certain drugs that are administered in the perioperative period may trigger arrhythmias (e.g., antibiotics, antihistamines), hydromorphone is not a common cause.

Acute myocardial ischemia is a possible cause of postoperative arrhythmia (e.g., PVCs). While this patient has cardiovascular risk factors, including obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a family history of coronary artery disease, he does not have any signs (e.g., ST elevations or Q waves on ECG) or symptoms (e.g., chest pain, diaphoresis, or dyspnea) that suggest myocardial ischemia.

images.title: Acute anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 90/min
– Left axis deviation (R > S in I, S > R in aVF)
– There are both ventricular (green overlay) and supraventricular (purple overlay) extrasystoles.
– ST elevation in all precordial leads (V_1–V_6; example indicated by blue overlay), as well as I, aVL, and -aVR
– Reciprocal ST depression in III (red overlay), and nonsignificantly also in aVF
– Pathological Q waves in V_1–V_4 (yellow overlay)Note that the limb leads of this ECG are arranged differently than usual: in this 'Cabrera' format the limb leads are shown in anatomically contiguous order, as they appear on the Cabrera circle (beginning with aVL and proceeding clockwise). To allow this the format also uses negative aVR (-aVR), which is obtained by simply inverting the polarity of the usual positive aVR. ST elevation in -aVR is therefore equivalent to ST depression in aVR.

answers.explanation_why: Atrial enlargement (e.g., due to fluid overload) is a common contributing factor in the development of postoperative arrhythmias. Moreover, chronic hypertension may lead to left atrial enlargement. However, atrial enlargement leads to supraventricular arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation) rather than ventricular arrhythmias like this patient's PVCs.

images.title: Atrial fibrillation
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25mm/s)- Irregularly irregular rhythm
- Rate ∼ 90/min
- Normal axis
- No discernable P waves
- Coarse fibrillatory waves (f waves) are visible, particularly in II, aVF and V1

images.title: Bigeminy
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Rate: ∼ 70/min
– Rhythm: bigeminy - alternating sinus complexes (examples indicated by green circles) and premature ventricular complexes (PVCs; examples indicated by red lines)
– Axis: normal or slight left axis deviation
– Nonspecific intraventricular conduction delay in the sinus complexes (QRS duration > 0.12 s but no clear right or left bundle branch block morphology)
– The PVCs are unifocal (all PVCs in a given lead look the same, indicating they come from the same focus) and most likely arise in the left ventricle (positive in V1, negative in V5/V6).

question_text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient appears to be in moderate respiratory distress and is cradling his upper left arm in his right arm. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 25/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 108/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises on the left anterior thoracic wall. Jugular venous pulsation is measured at 3 cm above the sternal angle (8 cm H₂O) with the head of the bed elevated at 30 degrees. The trachea is at the midline. On inspiration, his left chest wall moves inwards while his right chest wall is expanding. There is pain to palpation and crepitus over his left anterior ribs. A CT scan confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient appears to be in moderate respiratory distress and is cradling his upper left arm in his right arm. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 25/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 108/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises on the left anterior thoracic wall. Jugular venous pulsation is measured at 3 cm above the sternal angle (8 cm H₂O) with the head of the bed elevated at 30 degrees. The trachea is at the midline. On inspiration, his left chest wall moves inwards while his right chest wall is expanding. There is pain to palpation and crepitus over his left anterior ribs. A CT scan confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: Paradoxical chest movement (inward movement of the chest wall during inspiration) indicates a flail chest, which is a detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to ≥ 3 adjacent rib fractures in ≥ 2 places.
learning_objective: Recognize flail chest, and choose the most appropriate respiratory support.

answers.explanation_why: Needle thoracostomy is performed if the patient has a tension pneumothorax. Although rib fractures can cause a pneumothorax, the absence of tracheal deviation and increased jugular venous pressure makes a tension pneumothorax unlikely.

Rib fractures inhibit deep breathing because of the pain accompanying chest wall expansion. The flail segment further increases the work of breathing and restricts lung volume changes by moving in the direction opposite to thoracic wall movement. The initial management of a flail chest consists of adequate analgesia and supplemental oxygen therapy. Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is indicated if the patient has evidence of respiratory failure. PPV directly assists with alveolar ventilation and gas exchange and may have an internal splinting effect on the flail segment. In patients who are alert and fully oriented, noninvasive PPV may be attempted, but this patient with an altered mental status also requires intubation for airway protection.

If the patient with a flail chest has a concomitant pneumothorax, tube thoracostomy should be performed before initiating PPV to prevent a simple pneumothorax from turning into a life-threatening tension pneumothorax.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

answers.explanation_why: Bedside thoracotomy is indicated as a last resort for cardiac arrest or exsanguinating intrathoracic hemorrhage when all other measures have failed. Although this patient shows respiratory compromise and requires urgent intervention, thoracotomy is not an appropriate treatment for a flail chest.

Pericardiocentesis is indicated for a patient with cardiac tamponade, which can occur following trauma as a result of a hemopericardium. The absence of increased jugular venous pressure makes a cardiac tamponade unlikely.

Surgical fixation may be indicated for patients with flail chest but would not be the first step in treatment of a patient with respiratory distress who does not respond to O_2 supplementation. Indications include gross chest wall deformity and failure to wean the patient off mechanical ventilation, which would be a sign that mechanical ventilation alone does not provide sufficient internal stabilization of the flail segment.
