question_text: A 3900-g (8-lb 10-oz) newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Immediately after delivery, he spontaneously cries, grimaces, and moves all four extremities. Over the next five minutes, he becomes cyanotic and tachypneic. Bag-mask ventilation with 100% oxygen is begun, but ten minutes after delivery the baby continues to appear cyanotic. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen bag-mask ventilation shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. Breath sounds are normal on the right and absent on the left. Heart sounds are best heard in the right midclavicular line. The abdomen appears concave. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 3900-g (8-lb 10-oz) newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Immediately after delivery, he spontaneously cries, grimaces, and moves all four extremities. Over the next five minutes, he becomes cyanotic and tachypneic. Bag-mask ventilation with 100% oxygen is begun, but ten minutes after delivery the baby continues to appear cyanotic. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen bag-mask ventilation shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. Breath sounds are normal on the right and absent on the left. Heart sounds are best heard in the right midclavicular line. The abdomen appears concave. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
hint: This newborn exhibits respiratory distress (cyanosis, tachypnea), absent breath sounds on the left, heart sounds shifted further to the right, and a scaphoid abdomen. These features, together with the chest x-ray demonstrating a mediastinal shift to the right, bowel loops within the thoracic cavity, and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax, confirm the diagnosis of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
learning_objective: Recognize congenital diaphragmatic hernia, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Extracorporeal life support (ECLS) is indicated in infants with CDH and respiratory failure who do not improve with mechanical ventilation, as well as those with persistent hypoxia and/or acidosis on conventional medical therapy. This patient's respiratory decompensation requires immediate treatment, which means that ECLS is not the most appropriate next step.

Endotracheal surfactant is indicated in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Neonates with NRDS may present with tachypnea and cyanosis, however, this patient's chest x-ray indicates CDH. While surfactant administration is also recommended in the management of CDH in infants born at < 34 weeks of gestation if the x-ray findings suggest concomitant NRDS, this patient was born at term and there is no evidence of NRDS on x-ray.

images.title: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
images.description: X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infantThe lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

answers.explanation_why: This neonate has cyanosis, hypoxia, and tachypnea, which can be findings of congenital heart disease. Echocardiography can be used to confirm the presence of a cardiac malformation (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot or transposition of the great vessels). However, this newborn's x-ray does not reveal any signs of heart disease (e.g., increased heart size or an abnormal configuration of the aortic arch), but rather findings indicating CDH.

Surgical repair is indicated in all cases of CDH since spontaneous closure is unlikely and surgery may prevent further complications of the lung (e.g., pulmonary hypoplasia and persistent pulmonary hypertension) and intestine (e.g., bowel obstruction, strangulation, or perforation). The most common procedure is the reduction of the hernial contents followed by closure (primary or using a biomaterial patch) of the diaphragmatic defect. However, surgery should be deferred until the newborn has been stabilized (most frequently at 24–48 hours); therefore, it is not the most appropriate next step in a patient with acute respiratory decompensation.

The patient has some of the characteristic features of tension pneumothorax, including respiratory distress, absent breath sounds over the affected side of the lung, and shifting of heart sounds to the contralateral side, suggesting mediastinal deviation. However, in addition to the mediastinal shift to the right, this patient's chest x-ray shows findings of CDH. While chest tube placement is the preferred and often life-saving treatment for pneumothorax, it is contraindicated in patients with a diaphragmatic hernia as there is a high risk of injury to the herniated bowel.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A large right tension pneumothorax is accompanied by lung collapse. When compared to the left hemithorax, no lung markings are seen in the right hemithorax beyond the margin of the collapsed right lung (green overlay). Signs of tension seen here include contralateral shift of mediastinal structures and depression of the right hemidiaphragm (indicated by red lines and arrow). Another sign that may be seen in tension pneumothorax is ipsilateral intercostal space widening.An unrelated finding on this radiograph is slight curvature of the upper to midthoracic spine, convex to the left.Black line and arrows: shift of mediastinal pleura; white line and arrows: shift of cardiomediastinal silhouette

answers.explanation_why:
In patients with CDH, the compression of the lung from protruded abdominal contents may interfere with fetal lung maturation and lead to pulmonary hypoplasia, persistent pulmonary hypertension, and poor surfactant production, resulting in severe respiratory distress in the newborn. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the priority in all patients with CDH and should be performed before any further intervention because they help to decrease air swallowing and correct hypoxia. Bag-mask ventilation is contraindicated as air is pumped into the stomach and the bowel, resulting in gastric and/or intestinal distention and further compression of the lung. As in this patient, the majority (approximately 85%) of CDH cases are left-sided.

Following intubation, a nasogastric tube should be placed for gastric decompression to decompress the stomach/bowel and reduce lung compression.

images.title: Left-sided congenital diaphragmatic hernia
images.description: Chest x-ray, PA view, in a newborn.Mediastinal shift to the right (solid line: mediastinal border in this patient; dashed line: approximate physiologic position), bowel loops within the left thoracic cavity (green marking), and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax.

question_text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 2 episodes of loss of consciousness over the past week. She recovered immediately and was not confused following the episodes. During the past 5 months, she has also had increased shortness of breath and palpitations. She has been unable to carry out her daily activities. She also reports some chest tightness that resolves with rest. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She immigrated with her family from India 10 years ago. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 115/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows accentuation and splitting of S_2. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur in the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these findings?
content_preview: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 2 episodes of loss of consciousness over the past week. She recovered immediately and was not confused following the episodes. During the past 5 months, she has also had increased shortness of breath and palpitations. She has been unable to carry out her daily activities. She also reports some chest tightness that resolves with rest. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She immigrated with her family from India 10 years ago. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 115/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows accentuation and splitting of S2. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur in the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these findings?
hint: This patient has features of mitral stenosis (opening snap and diastolic murmur along with atrial fibrillation) that has progressed and caused further hemodynamic changes. Mitral stenosis commonly occurs as a late complication of rheumatic fever, which is more common in developing countries where patients may not have been adequately treated.
learning_objective: Recognize mitral stenosis, and recall its hemodynamic consequences.

answers.content: Increased left ventricular end diastolic pressure
answers.explanation_why: Increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP) is seen in left heart failure, but this patient demonstrates signs of mitral stenosis (MS). MS causes a decrease in LVEDP due to impaired ability to fill the left ventricle in diastole through the stenotic valve.

Left-to-right shunting may be present in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) or an atrial septal defect (ASD). However, this patient's cardiovascular examination is consistent with mitral stenosis (opening snap with low-pitched diastolic murmur at the apex). She does not have a murmur that suggests a VSD or ASD (holosystolic murmur).

Decreased left ventricular contractility may be due to ischemic or nonischemic cardiomyopathy. A decrease in contractility may lead to left heart failure, increased left heart pressures, and subsequent right heart failure. However, the patient shows signs of mitral stenosis (MS), left atrial dilatation, and right ventricular hypertrophy, suggesting that MS is the underlying mechanism and not left ventricular failure.

Increased systemic arterial resistance can be seen in patients with essential hypertension or secondary causes of hypertension. This may eventually lead to left ventricular hypertrophy which can evolve into diastolic dysfunction. As this patient shows right axis deviation on ECG, she is unlikely to have left ventricular hypertrophy. Additionally, the patient has normal blood pressure on examination, which suggests a different diagnosis.

Preload to the right ventricle is determined by central venous pressure and venous return to the heart and may be increased in states that expand blood volume (such as congestive heart failure). While this patient shows signs of right-sided heart failure, the presence of mitral stenosis with right axis deviation suggests a different underlying mechanism of the patient's disease.

Mitral stenosis leads to increased left atrial pressure, causing both left atrial dilatation, which may result in atrial fibrillation, and an increase in pulmonary arterial pressure to overcome the increased left heart pressure (pulmonary hypertension). Over time, this will lead to pulmonary vascular remodeling, increased pulmonary vascular resistance, splitting of S_2, and right ventricular hypertrophy (as indicated by the right axis deviation) to compensate. Right ventricular failure eventually manifests with characteristic features such as jugular venous distention and pitting edema.

images.title: Heart murmur in mitral stenosis
images.description: Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

question_text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, abdominal fullness, and pedal edema for 3 months. Four months ago, he was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and is currently receiving therapy with isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 96/70 mm Hg. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. There is jugular venous distention. The jugular venous pressure rises with inspiration. Breath sounds are decreased at the lung base bilaterally. Cardiac examination reveals an early diastolic sound over the left sternal border. The abdomen is distended and a shifting dullness test is positive. An ECG shows low-amplitude QRS complexes. Chest x-ray shows small pleural effusions bilaterally and calcifications over the left cardiac silhouette. Echocardiography shows a 40% decrease in the velocity of peak diastolic blood flow across the mitral valve during inspiration. Cardiac catheterization shows elevated right ventricular diastolic pressure with characteristic dip-and-plateau waveform. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, abdominal fullness, and pedal edema for 3 months. Four months ago, he was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and is currently receiving therapy with isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 96/70 mm Hg. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. There is jugular venous distention. The jugular venous pressure rises with inspiration. Breath sounds are decreased at the lung base bilaterally. Cardiac examination reveals an early diastolic sound over the left sternal border. The abdomen is distended and a shifting dullness test is positive. An ECG shows low-amplitude QRS complexes. Chest x-ray shows small pleural effusions bilaterally and calcifications over the left cardiac silhouette. Echocardiography shows a 40% decrease in the velocity of peak diastolic blood flow across the mitral valve during inspiration. Cardiac catheterization shows elevated right ventricular diastolic pressure with characteristic dip-and-plateau waveform. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient with tuberculosis and dyspnea, ascites (distended abdomen, shifting dullness), and peripheral edema has a positive Kussmaul sign (increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration) and a pericardial knock (early diastolic sound over the left sternal border). These features along with calcifications on chest x-ray and an exaggerated respiratory variation of blood flow on echocardiography indicate constrictive pericarditis, which may be confirmed by a positive square root sign on cardiac catheterization (dip-and-plateau waveform).
learning_objective: Recognize constrictive pericarditis, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: An implantable cardioverter defibrillator is recommended for patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy at risk for sudden cardiac death (e.g., history of cardiac arrest, family history of sudden cardiac death). Although obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may cause dyspnea and hypotension, as seen in this patient, it does not typically cause peripheral edema, Kussmaul sign, or a low-amplitude QRS complex. Additionally, this patient is missing typical signs of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, including: exertional angina; syncope; a jerky, biphasic pulse; a heaving, double apical impulse; systolic murmur; an S_3 or S_4; and/or evidence of arrhythmias.

Corticosteroid therapy is an alternative treatment for acute pericarditis in patients who have a contraindication to NSAIDs. It is not considered a first-line treatment due to systemic side effects and concern for an increased rate of recurrence of acute pericarditis when corticosteroids are administered. Furthermore, acute pericarditis usually presents with chest pain and a pericardial friction rub, both of which are absent in this patient. Additionally, acute pericarditis usually resolves within 6 weeks, but this patient has had symptoms for 3 months. An ECG would also show a concave-shaped ST elevation with or without PR depression, and unlike this patient, changes in the QRS complex would not be present.

Colchicine therapy is indicated for the treatment of acute pericarditis as it alleviates symptoms and reduces the rate of recurrence. However, acute pericarditis usually manifests with chest pain and a pericardial friction rub, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, acute pericarditis also usually resolves within six weeks, whereas this patient has had symptoms for three months. An ECG would also show diffuse, concave-shaped ST elevations with or without PR depressions, and changes in the QRS complex would not be present.

Pericardiectomy, along with the treatment of any underlying condition (i.e., this patient's tuberculosis), is the recommended approach for constrictive pericarditis. In constrictive pericarditis, a thick, rigid, and fibrous pericardium compromises cardiac function, which is restored by the removal of the fibrotic pericardium. In patients without signs of chronic constrictive pericarditis (i.e., no pericardial calcifications, atrial fibrillation, hepatic dysfunction, anasarca, or cachexia), pharmacotherapy can be attempted first. This can include NSAIDs, colchicine, diuretics, corticosteroids, and immunomodulatory therapy; these measures should also be considered as adjuncts to pericardiectomy in chronic constrictive pericarditis.

In healthy individuals, the velocity of blood flow in the left side of the heart normally decreases with inspiration. However, in patients with constrictive pericarditis, this decrease in blood flow is exaggerated (> 25% decrease in diastolic flow across the mitral valve) because the rigid, fibrotic, shell-like pericardium impedes diastolic filling due to impaired relaxation of the left ventricle. In addition to these findings, an echocardiogram would show acoustic shadowing (caused by calcifications) and thickening of the pericardium.

In patients with constrictive pericarditis, tachycardia is a compensatory mechanism that helps maintain cardiac output. Administering beta blockers such as metoprolol to such patients eliminates this compensatory function and would result in a poor outcome. Therefore, neither this nor any other drug that reduces heart rate is recommended for the management of constrictive pericarditis.

Heart transplantation is indicated as a last resort for restrictive cardiomyopathy, which presents with increased jugular venous pressure, Kussmaul sign, peripheral edema, ascites, and pleural effusion, as seen here. However, restrictive cardiomyopathy does not present with an exaggerated variation of blood flow during respiration, or a pericardial knock. Instead, a third and/or fourth heart sound would be heard. Although this condition may also present with low-amplitude QRS complex, it is usually seen with other ECG findings such as depolarization abnormalities (e.g., bundle branch block), ventricular hypertrophy, atrioventricular conduction alteration, and/or pathologic Q waves, none of which are present in this patient.

Pericardiocentesis is the treatment for cardiac tamponade. This patient has a history of tuberculosis, which may cause pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Although cardiac tamponade would manifest with some of this patient's features – e.g., tachycardia, jugular venous distention, low-amplitude QRS complexes, hypotension, and an exaggerated variation of blood flow with respiration – it would also cause other features that are absent (e.g., muffled heart sounds, chest pain). Additionally, acute cardiac tamponade does not cause Kussmaul sign or a pericardial knock.

question_text: One and a half hours after undergoing an elective cardiac catheterization, a 53-year-old woman has right flank and back pain. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She had an 80% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery and 2 stents were placed. Intravenous unfractionated heparin was used prior to the procedure. Prior to admission, her medications were enalapril, simvastatin, and metformin. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 109/75 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Examination shows a tender lower abdomen; there is no guarding or rigidity. There is right suprainguinal fullness and tenderness. There is no bleeding or discharge from the femoral access site. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. A complete blood count shows a hematocrit of 36%, a leukocyte count of 8400/mm^3, and a platelet count of 230,000/mm^3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: One and a half hours after undergoing an elective cardiac catheterization, a 53-year-old woman has right flank and back pain. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She had an 80% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery and 2 stents were placed. Intravenous unfractionated heparin was used prior to the procedure. Prior to admission, her medications were enalapril, simvastatin, and metformin. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 109/75 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Examination shows a tender lower abdomen; there is no guarding or rigidity. There is right suprainguinal fullness and tenderness. There is no bleeding or discharge from the femoral access site. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. A complete blood count shows a hematocrit of 36%, a leukocyte count of 8400/mm3, and a platelet count of 230,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This woman presents with flank and back pain after an interventional vascular procedure conducted through a femoral access site. In combination with lower abdominal tenderness and suprainguinal fullness and tenderness, this suggests retroperitoneal bleeding.
learning_objective: Recognize retroperitoneal bleeding after a vascular procedure, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Abdominal x-ray is commonly performed for evaluating surgical emergencies such as free air or signs of mechanical bowel obstruction. This patient has suspected retroperitoneal bleeding, for which this imaging modality does not provide reliable information about the extent or origin of the bleeding, even if visualized indirectly (e.g., in obliteration of the psoas muscle shadow).

Administration of protamine sulfate is indicated for heparin overdose or major active bleeding on heparin therapy in order to bind heparin and reverse its anticoagulation effects. This patient received a dose of unfractionated heparin prior to surgery and active bleeding is suspected. However, unfractionated heparin has a half-life of only 30–60 minutes, and thus the remaining effect is most likely minor 1.5 hours after administration. Additionally, the decision as to whether reversal of anticoagulation is indicated in this patient should be based on the judgment of an experienced clinician and should include careful consideration of indications for anticoagulation and severity of bleeding. The diagnosis should therefore be confirmed first.

answers.content: Obtain CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
answers.explanation_why: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis should be performed in all patients with suspected retroperitoneal bleeding to confirm the diagnosis. While generally rare, retroperitoneal hemorrhage is the most common cause of unexpected mortality after diagnostic or interventional cardiac catheterization. It often occurs when femoral access is obtained above the inguinal ligament, as compression of the puncture site is difficult in this area and sufficient hemostasis is not easily achieved. Patients usually become symptomatic after significant blood loss, which often leads to a late diagnosis of the condition. Retroperitoneal hemorrhage can also occur spontaneously or after only mild trauma in patients on oral anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin).

images.title: Retroperitoneal hemorrhage from the left common iliac artery
images.description: CT abdomen (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with abdominal pain after lumbar discectomyThe large collection with irregular margins in the left retroperitoneum represents hemorrhage (H; green overlay). The site of active bleeding is indicated by contrast-enhanced blood (bright green overlay) arising from the proximal left common iliac artery (CIA).PV: portal vein; K: kidney; GB: gallbladder; A: aorta

answers.explanation_why: Atropine can be used in patients with a vasovagal response to treat bradycardia. Vasovagal responses can be triggered by a variety of factors, including stress or arterial puncture in the catheter lab. While a vasovagal response would also manifest with hypotension, it would be combined with bradycardia and not the tachycardia seen in this patient. This patient's symptoms are most likely a compensatory response to active bleeding and subsequent hypovolemia.

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is obtained for diagnostic evaluation of patients with suspected cardiovascular disease. Although extremely rare (≤ 0.1%), a myocardial infarction is a possible complication to be considered in patients after cardiac catheterization. While myocardial infarctions can manifest with abdominal symptoms, they usually cause epigastric rather than inguinal pain. Additionally, this patient has hemodynamic signs of volume loss, which makes confirmation of suspected bleeding the priority in this patient.

Endovascular treatment in the catheter lab should be considered in a hemodynamically unstable patient with active retroperitoneal bleeding that does not respond to supportive treatment (e.g., monitoring, fluid resuscitation, blood transfusion). Stent placement or intraarterial embolization may be used to try to stop the hemorrhage. However, this patient appears hemodynamically stable and diagnosis should be confirmed before initiating invasive treatment.

question_text: A 25-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department because of an episode of acute psychosis with suicidal ideation. He has no history of serious illness and currently takes no medications. Despite appropriate safety precautions, he manages to leave the examination room unattended. Shortly afterward, he is found lying outside the emergency department. A visitor reports that she saw the patient climbing up the facade of the hospital building. He does not respond to questions but points to his head when asked about pain. His pulse is 131/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Physical examination shows a 1-cm head laceration and an open fracture of the right tibia. He opens his eyes spontaneously. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Breath sounds are decreased over the right lung field, and the upper right hemithorax is hyperresonant to percussion. There is no jugular venous distension. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department because of an episode of acute psychosis with suicidal ideation. He has no history of serious illness and currently takes no medications. Despite appropriate safety precautions, he manages to leave the examination room unattended. Shortly afterward, he is found lying outside the emergency department. A visitor reports that she saw the patient climbing up the facade of the hospital building. He does not respond to questions but points to his head when asked about pain. His pulse is 131/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Physical examination shows a 1-cm head laceration and an open fracture of the right tibia. He opens his eyes spontaneously. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Breath sounds are decreased over the right lung field, and the upper right hemithorax is hyperresonant to percussion. There is no jugular venous distension. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Remember the ABCDE approach to trauma management.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for cervical spine protection in a trauma patient, and choose the initial step in airway management.

answers.explanation_why: Needle thoracostomy is indicated for tension pneumothorax causing respiratory compromise. Although this patient likely has pneumothorax (hyperresonance to percussion and decreased breath sounds on examination), he currently does not have signs of severe acute respiratory distress resulting from tension pneumothorax (e.g., jugular venous distention, tracheal deviation, cyanosis). Airway protection should take place before managing a potential tension pneumothorax that is not causing respiratory compromise. Close monitoring for deterioration, for which needle thoracostomy may become necessary, is also indicated.

Endotracheal intubation is indicated for patients with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8 or less because these patients often cannot maintain their airway. This patient has a GCS of 11: He opens his eyes spontaneously (eye opening = 4), obeys commands by localizing pain (motor response = 6), and does not respond verbally to questions (verbal response = 1). Although this patient currently does not need intubation for airway protection, he is still at risk for an injury that further compromises his airway; therefore, part “A” of the ABCDE approach needs to be addressed first.

In patients with blunt trauma to the head and neck, a cervical spine injury should be assumed until proven otherwise. The fact that this patient does not respond verbally to questions despite being conscious raises concern that his airway is compromised. This patient needs a cervical collar to immobilize the cervical spine, ensuring protection of his airway from further damage. This step addresses part “A” (airway assessment and protection) of the ABCDE approach to managing trauma patients.

To diagnose or exclude cervical spine injury, x-ray and CT scan, as well as a physical examination in the form of cervical spine palpation for tenderness, are performed.

answers.content: Place two large bore IV catheters and start two bags of 0.9% saline
answers.explanation_why: This patient will need intravenous fluids to increase his blood pressure of 105/69 mm Hg. Intravenous fluid administration addresses the “C” (circulation and hemorrhage control) of the ABCDE approach to managing trauma patients. Before the administration of fluids, however, this patient needs airway protection; airway (“A”) compromise is more immediately life-threatening than hypotension.

A neurological examination is appropriate once the airway, respiratory (breathing), and circulatory status of this patient have been addressed (parts “A” through “C” of the ABCDE approach to managing trauma patients). The neurological examination is part “D” of the ABCDE approach to neurological disability assessment.

An x-ray in this patient will eventually be necessary to help identify possible rib fractures and pulmonary conditions such as pneumothorax and/or hemothorax. Because this patient likely suffered severe blunt trauma to the head and neck, he may have sustained an airway-compromising injury. Such an injury must be adequately addressed before an x-ray is obtained.

answers.content: Perform open reduction of the tibia fracture
answers.explanation_why: Open reduction of the tibia fracture is not the most appropriate next step in treating this patient who may have an injury that compromises his airway. Before the tibia fracture can be addressed, the ABCDE approach to trauma management needs to be completed in alphabetical order, with an emphasis on “A” or airway management and protection in the patient.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after having been diagnosed with stage II adenocarcinoma of the left lower lung lobe without evidence of distant metastases 1 week ago following an evaluation for a chronic cough. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. His current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and enalapril. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m^2. He appears lethargic. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows inspiratory wheezing at the left lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, glucose, and liver enzymes are within the reference range. Spirometry shows an FEV_1 of 1.8 L. The diffusing lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 66% of predicted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after having been diagnosed with stage II adenocarcinoma of the left lower lung lobe without evidence of distant metastases 1 week ago following an evaluation for a chronic cough. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. His current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and enalapril. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. He appears lethargic. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows inspiratory wheezing at the left lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, glucose, and liver enzymes are within the reference range. Spirometry shows an FEV1 of 1.8 L. The diffusing lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 66% of predicted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A FEV_1 > 1.5 L and < 2 L with a DLCO of > 60 % of predicted indicates sufficient preoperative lung function.
learning_objective: Recognize stage II lung adenocarcinoma with sufficient preoperative lung function, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical resection with or without chemotherapy is the standard of care for early-stage lung cancers and confers the best chance for cure. Resection significantly affects lung function, so preoperative pulmonary assessment using spirometry is necessary. It is recommended that patients undergoing lobectomy have a FEV1 over 1.5 liters and DLCO > 60% of predicted without evidence of undue dyspnea on exertion.

For lung cancer, radiation therapy alone is typically only recommended for palliative purposes and if the cancer is inoperable due to metastases. This patient's lung cancer is not advanced enough to forego other definitive treatment options, nor does he have symptoms (e.g. dyspnea due to airway obstruction, dysphagia, or hemoptysis) related to any mass effect of the adenocarcinoma that would require palliative radiation.
Wedge resection is considered in patients with limited pulmonary function, meaning FEV1 is less than 1.5 liters and DLCO is less than 60% of predicted.

Combined therapy with cisplatin and etoposide is one of the most common chemotherapy regimens for small cell lung cancer. This regimen is less commonly used for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Before a regimen is initiated, the tumor should be tested for common mutations in NSCLC (e.g., PD-L1, EGFR, ALK). Chemotherapy should only be started if the patient has no targetable mutations.

Pneumonectomy is recommended for patients with FEV1 greater than 2 liters. Furthermore, this procedure is usually performed for malignancies that are centrally located (e.g., bronchogenic carcinoma); it is not commonly used in peripherally located lung cancers such as lung adenocarcinomas.

question_text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is lethargic. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. He withdraws his extremities to pain. There are multiple bruises over his face, chest, and abdomen. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. Two large bore peripheral venous catheters are inserted, and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Rapid sequence intubation is initiated, and orotracheal intubation via direct laryngoscopy is attempted three times without success. A laryngeal mask airway insertion also fails. Despite continuous bag-valve-mask ventilation, pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. The patient has no advance directive, and family members have not arrived. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is lethargic. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. He withdraws his extremities to pain. There are multiple bruises over his face, chest, and abdomen. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. Two large bore peripheral venous catheters are inserted, and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Rapid sequence intubation is initiated, and orotracheal intubation via direct laryngoscopy is attempted three times without success. A laryngeal mask airway insertion also fails. Despite continuous bag-valve-mask ventilation, pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. The patient has no advance directive, and family members have not arrived. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient is in a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate (CICV) scenario with increasing hypoxemia.
learning_objective: Recognize a cannot intubate-cannot ventilate scenario, and choose the most appropriate emergency airway management.

answers.explanation_why: Video laryngoscopy allows for visualization of the oropharynx and is commonly used to facilitate orotracheal intubation in patients with a difficult airway. Although video laryngoscopy could have been used earlier in the management of this patient, several intubation attempts have been unsuccessful. Furthermore, his oxygen saturation is acutely dropping despite attempts at maintaining ventilation and oxygenation through bag-valve and laryngeal masks. If establishing an alternative airway via video laryngoscopy is unsuccessful, hypoxic brain injury may occur. Another step is more appropriate in an emergency setting.

This patient has just suffered major trauma, and his preferred code status is unknown. It would be highly inappropriate to change his code status to comfort measures only in the absence of an advance directive, a health care proxy, and before all possible treatment modalities have been exhausted.

Although an emergency tracheostomy may be performed in a CICV scenario, this approach is usually not the first-line option because it is more complex and time-consuming, and causes more bleeding than other emergency surgical airway procedures.

A nasotracheal approach can be attempted to achieve intubation in patients with a difficult airway and limited oral access (e.g., due to oropharyngeal obstruction). However, this technique is usually performed electively in the operating room under direct visualization of the pharynx with laryngoscopy. Nasopharyngeal intubation is time-consuming and is therefore inappropriate in a CICV scenario with declining oxygen saturation, which requires an emergency airway.

This patient has just experienced major trauma and presents with signs of respiratory distress (respiratory rate of 10/min, oxygen saturation of 84%), neurological compromise (lethargy, sluggish pupils), and a compromised airway (decreased breath sounds over left hemithorax, rapid decrease in oxygen saturation). After unsuccessful attempts at securing the airway and ventilation via orotracheal intubation, laryngeal mask placement, and bag-mask ventilation, immediate action is required to prevent hypoxia. A surgical airway with cricothyrotomy should be established in patients who cannot be intubated and oxygenated. Cricothyrotomy is the preferred method in an emergency when rapid airway control is needed, especially in cases where intubation is unsuccessful, and other supraglottic airway devices are ineffective.

images.title: Cricothyroidotomy
images.description: Diagram showing an emergency cricothyroidotomy, which is typically performed if attempts to intubate have been unsuccessful. An incision is made through the cricothyroid membrane, and a cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted through the incision site. Cricothyroidotomy allows ventilation of the patient until a more definitive airway is placed.

question_text: A 34-year-old primigravid woman at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a follow-up examination for a mass she found in her left breast 2 weeks ago. Menarche occurred at the age of 11 years, and menses occurred at 30- to 40-day intervals until pregnancy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm, firm, nontender, nonmobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. Ultrasound and ultrasound-guided core biopsy confirm an infiltrating lobular carcinoma. The pathological specimen is positive for estrogen and ERBB2 receptors and negative for progesterone receptors. Staging shows no distant metastatic disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 34-year-old primigravid woman at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a follow-up examination for a mass she found in her left breast 2 weeks ago. Menarche occurred at the age of 11 years, and menses occurred at 30- to 40-day intervals until pregnancy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm, firm, nontender, nonmobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. Ultrasound and ultrasound-guided core biopsy confirm an infiltrating lobular carcinoma. The pathological specimen is positive for estrogen and ERBB2 receptors and negative for progesterone receptors. Staging shows no distant metastatic disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Early-stage infiltrating lobular carcinoma is usually treated with breast-conserving surgery and adjuvant systemic therapy. For gestational breast cancer, it is important to offer a treatment regimen with a low risk of fetal damage.
learning_objective: Recognize gestational breast cancer, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical resection is associated with minimal risk to the fetus regardless of gestational age, but radiotherapy is contraindicated during pregnancy because of the risk of fetal damage.

Surgical resection (i.e., breast-conserving surgery or mastectomy with or without axillary node dissection) poses little risk to the fetus at any gestational age. Because her tumor is 3 cm, this patient is considered high risk and should therefore undergo adjuvant chemotherapy. Certain chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, fluorouracil) have a low risk profile and can be used in the second or third trimester of pregnancy. Chemotherapy should be discontinued 3–4 weeks before delivery to reduce the risk of complications (e.g., transient neonatal myelosuppression, bleeding, sepsis) during childbirth and in the postpartum period.

A 3–6 month delay in chemotherapy is associated with less favorable outcomes in nonpregnant individuals. Therefore, physicians should counsel patients through open communication and shared decision-making, according to their individual treatment needs. Patients have the right to refuse chemotherapy and/or delay treatment until after delivery.

Trastuzumab can be considered in nonpregnant patients who have an ERBB2-positive tumor. However, because of the fetal complications associated with trastuzumab (e.g., pulmonary hypoplasia, fetal death), this medication should not be used in pregnant individuals.

The combination of hormonal therapy and trastuzumab is a recommended adjuvant treatment after surgical resection for estrogen-receptor-positive, ERBB2-positive breast cancer. However, both treatment options are contraindicated during pregnancy because of the risk of fetal damage.

Termination of pregnancy is not recommended in this patient because there is treatment available that is associated with only minimal risk of fetal damage. Furthermore, pregnancy termination is not associated with better breast cancer survival.

question_text:
A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of 2-day history of confusion and anuria. He has chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia at the age of 8 years and was treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplantation. He is HIV-positive and has an active hepatitis C virus infection. He drinks around eight cans of beer every week. His current medications include tenofovir, emtricitabine, atazanavir, daclatasvir, sofosbuvir, insulin, amlodipine, and enalapril. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Examination shows severe edema in both legs and generalized muscular weakness. Auscultation of the lungs show crepitant rales. Laboratory studies show positive HCV antibody and positive HCV RNA. His HIV viral load is undetectable and his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 589/mm^3. Six months ago, his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count was 618/mm^3. An ECG of the heart shows arrhythmia with frequent premature ventricular contractions. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.23

PCO_2

31 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

13 mEq/L

Base excess
-12 mEq/L

The patient states he would like to donate organs or tissues in the case of his death. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for organ donation in this patient?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of 2-day history of confusion and anuria. He has chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia at the age of 8 years and was treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplantation. He is HIV-positive and has an active hepatitis C virus infection. He drinks around eight cans of beer every week. His current medications include tenofovir, emtricitabine, atazanavir, daclatasvir, sofosbuvir, insulin, amlodipine, and enalapril. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Examination shows severe edema in both legs and generalized muscular weakness. Auscultation of the lungs show crepitant rales. Laboratory studies show positive HCV antibody and positive HCV RNA. His HIV viral load is undetectable and his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 589/mm3. Six months ago, his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count was 618/mm3. An ECG of the heart shows arrhythmia with frequent premature ventricular contractions. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.23 PCO2 31 mm Hg HCO3- 13 mEq/L Base excess -12 mEq/L The patient states he would like to donate organs or tissues in the case of his death. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for organ donation in this patient?
hint: This patient's medical history has to be thoroughly reviewed for any incurable illnesses or malignancies.
learning_objective: Recognize the current absolute contraindications for organ donation.

answers.explanation_why: Hepatitis C infection is not an absolute contraindication for organ donation. Donor organs from hepatitis C-positive donors may be offered to hepatitis C-positive recipients, even if the virus can be detected in the blood, as in this patient.

HIV infection was formerly an absolute contraindication for organ donation and legally prohibited individuals from becoming organ donors in the US. This rule was based on the principle of nonmaleficence, as transplantation of HIV-positive donor organs may pose harm to transplant recipients. However, the HIV Organ Policy Equity (HOPE) Act implemented in November 2015 now allows transplantation of organs from HIV-positive donors to HIV-positive recipients, provided the donor has an undetectable viral load, no prior history of an opportunistic infection, no active fungal infection, and a CD4+ count over 500 cells/μL for a 6-month period prior to donation. None of these restrictions apply to this patient. This patient's history of HIV does not, therefore, affect his eligibility to donate his organs to HIV-positive recipients. Donor organs from HIV-positive individuals are not transplanted to non-HIV-positive patients.

Although incurable or metastatic malignancy is an absolute contraindication for organ donation, this patient's history of childhood leukemia with a long cancer-free interval does not prohibit organ donation. Organ donation from individuals with low-grade, localized tumors without evidence of metastasis is also permitted.

Alcoholism is a contraindication for pancreas donation, but not for solid organ donations in general. Another contraindication for pancreas donation is diabetes mellitus. Alcohol use disorder (as well as substance use disorder) is also a contraindication for undergoing liver transplantation.

Absolute contraindications for organ donation include incurable or metastatic malignancy, sepsis, transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (e.g., Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease), and cardiac arrest that occurred before brain death, none of which apply to this patient. HIV infection was previously an absolute contraindication for organ donation and legally prohibited individuals from becoming organ donors in the US, but the 2015 HIV Organ Policy Equity (HOPE) act allows transplantation of organs from HIV-positive donors to HIV-positive recipients at certain institutions.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of coughing up blood over the past 2 hours. He says that he has coughed up approximately half a cup of bright-red blood each time. He has had progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion and a productive cough with occasionally blood-tinged sputum for the past 6 months. He has a history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He drinks 2 to 3 beers every evening. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. His medications include amlodipine, tiotropium, and an albuterol inhaler as needed. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 97/63 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. He appears anxious and cachectic. Auscultation of the lungs shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. During the examination, the patient coughs up copious amounts of blood. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8800/mm^3, and platelet count is 160,000/mm^3. His coagulation parameters are within normal limits. Serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. An x-ray of the chest shows hyperinflation of the lung fields and a 2-cm nodule in the right lower lobe. In addition to placing the patient in the right lateral decubitus position, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of coughing up blood over the past 2 hours. He says that he has coughed up approximately half a cup of bright-red blood each time. He has had progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion and a productive cough with occasionally blood-tinged sputum for the past 6 months. He has a history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He drinks 2 to 3 beers every evening. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. His medications include amlodipine, tiotropium, and an albuterol inhaler as needed. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 97/63 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. He appears anxious and cachectic. Auscultation of the lungs shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. During the examination, the patient coughs up copious amounts of blood. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8800/mm3, and platelet count is 160,000/mm3. His coagulation parameters are within normal limits. Serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. An x-ray of the chest shows hyperinflation of the lung fields and a 2-cm nodule in the right lower lobe. In addition to placing the patient in the right lateral decubitus position, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with massive hemoptysis and a pulmonary nodule on x-ray. After securing his airway and cardiovascular function, the source of bleeding should be located.
learning_objective: Recognize massive hemoptysis and a pulmonary nodule, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic procedure after stabilization.

answers.explanation_why: Radionuclide scanning with tagged red blood cells has been successfully used to identify the source of bleeding in individual cases of hemoptysis. However, this technique will only work if there is severe bleeding and may not be accurate if blood pools within the lung. For these reasons, it is not generally recommended.

CT scan of the chest is indicated in patients with a new lesion detected on chest x-ray. CT scan may also be used to identify the bleeding site in patients with hemoptysis and should be performed within the first 12–24 hours of symptom manifestation. However, in this patient with active bleeding and vital signs indicating hemodynamic compromise, another management modality should be performed first.

Upper endoscopy is indicated in the evaluation of patients with hematemesis. While it can sometimes be difficult to distinguish between hemoptysis and hematemesis, this patient's history of progressive shortness of breath with a cough productive of blood-tinged sputum and a pulmonary nodule on chest x-ray are highly suggestive of hemoptysis.

Surgery should be considered in patients with unilateral bleeding not controllable by first-line and second-line treatments. However, no attempts to control this patient's hemoptysis with less invasive treatment options have been made yet. Additionally, lung resection, particularly in patients with active pulmonary bleeding, is associated with high morbidity and mortality and first requires evaluation of the patient's ability to undergo surgery. This patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which may disqualify him for surgery.

Arteriography may be used to identify a site of intrapulmonary hemorrhage and stop the bleeding via embolization. While this treatment option is indicated in patients with persistent hemoptysis after first-line treatment has failed, no other hemostatic measures have been attempted in this patient yet.

Initial steps in the management of massive life-threatening hemoptysis involve the correct positioning of the patient (with the bleeding lung in the dependent position), airway protection, and cardiovascular support. After the patient has been stabilized, bronchoscopy is indicated to identify the source of bleeding as well as to stop the bleeding (e.g., via balloon tamponade, iced saline lavage, topical epinephrine, or laser therapy). If bleeding cannot be controlled by bronchoscopy, arteriography with embolization or surgery should be attempted. In patients with signs of coagulopathy, or those taking anticoagulants, transfusion of blood products or administration of reversal agents may be warranted.

In a patient with a significant smoking history, an x-ray finding of a pulmonary nodule in combination with pulmonary symptoms (progressive shortness of breath and cough productive of blood-tinged sputum) suggests pulmonary hemorrhage due to bronchogenic carcinoma.

question_text:
A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening lower back pain for the past week. The pain is constant, and she describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. Six months ago, she underwent a lumpectomy for hormone receptor-negative lobular carcinoma of the right breast. She has undergone multiple cycles of radiotherapy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a well-healed surgical incision over the right breast. There is severe tenderness to palpation over the 12^th thoracic vertebra. A straight-leg raise test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:

Glucose
76 mg/dL

Creatinine
1 mg/dL

Total bilirubin
0.8 mg/dL

Alkaline phosphatase
234 U/L

Aspartate aminotransferase
16 U/L

Alanine aminotransferase
14 U/L

γ-Glutamyltransferase

40 U/L (N=5–50)

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening lower back pain for the past week. The pain is constant, and she describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. Six months ago, she underwent a lumpectomy for hormone receptor-negative lobular carcinoma of the right breast. She has undergone multiple cycles of radiotherapy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a well-healed surgical incision over the right breast. There is severe tenderness to palpation over the 12th thoracic vertebra. A straight-leg raise test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show: Glucose 76 mg/dL Creatinine 1 mg/dL Total bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 234 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase 16 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 14 U/L γ-Glutamyltransferase 40 U/L (N=5–50) Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In a patient with a history of breast cancer, the combination of increased serum alkaline phosphatase and back pain raises concern for vertebral bone metastasis. A sensitive, noninvasive imaging modality is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize the concern for vertebral bone metastasis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: A positron emission tomography (PET) scan is often used for whole-body skeletal evaluation in the staging of metastatic disease, particularly for lung and breast cancer, as it is specific for bone metastases from these cancers. However, PET scan is more expensive and technically difficult than other whole-body imaging modalities. Moreover, this patient requires a focused workup of her back pain first, rather than a whole-body evaluation.

A bone biopsy is helpful in confirming a diagnosis of bone metastasis, especially when imaging is insufficient or the patient has no known history of primary cancer. However, this is not the first step in management for a patient with suspected vertebral metastases; less invasive diagnostic steps should be taken first.

X-ray is not the first-line imaging modality for patients with suspected vertebral metastases, as it is not sensitive for detecting spinal cord and/or epidural involvement. A focused x-ray study is often the first imaging modality used in evaluating symptomatic metastases to nonvertebral bones. If x-ray shows a pathological fracture, further imaging with a CT scan or MRI is then indicated to evaluate the fracture and determine the need for surgery. Whole-body radiographs are mostly reserved for pure lytic bone metastases (e.g., from multiple myeloma).

Contrast-enhanced MRI of the spine is the imaging modality of choice for suspected vertebral bone metastasis, even in patients without neurologic findings (e.g., bowel or bladder incontinence, weakness, or sensory loss). MRI is also helpful for assessing potential epidural involvement and spinal cord compression, which is why it tends to be preferred over x-ray. The diagnostic approach to bone metastases differs depending on the site of metastasis. If metastases are suspected in the extremities, the first-line imaging study is plain x-ray. In addition, if this patient had back pain but no history of breast cancer, the index of suspicion for a secondary bone malignancy would be low; x-ray might be the first imaging study conducted in this case if there were a reason to suspect a primary bone tumor or spinal stenosis.

Bone scintigraphy is commonly used for whole-body skeletal evaluation in cancer patients to identify asymptomatic sites of metastasis. Any patient with a history of cancer associated with either pure blastic (e.g., prostate cancer) or mixed lytic/blastic (e.g., some breast, testicular, and ovarian cancers) metastases should undergo a bone scan. This patient with a history of breast cancer will eventually require a bone scan to look for other sites of malignancy. However, the most appropriate next step in management involves further evaluation of her back pain and suspected vertebral metastases.

question_text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after sustaining a stab wound to the right chest. First responders found the patient sitting on the curb experiencing pain where he had been stabbed. On arrival at the hospital, he is alert. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows several 1–2 cm lacerations and ecchymoses over the face and trunk. There is no neck crepitus. A pocket knife is lodged in the fourth parasternal intercostal space and there is a small amount of blood oozing out of the wound. There is no bubbling of the blood at the wound. The lungs are clear to auscultation with equal breath sounds. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows the knife in situ extending into the right thorax. Both lungs appear normal; they are homogeneously aerated and have no abnormal opacities. Size and shape of the heart are within normal limits. No fractures or tracheal deviation are visible. Both hemidiaphragms and costophrenic angles are sharply demarcated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after sustaining a stab wound to the right chest. First responders found the patient sitting on the curb experiencing pain where he had been stabbed. On arrival at the hospital, he is alert. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows several 1–2 cm lacerations and ecchymoses over the face and trunk. There is no neck crepitus. A pocket knife is lodged in the fourth parasternal intercostal space and there is a small amount of blood oozing out of the wound. There is no bubbling of the blood at the wound. The lungs are clear to auscultation with equal breath sounds. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows the knife in situ extending into the right thorax. Both lungs appear normal; they are homogeneously aerated and have no abnormal opacities. Size and shape of the heart are within normal limits. No fractures or tracheal deviation are visible. Both hemidiaphragms and costophrenic angles are sharply demarcated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: Further diagnostic workup in a hemodynamically stable patient with penetrating chest trauma usually includes a CT scan of the chest and often echocardiography, ultrasonography, or angiography to better visualize intrathoracic structures. The knife that caused this patient's stab wound is still in situ.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in treatment for a patient with a stab wound to the chest and an impaled object.

answers.explanation_why: A needle thoracostomy is helpful in emergency treatment of patients with a tension pneumothorax, which can be caused by lung injury due to penetrating trauma. A patient with a tension pneumothorax will have hypotension, jugular vein distention, tracheal deviation, and absent breath sounds with hyperresonance to percussion on the ipsilateral side. This patient exhibits none of these features.

A tube thoracostomy is indicated in patients with hemothorax or pneumothorax. Hemothorax and pneumothorax result in decreased or absent breath sounds on the ipsilateral side with associated dullness and hyperresonance to percussion, respectively. This patient, however, has normal breath sounds bilaterally and chest x-ray shows homogeneously aerated lungs and sharply demarcated costophrenic angles.

answers.content: Surgical exploration in the operating room
answers.explanation_why: Impaled foreign bodies should be removed under direct visualization in the operating room. As the knife is still in situ, the exact extent of intrathoracic damage is unknown. Although this patient is currently hemodynamically stable, he could have sustained vascular damage that is masked by the knife tamponading the stab wound and preventing hemorrhage at this time. Upon removal of the knife, the patient could hemorrhage and rapidly deteriorate. Emergency surgery is indicated to remove the knife in an environment in which bleeding can be controlled. Therefore, this patient should undergo rapid sequence endotracheal intubation in anticipation of emergency surgery. In hemodynamically stable patients, some surgeons first use video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery to evaluate the situs and, if safe removal of the foreign body is not possible with this technique, proceed to open thoracotomy.

Cricothyroidotomy is used in patients who require emergency airway protection if other interventions have failed to secure the airways. The most common indication is laryngospasm, an obstruction that prevents less invasive airway management. While an emergency procedure is required to remove the in situ knife and manage the injuries, cricothyroidotomy is not the first choice for airway management in this patient because there is no evidence of laryngospasm (e.g., stridor, shortness of breath, tachypnea) and other interventions to secure the airways have not been attempted.

Emergency department thoracotomy (EDT) is a last resort for patients who have sustained life-threatening thoracic trauma and are at immediate risk for, or already in, cardiac arrest and for patients who require immediate hemostasis for exsanguinating vascular or cardiac injuries. EDT is primarily recommended for pulseless patients with signs of life (e.g., measurable blood pressure, spontaneous breathing) following penetrating thoracic trauma. This patient, however, is hemodynamically stable with only minor bleeding from his chest wound; therefore, there is no indication for resuscitative thoracotomy. Although this patient has sustained penetrating thoracic trauma and an emergency intervention is necessary, a different procedure should be performed in a different setting.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He feels well. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2766 g (6 lb 2 oz). He now weighs 14 kg (31 lb). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at 60th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard at the left upper sternal border and a grade 2/6 mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. S_2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He feels well. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2766 g (6 lb 2 oz). He now weighs 14 kg (31 lb). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at 60th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard at the left upper sternal border and a grade 2/6 mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with a congenital heart defect that may lead to paradoxical embolism and stroke if not surgically corrected.
learning_objective: Recognize an atrial septal defect.

answers.explanation_why: A patent ductus arteriosus is often discovered incidentally in asymptomatic children. However, cardiac auscultation would usually show a loud continuous machine-like murmur (due to the constant left-to-right shunt) that is best heard in the left infraclavicular region.

A systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border may be a benign flow murmur. While benign (innocent) systolic murmurs are a common finding in children, they are usually soft (grade ≤ 2). The patient's findings of a diastolic murmur and a fixed split S_2 are also not consistent with a benign murmur and warrant further investigation.

This child presents with typical auscultation findings of an atrial septal defect (ASD) with the fixed (no change with respiration), widely split S_2 being the most specific. Right ventricular volume overload due to the left-to-right shunt across the ASD causes a delayed closure of the pulmonary valve relative to the aortic valve. Since the right and left sides of the heart communicate, the pressure difference that normally exists during respiration evens out; therefore, the duration of the split does not change with inspiration or expiration. The increased blood flow through the right side of the heart also causes a pulmonary flow murmur, which explains the patient's systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. Some patients with ASD can also have a soft, mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border secondary to increased flow across the tricuspid valve.

While a mid-diastolic murmur may be appreciated in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) as a result of increased flow through the mitral valve, this murmur would usually be best heard at the cardiac apex (mitral area) rather than the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area). The classic auscultatory finding at the left lower sternal border in patients with a VSD would be a harsh holosystolic murmur.

Isolated pulmonary valve stenosis can cause a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a wide S_2 split but would not explain the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border or the fixed split in S_2 (i.e., no variation with respiration).

Coarctation of the aorta usually presents a systolic ejection murmur in the paravertebral region due to blood flow through the aortic narrowing. It would not explain the fixed split in S_2 or the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.
