question_text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the cardiologist because of sweating and respiratory distress while eating. She is at the 30^th percentile for height and 15^th percentile for weight. Echocardiography shows a defect in the membranous portion of the interventricular septum and a moderately decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. Physical examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the cardiologist because of sweating and respiratory distress while eating. She is at the 30th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Echocardiography shows a defect in the membranous portion of the interventricular septum and a moderately decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. Physical examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Examination findings for a symptomatic ventricular septal defect (VSD) in a patient this age will reflect shunting of blood from the left to right ventricle.
learning_objective: Recognize symptomatic ventricular septal defect (VSD), and recall the maneuvers that affect its murmur.

answers.content: Systolic murmur that increases with hand clenching
answers.explanation_why: Hand clenching increases systemic vascular resistance and afterload, which causes left-to-right shunting of blood and makes the systolic murmur in VSD more audible. Small VSDs may cause a loud systolic murmur with palpable thrill due to the large pressure differential between the left and right ventricles, while large VSDs are typically less obvious on auscultation. If left untreated, VSDs can lead to pulmonary hypertension and heart failure.

images.title: Heart murmur in ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation, and tricuspid regurgitation
images.description: Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

answers.content: Wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound
answers.explanation_why: A wide, fixed (i.e., does not change with respiration) splitting of the second heart sound is characteristic of atrial septal defect (ASD). It occurs due to right ventricular overload and subsequent delay in pulmonary valve closure. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is not a common feature of VSD.

answers.content: Systolic murmur that increases with forced exhalation against a closed glottis
answers.explanation_why: A systolic murmur that increases with forced exhalation against a closed glottis (Valsalva maneuver) is characteristic of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). The Valsalva maneuver reduces both preload and left ventricular afterload, which would exacerbate the subaortic stenosis in HOCM but reduce the left-to-right shunt of blood in VSD. The Valsalva maneuver would therefore decrease this patient's murmur intensity.

answers.content: Diastolic murmur preceded by opening snap
answers.explanation_why: A diastolic murmur preceded by an opening snap at the apex is characteristic of mitral stenosis (MS). The opening snap occurs when leaflet motion suddenly stops during diastole after the stenosed valve has opened fully. While a short, mid-diastolic murmur can sometimes be heard in VSD due to increased blood flow across the mitral valve, an opening snap would not be expected.

answers.content: Continuous murmur that is loudest at the second heart sound
answers.explanation_why: A continuous murmur that becomes louder at the second heart sound is characteristic of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The murmur is best appreciated in the left infraclavicular region and results from the constant flow of blood from the high pressure aorta to the low pressure pulmonary artery. VSD is characterized by a different finding on auscultation.

images.title: Heart murmur in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)

question_text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe epigastric pain and vomiting that started 30 minutes ago while gardening. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis and jugular venous distention. An ECG shows P waves independent of QRS complexes and ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Coronary angiography is most likely to show narrowing of which of the following vessels?
content_preview: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe epigastric pain and vomiting that started 30 minutes ago while gardening. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis and jugular venous distention. An ECG shows P waves independent of QRS complexes and ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Coronary angiography is most likely to show narrowing of which of the following vessels?
hint: Epigastric pain and vomiting, combined with ST segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF are consistent with an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Dissociated P waves and QRS complexes are indicative of third-degree atrioventricular block.
learning_objective: Recognize inferior wall myocardial infarction and its associated ECG changes, and recall the coronary artery anatomy.

answers.explanation_why: The left coronary artery (LCA) branches to the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and the left circumflex artery (LCX). Occlusion of the LCA can lead to a massive myocardial infarction involving a combination of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), apical (leads I, aVL, V3– V5), and posterolateral (leads II, III, aVF, and V5– V7, and sometimes lead I and aVL) walls. This patient's ECG is consistent with infarction of the inferior wall, which can be supplied by the distal LCX but is more commonly supplied by a different artery.

Occlusion of the proximal right coronary artery (RCA) can cause an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which in turn can present atypically with epigastric pain. High-degree atrioventricular block can occur in this setting because the sinoatrial node (SA node) and atrioventricular node (AV node) are usually supplied by the RCA (the SA node directly, and the AV node via the AV nodal branch). Right-sided leads (V4R, V5R, and V6R) should also be obtained to evaluate for right ventricular (RV) infarction (especially given the patient's jugular venous distention), as the RCA supplies the RV via its right marginal branch.

images.title: Illustration of the coronary arteries
images.description: This image shows the anatomical location of the coronary arteries from a ventral and dorsal view. The left and right coronary arteries arise from the aortic sinus and run along the corresponding coronary sinuses on the caudal side of the heart. The majority of the population has right-dominant coronary artery circulation.

answers.explanation_why: The left circumflex artery (LCX) supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle. Occlusion of the LCX causes ECG changes in the lateral (V5, V6, I, aVL) leads. In patients with left-dominant coronary circulation, occlusion of the LCX causes distal infarction of the posterior descending artery, leading to an inferior wall myocardial infarction and ECG changes in the posterior/posterolateral (V7–V9) and inferior (II, III, aVF) leads. However, the LCX is not the most likely source of this patient's inferior wall myocardial infarction because only approx. 10% of the population is left-dominant.

Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) causes infarction of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), and/or apical wall (leads I, aVL, and V3– V5). The inferior wall is not typically supplied by the LAD. Moreover, although an anteroseptal myocardial infarction can sometimes cause serious arrhythmias, such as a high-degree atrioventricular block (the LAD supplies the left and right bundle branches and partially supplies the left anterior and posterior fascicles), conduction abnormalities are more common following an inferior myocardial infarction.

Occlusion of the posterior interventricular artery would cause a posterior wall myocardial infarction, which would manifest as ST segment depression in leads V1 and V2, sometimes with prominent R waves. Posterior leads (V7– V9) would show ST segment elevation. Epigastric pain is not common in posterior wall myocardial infarctions, nor are conduction abnormalities, since the posterior interventricular artery does not supply the conduction system.

images.title: Posterior myocardial infarction
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Heart rate: ~ 83/min
– Sinus rhythm
– Normal axis (R > S in I and II)
– Downsloping ST depression in leads V_2 and V_3 and horizontal ST depression in V_4 (examples indicated by red overlay) is accompanied by positive T waves (examples indicated by blue overlay). This appearance is reciprocal to posterior ST elevations with T-wave inversions.
– Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V_2 (example indicated by green overlay): reciprocal to posterior Q waves
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): rSR′ complex in V_1 and QRS duration of 0.12 sThese findings suggest a posterior myocardial infarction. To confirm, an additional ECG including the posterior leads V7–V9 can be obtained to look for ST elevation, T-wave inversion, and Q waves. Note that ST depression ≥ 0.5 mm in leads V1–V4 is a STEMI-equivalent ECG finding (i.e., management is the same as that for STEMI).

question_text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father, who is concerned because his son has been less interested in playing soccer with him recently. They used to play every weekend, but his son has started to tire easily and has complained of pain in the lower legs while running around on the soccer field. The boy has no personal or family history of serious illness. Cardiac examination shows a systolic ejection murmur best heard over the left sternal border that radiates to the left paravertebral region. Chest x-rays show erosions of the posterior aspects of the 6^th to 8^th ribs. If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
content_preview: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father, who is concerned because his son has been less interested in playing soccer with him recently. They used to play every weekend, but his son has started to tire easily and has complained of pain in the lower legs while running around on the soccer field. The boy has no personal or family history of serious illness. Cardiac examination shows a systolic ejection murmur best heard over the left sternal border that radiates to the left paravertebral region. Chest x-rays show erosions of the posterior aspects of the 6th to 8th ribs. If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
hint: Intermittent leg pain on exertion (intermittent claudication) suggests lower extremity arterial insufficiency. The systolic ejection murmur described is likely due to aortic narrowing, and the erosions of the ribs suggest collateral circulation through the intercostal arteries (rib notching). Together, these findings indicate aortic coarctation.
learning_objective: Recognize aortic coarctation, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: An increased risk of intracranial hemorrhage is present in patients with untreated aortic coarctation because of brachiocephalic hypertension. Moreover, aortic coarctation is associated with intracranial aneurysm formation (due to hypertension and/or genetic risk factors), which increases the risk of hemorrhage due to aneurysm rupture. Other complications of aortic coarctation include aortic arch aneurysm and dissection, coronary artery disease, ischemic stroke, endocarditis, left ventricular hypertrophy, and heart failure.

Central cyanosis is seen in patients with congenital heart defects that lead to right-to-left shunting, such as tetralogy of Fallot and transposition of the great vessels. It is not typically seen in aortic coarctation, which is considered an acyanotic heart defect. Cyanotic heart defects usually become evident in the newborn period, often manifesting with acute, life-threatening episodes of cyanosis. If left untreated, most defects are fatal within the first year of life.

Paradoxical embolism is a possible complication of shunts that allow a thrombus to pass from venous to arterial circulation, such as patent foramen ovale and atrial septal defect (ASD). Since both of these conditions are usually asymptomatic, intermittent claudication would not be expected. Moreover, unlike this patient's murmur, ASD manifests with a mid-systolic pulmonary flow or ejection murmur accompanied by wide, fixed splitting of S_2.

Risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) include smoking, advanced age, atherosclerosis, and systemic arterial hypertension. Although aortic coarctation leads to brachiocephalic hypertension, the risk of AAA is not increased because blood flow in the vessels distal to the constriction at the aortic isthmus is actually decreased. Rather, increased blood flow proximal to the constriction increases the risk of dilation of the aortic arch (thoracic aorta). AAA is rare in children and when it occurs, it is usually due to an underlying connective tissue disease (e.g., Ehler-Danlos syndrome).

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction caused by aortic coarctation results in compensatory left ventricular hypertrophy and arterial hypertension, either of which can eventually result in left-sided heart failure. Although right-sided heart failure can occur secondary to left-sided heart failure, this patient is at a higher risk of a different complication.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S_2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The patient presents with lower extremity cyanosis and clubbing with preserved upper extremity oxygenation (a finding known as differential cyanosis) and symptoms of heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of a large patent ductus arteriosus, and recall the expected echocardiographic finding.

answers.content: Single overriding great vessel arising from the heart
answers.explanation_why: A single overriding great vessel is called a persistent truncus arteriosus. This single arterial trunk arising from the heart provides mixed blood to the pulmonary arteries and the systemic circulation. Pulses may be accentuated and bounding; however, oxygen saturation would be decreased in all extremities. Furthermore, if it is not diagnosed prenatally, it will typically present perinatally with symptoms of global cyanosis and heart failure, while this adolescent patient only has differential cyanosis.

answers.content: Anomalous shunting of blood through a defect in atrial septum
answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASD) are often asymptomatic. In adults, larger defects may lead to a distinct left-to-right shunt, which can result in right heart failure, supraventricular arrhythmias, and pulmonary hypertension, and ultimately lead to an Eisenmenger reaction and global cyanosis. Differential cyanosis would not be seen.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Persistent blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta
answers.explanation_why:
Failure of the ductus arteriosus to completely close postnatally allows blood to flow from the descending aorta back to the pulmonary artery (left-to-right shunt). In a large patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), this leads to volume overload of the right ventricle and the lung circuit. This increased blood flow causes pulmonary hypertension and irreversible remodeling of small pulmonary vessels, which may eventually lead to an Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal). This patient's palpable right parasternal heave and pronounced S_2 are evidence of increased right heart strain. In patients with a large PDA, the features of differential cyanosis occur once shunt reversal develops. Because the ductus is located on the descending aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery, reversal of the shunt results in deoxygenated blood reaching only the lower body. Due to the rise in pulmonary pressure, the characteristic continuous machine-like murmur heard in patients with PDA eventually disappears.

Infants with PDA usually receive an infusion of indomethacin to induce closure of the duct, while in older children symptomatic PDAs are typically closed surgically or via percutaneous catheter occlusion. The presence of an Eisenmenger reaction is, however, a contraindication to a PDA closure.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect
answers.explanation_why: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect is seen in tetralogy of Fallot. The other features of this cardiac abnormality are pulmonary stenosis and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is typically symptomatic in infancy and presents with tet spells and mild cyanosis in all extremities.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Abnormal narrowing of the aorta at the aortic isthmus
answers.explanation_why: Abnormal narrowing at the aortic isthmus is consistent with coarctation of the aorta (CoA), which would cause differential cyanosis if the CoA is severe (i.e., a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect) but this differential cyanosis would be evident from the neonatal period. In addition, patients with CoA have a brachio-femoral pulse delay rather than synchronous pulses. The symptoms of a mild CoA can begin later in life but in such a scenario, differential cyanosis would not be expected. Instead, patients present with features of brachiocephalic hypertension (e.g., headaches, epistaxis), lower extremity arterial insufficiency (manifesting with claudication and cool skin with faint or unpalpable pulses, but no cyanosis), and evidence of compensatory collateral arteries (e.g., continuous murmur over the back).

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

question_text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department after briefly losing consciousness and collapsing when rising from a chair. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has had a 2-week history of dizziness upon standing. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. He currently takes dutasteride and tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia. His blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. On cardiac auscultation, there is a plopping sound followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department after briefly losing consciousness and collapsing when rising from a chair. He did not sustain any injuries from his collapse. He has had a 2-week history of dizziness upon standing. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. He drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. He currently takes dutasteride and tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia. His blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. On cardiac auscultation, there is a plopping sound followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
hint: This patient presents with syncope, orthostatic hypotension (drop of ≥ 20 mm Hg in systolic pressure from supine to standing), and a diastolic murmur over the apex, all of which raise suspicion for an obstruction of blood flow into the left ventricle.
learning_objective: Recognize a cardiac tumor presenting with syncope and orthostatic hypotension.

answers.explanation_why: Stokes-Adams attacks are characterized by a sudden loss of consciousness, usually without warning and lasting for a few seconds. However, these episodes of fainting are caused by an abnormal heart rhythm (especially complete atrioventricular block) and not due to a mechanical obstruction of blood flow.

Aortic valve stenosis is the most common valvular heart disease and may manifest with dizziness and syncope. It should always be considered as a differential diagnosis in an older patient with a heart murmur, such as this one. The auscultatory finding in aortic valve stenosis is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur heard best over the 2^nd right intercostal space, which is inconsistent with this patient's rumbling diastolic murmur heard best at the apex.

Cardiac myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumor, commonly located in the left atrium. They may be pedunculated, in which case they often present with position-dependent symptoms of obstructed blood flow through the atrioventricular valves, or they may embolize. Additionally, patients may present with constitutional findings (e.g., weight loss, fever, or anemia). The typical auscultatory finding (also present in this patient) is an early diastolic “plop,” caused by a movement of the mobile tumor mass, followed by a mid-diastolic rumbling murmur best heard at the apex that results from the obstructed blood flow through the mitral valve, and mimics the murmur of mitral stenosis.

Various drugs can cause (orthostatic) hypotension and may lead to syncope, including alpha-1 blockers. This patient is taking an alpha-1 blocker and presents with orthostatic hypotension. However, among the alpha-1 blockers, tamsulosin is the agent with the lowest potential of inducing hypotension because of its increased selectivity for alpha-1 receptors of the bladder neck and the prostatic urethra. The peculiar heart murmur of a diastolic “plop” followed by a rumble suggests a different diagnosis.

Dilated cardiomyopathy is most commonly idiopathic but can also be alcohol-induced. It usually manifests with signs of heart failure. While this patient consumes critical levels of alcohol, and has symptoms that may suggest impaired pump function of the heart (syncope, hypotension), dilated cardiomyopathy does not manifest with a position-dependent diastolic heart murmur.

question_text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. The patient is confused. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a hand-sized hematoma on the anterior chest wall. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. The patient is confused. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a hand-sized hematoma on the anterior chest wall. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?
hint: This patient's presentation of shock (hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status) after severe blunt chest trauma in the setting of a motor vehicle accident is highly suggestive of blunt thoracic aortic injury.
learning_objective: Recognize injury to the aortic isthmus.

answers.explanation_why: Papillary muscle rupture is a notorious complication after a myocardial infarction and presents with acute hypotension, new-onset mitral regurgitation, and subsequent pulmonary edema. Rapid deceleration injury in a motor vehicle accident is not associated with papillary muscle rupture.

The aortic isthmus, a physiological narrowing at the final section of the aortic arch, is located just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery and is tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. It is the most common site of injury due to blunt aortic trauma because it is extremely vulnerable to rapid deceleration injury, which can occur in motor vehicle accidents when the chest smashes against the steering wheel or is abruptly restrained by the seatbelt.

Management aims to assess the severity of injury and includes a CT angiography in hemodynamically stable patients or a TEE if hemodynamically unstable.

In rare cases, rapid deceleration injury in the setting of a motor vehicle accident can lead to a large aortic tear that extends to the aortic valve. Nevertheless, this is not a common site of injury. Moreover, a diastolic murmur would be heard due to new-onset aortic regurgitation.

Injury to the inferior vena cava may occur in patients after blunt decelerating trauma, but it is extremely rare. Aside from that, the hematoma seen on the patient's chest would not be typical as injury to the inferior vena cava would likely result in retroperitoneal hematoma.

Although the coronary arteries may also be affected together with aortic injury, the absence of ST-segment abnormalities on this patient's ECG makes involvement of the left main coronary artery unlikely.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent nosebleeds and fatigue for the past 2 months. He also frequently complains his head hurts. The patient has met all motoric milestones for his age but does not like to run because his legs start to hurt if he does. He is at the 40^th percentile for both height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure in the right arm is 130/85 mm Hg. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent nosebleeds and fatigue for the past 2 months. He also frequently complains his head hurts. The patient has met all motoric milestones for his age but does not like to run because his legs start to hurt if he does. He is at the 40th percentile for both height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure in the right arm is 130/85 mm Hg. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's general fatigue, hypertension, low-grade systolic ejection murmur, lower-extremity claudication, headaches, and recurrent epistaxis together suggest coarctation of the aorta (CoA).
learning_objective: Recognize coarctation of the aorta, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Notching of the ribs, an x-ray finding in patients with coarctation of the aorta, results from compensatory collateral blood flow involving the intercostal vessels. Those vessels may dilate to bypass the left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Although this patient may eventually develop visible rib notching, it is generally a sign of chronic disease and usually does not become apparent in children before the age of 5 years.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.

answers.explanation_why: Interarm differences in tissue oxygenation and blood pressure can be a finding of coarctation of the aorta in the rare case that the narrowing is proximal to the left subclavian artery. In such patients, blood pressure in the right arm would be markedly higher than in the left arm and oxygen saturation would be lower in the left arm. However, coarctation of the aorta most commonly presents with differences in blood pressure between the upper and the lower extremities.

Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis is a characteristic feature of tetralogy of Fallot. A systolic ejection murmur can be present and is usually best heard at the left sternal border, rather than the left paravertebral region. Patients usually present with (mild) cyanosis and intermittent hypoxic episodes that improve with squatting, none of which are seen here. Coarctation of the aorta is characterized by an outflow obstruction of the left ventricle.

Left-axis deviation and increased R wave amplitude in V5–V6 on ECG are signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. While myocardial hypertrophy is one of the compensatory mechanisms to counter the aortic narrowing in patients with coarctation of the aorta, such as this 3-year-old boy, the changes in ECG vary with age and degree of stenosis, and it usually takes several years before the hypertrophy becomes apparent. In older children and adults, ECG may show signs of left ventricular hypertrophy in the left precordial leads (e.g., positive Sokolow-Lyon criteria).

In patients with CoA, delayed or even absent lower extremity pulses are expected distal to the stenotic portion of the aorta. Since the post-stenotic blood supply is limited, the resulting lower-extremity hypoxia becomes evident, especially during exertion, which is a strong sign of intermittent claudication, as in this patient.

Doppler echocardiography is the confirmatory test of choice and can identify the location and extent of the stenosis.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-week history of shortness of breath and dull chest pain. She has a history of antiphospholipid syndrome. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-week history of shortness of breath and dull chest pain. She has a history of antiphospholipid syndrome. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The presence of jugular venous distention suggests right heart failure, which can manifest with findings such as exertional shortness of breath and chest pain, as seen here. Antiphospholipid syndrome can cause pulmonary embolism, resulting in pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. A mean pulmonary artery pressure ≥ 25 mm Hg at rest confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension, and a normal PCWP (4–12 mm Hg) excludes left heart failure as the cause.
learning_objective: Recognize right heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension, and recall the expected echocardiographic finding.

answers.content: Constriction of the renal afferent arteriole
answers.explanation_why: In cases of systemic hypoperfusion, reduced renal perfusion results in dilatation of the afferent arteriole via myogenic autoregulation and the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism, as well as constriction of the efferent arteriole via an increase in angiotensin II synthesis. Afferent arteriole dilation and efferent arteriole constriction then work in combination to maintain a constant GFR despite decreased cardiac output. Right heart failure is a condition that can cause systemic hypoperfusion. For this reason dilatation (not constriction) of the renal afferent arteriole would rather be expected in this patient.

Right heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension involves increased afterload of the right ventricle, resulting in reduced right ventricular output. Reduced right-sided cardiac output leads to venous congestion in the vessels that drain into the right heart, including the coronary sinus, which can become dilated as a result.

images.title: Coronary veins
images.description:
The coronary sinus is the largest vein of the heart. It lies in the left posterior atrioventricular groove and opens into the right atrium.

Main tributaries of the coronary sinus:
- Great cardiac vein: lies in the left anterior atrioventricular groove; receives the anterior interventricular vein that begins at the cardiac apex
- Small cardiac vein: lies in the right posterior atrioventricular groove; receives the right marginal vein and the anterior veins of the right ventricle
- Middle cardiac vein: lies in the posterior interventricular groove
- Posterior vein(s) of the left ventricle: lies to the left of the middle cardiac vein

answers.explanation_why: Decreased left ventricular contractility is the hallmark of systolic left heart failure. Although left heart failure can lead to right heart failure, PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure (> 18 mm Hg). This patient's normal PCWP makes left heart failure unlikely.

Mitral valve leaflet thickening can occur in mitral valve diseases such as mitral stenosis (e.g., due to rheumatic fever). Mitral valve disease usually results in increased left atrial pressure and therefore increased PCWP, whereas PCWP is normal in this patient.

Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (heart failure cells) are typically seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary congestion due to blood leakage into the alveolar spaces. Conditions that cause chronic pulmonary venous congestion include left heart failure and mitral stenosis. PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure and mitral stenosis, whereas it is normal in this patient.

images.title: Heart failure cells in decompensated heart failure
images.description: Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)Accumulations of hemosiderin-laden macrophages, known as siderophages (examples indicated by blue overlay), are visible within alveoli. Additionally, alveoli filled with erythrocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen.Siderophages in pulmonary alveoli (heart failure cells) suggest decompensated heart failure.

question_text:
A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of chills and worsening shortness of breath. He has no history of serious illness and does not use illicit drugs. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m^2. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/60 mm Hg. There is no jugular venous distention. Examination of the extremities shows several nontender, nonblanching, erythematous macules on the palms and soles and painful nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes. Coarse crackles are heard over both lungs. Cardiac examination is shown. Results of initial blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation findings?
Video
content_preview: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of chills and worsening shortness of breath. He has no history of serious illness and does not use illicit drugs. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/60 mm Hg. There is no jugular venous distention. Examination of the extremities shows several nontender, nonblanching, erythematous macules on the palms and soles and painful nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes. Coarse crackles are heard over both lungs. Cardiac examination is shown. Results of initial blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation findings? Video
hint: The presence of Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and features of left heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema) indicate left-sided infective endocarditis (IE). The sound that coincides with the upstroke of carotid pulsation is S_1. There is a murmur that is heard shortly after the carotid pulse, which is consistent with diastolic timing. With a decrescendo early diastolic murmur, S_2 cannot be distinguished from the murmur on auscultation.
learning_objective: Recognize aortic regurgitation in infective endocarditis.

answers.explanation_why: IE is typically associated with valvular regurgitation. This patient's murmur is loudest at the left sternal border near Erb point (cardiology). The murmur's characteristics and location make aortic regurgitation (AR) due to valvular disease the most likely diagnosis. Other causes of AR include a congenital bicuspid aortic valve, rheumatic fever, and aortic root dilation due to connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). In contrast to AR due to valvular disease, the murmur of AR secondary to aortic root disease is heard best over the right upper sternal border (aortic area). In patients with AR, a high pulse pressure (due to increased end-diastolic volume and a subsequent increase in stroke volume) is a common finding.

images.title: Heart murmur in aortic and pulmonary insufficiency
images.description: Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

answers.explanation_why: Aortic stenosis (AS) can cause left heart failure but would result in low pulse pressure. Moreover, the characteristic murmur of AS is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best over the right 2^nd intercostal space (aortic area) with radiation to the carotids. Furthermore, IE is typically associated with valvular regurgitation rather than valvular stenosis.

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) can cause left heart failure and is a risk factor for as well as a complication of IE. However, a high pulse pressure is not caused by MVP. Typical cardiac auscultatory findings in MVP would include a midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the cardiac apex (left 5^th intercostal space in the midclavicular line).

images.title: Heart murmur in mitral valve prolapse
images.description: High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

answers.explanation_why: Mitral regurgitation (MR) is the most common valvular disease associated with IE and can manifest with left heart failure. However, MR manifests with a holosystolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex (left 5^th intercostal space in the midclavicular line) and does not cause a high pulse pressure.

The murmur of pulmonary stenosis (PS) is heard best parasternally at the left 2^nd intercostal space but this condition would manifest with features of right heart failure (e.g., jugular venous distention) and the typical murmur of PS is an ejection systolic murmur, often with a widely split S_2. Moreover, PS is usually a congenital heart defect. Acquired PS is rare and occurs in patients with carcinoid syndrome or rheumatic heart disease. IE is typically associated with valvular regurgitation rather than valvular stenosis.

images.title: Heart murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis
images.description: A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

answers.explanation_why: Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) can be caused by IE and the murmur of TR is loudest parasternally at the left 4^th intercostal space. However, TR due to IE occurs in patients with a history of intravenous drug use and would manifest with features of right heart failure (e.g., jugular venous distention). Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and pulmonary edema would not be expected with right-sided IE. Moreover, the typical murmur of TR is a holosystolic murmur.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy with a history of recurrent respiratory infections is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. His height and weight are both at the 20^th percentile. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Cardiac auscultation shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border and a diastolic rumble heard best at the apex. If left untreated, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy with a history of recurrent respiratory infections is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. His height and weight are both at the 20th percentile. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Cardiac auscultation shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border and a diastolic rumble heard best at the apex. If left untreated, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
hint: The presence of a holosystolic murmur (indicating flow through the defect) and a diastolic rumble (increased flow through the mitral valve during diastole) suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common type of congenital heart defect. VSDs are associated with frequent respiratory infections secondary to congestion of the pulmonary vessels.
learning_objective: Recognize ventricular septal defect (VSD), and recall its long-term complications.

answers.explanation_why: Congenital heart defects associated with an increased risk of myocardial ischemia are typically those that involve coronary artery abnormalities (e.g., anomalous course or origin, involving fistulas) or result in decreased coronary perfusion (e.g., in a large PDA, the retrograde blood flow to the left ventricle can decrease diastolic pressure in the proximal aorta and thereby decrease coronary perfusion). Although a long-standing, uncorrected VSD can also lead to decreased blood pressure, there is no evidence that it increases the risk of myocardial ischemia.

Acyanotic heart defects, such as VSDs, are not a known cause of increased platelet counts. A long-standing, uncorrected VSD will eventually result in Eisenmenger syndrome with subsequent shunt reversal. In this case, thrombocytopenia, not thrombocytosis may occur. Thrombocytopenia due to Eisenmenger syndrome is thought to result from megakaryocytes bypassing the pulmonary vasculature where they would normally be fragmented into platelets.

Secondary hypertension can result from congenital heart defects such as coarctation of the aorta. All aortic branches proximal to the coarctation receive increased blood flow, ultimately resulting in intimal-medial thickening and increased vascular stiffness. In a 2-year-old child, symptomatic coarctation would most likely present with chest pain, cold feet, and lower-extremity claudication on physical exertion, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, auscultation would reveal a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region and/or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades.

Aortic dissection is a dangerous complication of untreated coarctation of the aorta in adults. Chronic hypertension proximal to the area of coarctation increases intraluminal pressure and subsequently weakens the arterial wall, potentially resulting in aortic dissection. Symptomatic coarctation in a 2-year-old child would most likely present with chest pain, cold feet, and lower-extremity claudication on physical exertion, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, auscultation would reveal a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region and/or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades.

Digital clubbing is a sign of chronic hypoxemia, which is a complication of an untreated VSD. VSDs are acyanotic congenital heart defects that manifest as a left-to-right shunt. An untreated VSD can lead to chronic volume overload of the right ventricle (RV) and subsequently increased blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature. This increased flow causes irreversible remodeling of the small pulmonary vessels, leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and RV hypertrophy. RV pressure increases until it exceeds left ventricular (LV) pressure, at which point the shunt is reversed. This shunt reversal is known as Eisenmenger syndrome. Cyanosis and consequently, chronic tissue hypoxia, leads to the development of digital clubbing.

Chronic tissue hypoxia and megakaryocyte fragmentation are primary factors involved in the pathogenesis of digital clubbing. In Eisenmenger syndrome, blood can completely bypass the pulmonary vasculature, allowing whole megakaryocytes into the systemic circulation. Once these intact cells reach distal capillaries in the hands and feet, they impact and subsequently fragment. This fragmentation causes the release of platelet-derived growth factor and vascular endothelial growth factor, inducing angiogenesis and local mesenchymal growth and proliferation, which clinically manifests as digital clubbing.

images.title: Nail clubbing
images.description: There is enlargement of the distal phalanges, and the nail curvatures are increased.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) can result from a variety of conditions, including advanced left heart failure. In individuals with low cardiac output, advanced left heart failure may lead to decreased renal perfusion, decreased venous congestion, and eventually CKD. Chronic, untreated VSD, which is seen in this patient, causes constant volume overload of the right ventricle (RV) and subsequent RV damage. Advanced stages of RV failure manifest with hepatomegaly and peripheral edema.

question_text: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, he has bluish discoloration of his lips and fingernails. Oxygen saturation on room air is 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A continuous machine-like murmur is heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. Echocardiography shows the pulmonary artery arising from the posterior left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle with active blood flow between the right and left ventricles. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, he has bluish discoloration of his lips and fingernails. Oxygen saturation on room air is 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A continuous machine-like murmur is heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. Echocardiography shows the pulmonary artery arising from the posterior left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle with active blood flow between the right and left ventricles. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Echocardiography showing a pulmonary artery arising from the left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle confirms the diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA) which is an important cause of neonatal cyanosis that will not improve with supplemental oxygen. The continuous machine-like murmur indicates a coexistent patent ductus arteriosus, which is critical for life, as it allows mixing of oxygenated blood and its entry into the systemic circulation. Patients may also have coexistent arterial or ventricular septal defects that allow mixing of blood between the two circuits.
learning_objective: Recognize transposition of the great arteries, and recall the maternal condition associated with its development.

answers.explanation_why: Prenatal lithium intake is associated with Ebstein anomaly, which can have a wide range of clinical presentations, including congenital cyanosis from right-to-left shunting. Depending on the severity of the anomaly, the patient may have a holosystolic murmur (due to tricuspid regurgitation), as heard in this patient. However, echocardiography would show right-sided cardiomegaly with apical displacement of the tricuspid valve and tricuspid regurgitation, not the TGA seen in this patient.
Elevated serum TSH levels suggest hypothyroidism. Subclinical maternal hypothyroidism may increase the risk for future cognitive impairment, but it is not associated with TGA.

Prenatal alcohol consumption can cause fetal alcohol spectrum disorder. FASD can present with a wide range of cardiac abnormalities, including atrial septal defect, VSD, and great heart vessel defects. However, structural heart defects would also usually present with other more characteristic FASD findings, such as facial abnormalities (short palpebral fissures, thin vermillion border, smooth philtrum) and growth retardation.

Prenatal phenytoin intake is associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome. Although cases of congenital heart defects have been reported with maternal phenytoin use, transposition of the great arteries is rare. Furthermore, fetal hydantoin syndrome also presents with nail hypoplasia, hypoplasia of the digits, and abnormal facial features, which are all absent in this patient.

A positive rapid plasma reagin test suggests maternal syphilis, which can infect the infant in utero. Most cases of early congenital syphilis are asymptomatic at birth and do not develop symptoms until 5 weeks of life. If symptomatic at birth, findings include hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, nasal discharge, generalized lymphadenopathy, skeletal abnormalities, and/or and pemphigus syphiliticus, none of which are present in this infant. Transposition of the great arteries is not associated with congenital syphilis.

TGA is a cyanotic heart condition that is associated with maternal diabetes, caused by abnormal rotation of the pulmonary artery and aorta during fetal development. Mothers with untreated diabetes will have elevated fasting blood glucose levels. Other potential neonatal complications from maternal diabetes include fetal macrosomia (seen in this patient), polycythemia, hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

images.title: Transposition of the great vessels (TGV)
images.description: TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.

question_text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
hint: The boot-shaped heart on this boy's x-ray is caused by right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). His harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border is caused by pulmonary stenosis. These findings, along with his acute hypoxic spells (which cause cyanosis), indicate a diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
learning_objective: Recognize right ventricular outflow obstruction.

answers.content: Persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: A persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery characterizes a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), an acyanotic heart defect that can cause cyanosis if Eisenmenger syndrome develops. However, patients with a PDA and Eisenmenger syndrome typically develop differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Additionally, PDA causes a continuous, machine-like murmur heard throughout systole and diastole (unlike this patient's systolic murmur), and chest x-ray shows a prominent mediastinum caused by an enlarged pulmonary artery and aortic knob (not a boot-shaped heart).

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Hypoplasia of the left ventricle is caused by hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), a heart condition that is typically acyanotic in the early postnatal period because a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) ensures systemic perfusion. Cyanosis develops when the PDA closes, usually within a few days of birth (not as late as 3 months as in this case). Neonates with HLHS also have weak peripheral pulses, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis as the hypoplastic left ventricle cannot maintain adequate cardiac output. Additionally, HLHS does not cause a murmur, and findings on chest x-ray are variable (e.g., small, normal, or enlarged heart and increased pulmonary venous markings) but do not include a boot-shaped heart.

answers.content: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch
answers.explanation_why: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch, or coarctation of the aorta, manifests variably depending on the degree of aortic stenosis (AS) and the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Patients with significant AS and PDA present with differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Once the PDA closes (usually within a few days after birth), heart failure develops and manifests as dyspnea, sweating during feeds, and poor weight gain. Examination shows pallor (rather than cyanosis), features of inadequate left ventricular output (absent or weak femoral pulses, brachio-femoral delay), and signs of right heart failure (e.g., raised jugular venous pressure, edema, and hepatomegaly). Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary venous markings, not a boot-shaped heart.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

answers.explanation_why:
Right ventricular outflow obstruction (RVOO) in this patient is caused by pulmonary stenosis, which is one of the components of TOF, along with RVH, an overriding aorta, and a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Exertion, such as crying or feeding, increases the RVOO. This results in cyanosis (tet spells) due to right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood through the VSD instead of the pulmonary valve, which in turn causes the murmur to become softer. The right ventricle hypertrophies because it chronically pumps against high resistance caused by the RVOO.

Older children with TOF tend to squat during a tet spell. Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance, which increases left ventricular pressure and decreases the right-to-left shunting of blood through the VSD. Infants who are having a tet spell should be placed with their knees toward their chest to achieve the same effect.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Anatomic reversal of aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: Anatomic reversal of the aorta and pulmonary artery is known as transposition of the great vessels (TGV). This condition causes cyanosis because the aorta arises from the right ventricle and thus results in systemic circulation of deoxygenated blood. However, unlike this patient, cyanosis in TGV manifests immediately after birth. Additionally, chest x-ray in TGV shows an egg-on-a-string appearance due to an enlarged heart with a narrowed mediastinum, which resembles an egg lying on its side.

images.title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
images.description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

answers.explanation_why: Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) in infants is usually due to a malformed and displaced tricuspid valve in Ebstein anomaly. These infants may develop cyanosis only if there's an associated ASD or PFO that allows for right-to-left shunting of blood. Auscultation would reveal a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, like in this patient, with a widely split S2. However, a chest x-ray in Ebstein anomaly will show right atrial enlargement (due to chronic reflux of blood from the right ventricle into the right atrium) - not a boot-shaped heart as seen in this infant.

images.title: Ebstein anomaly
images.description: In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

images.title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of FallotThe cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 10 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest just below the clavicle. On arrival, he is hypotensive with rapid and shallow breathing and appears anxious and agitated. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Five minutes later, his pulse is 137/min and blood pressure is 84/47 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4^th intercostal space at the midclavicular line without active external bleeding. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 10 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest just below the clavicle. On arrival, he is hypotensive with rapid and shallow breathing and appears anxious and agitated. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Five minutes later, his pulse is 137/min and blood pressure is 84/47 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line without active external bleeding. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck's triad) indicate that this patient likely has cardiac tamponade.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiac tamponade, and recall its diagnostic finding.

answers.content: A 15 mm Hg decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration
answers.explanation_why: A > 10 mm Hg drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration is known as pulsus paradoxus, and is a sign observed in pathologies such as severe asthma, tension pneumothorax, constrictive pericarditis, and moderate and severe cardiac tamponade. In cardiac tamponade, the outward expansion of the right ventricle is limited, especially as blood flows during inspiration. This effect causes the interventricular septum to bulge into the left ventricle and together with a reduction in left ventricular filling causes a decrease in stroke volume as well as a subsequent drop in blood pressure.

Hemoptysis can occur in conditions such as tuberculosis and pulmonary contusion. Although this patient exhibits some features consistent with pulmonary contusion (tachycardia, rapid breathing), this condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention. Also, the nature of his trauma makes this diagnosis unlikely.

answers.content: Lateral shift of the trachea toward the right side
answers.explanation_why: Tracheal deviation toward the contralateral side of a lesion indicates a tension pneumothorax. Although tension pneumothorax can also be caused by penetrating chest trauma, and the patient has some features of this condition, such as tachycardia, hypotension, and jugular venous distention, he does not have the key finding of reduced/absent breath sounds on the side of the lesion.

answers.content: Subcutaneous crepitus on palpation of the chest wall
answers.explanation_why: Subcutaneous emphysema or crepitus on palpation of the chest wall suggests either bronchial rupture, esophageal rupture, or pneumothorax, which also may be caused by penetrating trauma. None of these conditions cause muffled heart sounds.

answers.content: Inward collapse of part of the chest with inspiration
answers.explanation_why: Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing such as inward collapse with inspiration, suggests flail chest, which is usually caused by severe blunt thoracic trauma rather than penetrating chest trauma. Although this patient has shallow breathing, which can be a feature of flail chest, the condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention. Also, it is unlikely that a single stab wound would cause several rib fractures.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

question_text: Seventy-two hours after admission for an acute myocardial infarction, a 48-year-old man develops dyspnea and a productive cough with frothy sputum. Physical examination shows coarse crackles in both lungs and a blowing, holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex. ECG shows Q waves in the anteroseptal leads. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is 23 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
content_preview: Seventy-two hours after admission for an acute myocardial infarction, a 48-year-old man develops dyspnea and a productive cough with frothy sputum. Physical examination shows coarse crackles in both lungs and a blowing, holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex. ECG shows Q waves in the anteroseptal leads. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is 23 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
hint: This patient's new murmur (blowing, holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex) and evidence of heart failure (dyspnea, bilateral crackles, elevated capillary wedge pressure) suggest acute mitral regurgitation.
learning_objective: Recognize rupture of the chordae tendinae post-myocardial infarction.

answers.explanation_why: Postmyocardial infarction syndrome is a type of pericarditis that arises from an autoimmune reaction to exposed myocardial antigens after acute MI. Patients present with dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, this syndrome would manifest 2–10 weeks after an MI rather than 72 hours as seen in this patient. Furthermore, fever is usually present, cardiac auscultation would reveal a pericardial friction rub, and ECG would show ST elevations in all leads.

Aortic root dilation can occur in postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis, which commonly manifests 1–3 days after MI. Patients with aortic root dilation present with features of aortic regurgitation. These patients have diastolic, not systolic, murmurs. Moreover, this patient is missing other symptoms of pericarditis, such as chest pain and a friction rub.

Chordae tendinae or papillary muscle rupture most commonly occurs 2–7 days after acute myocardial infarction and is due to extensive coagulative necrosis and the formation of granulation tissue at the area of infarction. This patient's localization of Q waves in the anteroseptal leads (e.g., V1–V4) suggests an infarction of the left anterior descending artery, which supplies the anterolateral papillary muscle. Acute mitral regurgitation can lead to signs of heart failure, as seen in this patient. The posteromedial papillary muscle is supplied only by the posterior descending artery and is at especially high risk of ischemia due to lack of collateral supply.

images.title: Timeline of most common post myocardial infarction complications

answers.content: Rupture of the ventricular free wall
answers.explanation_why: Ventricular wall rupture can occur within 2 weeks of myocardial infarction and typically results in hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade, which can manifest with profound right heart failure, shock, and often death. While free wall rupture and cardiac tamponade can also cause acute pulmonary edema, additional expected findings would include pulsus paradoxus and muffled heart sounds, none of which is observed in this patient.

Rupture of the interventricular septum may occur within the first 2 weeks after MI and typically presents with sudden hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia), dyspnea, and new-onset holosystolic murmur. However, because blood is shunted from left to right, patients typically present with signs of right heart failure (e.g., increased JVP, peripheral edema) rather than the signs of isolated left heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, elevated PCWP) seen here. Moreover, the expected murmur would be heard best over the left sternal border, not the apex.

question_text:
A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the physician because of worsening feeding difficulty since birth. Examination shows a grade 2/6 harsh holosystolic murmur, heard most clearly at the left lower sternal border, and a soft mid-diastolic rumble over the cardiac apex. Echocardiography shows shunting of blood through the ventricular septum during systole. The patient undergoes surgery for closure of the defect. Which of the following sets of changes are expected after successful repair of this cardiac defect?

Left atrial pressure
Left ventricular pressure
Right ventricular pressure

A
↓
↑
no change

B
↓
↑
↓

C
↑
↑
↑

D
↓
↓
↓

E
↑
↑
↓
content_preview: A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the physician because of worsening feeding difficulty since birth. Examination shows a grade 2/6 harsh holosystolic murmur, heard most clearly at the left lower sternal border, and a soft mid-diastolic rumble over the cardiac apex. Echocardiography shows shunting of blood through the ventricular septum during systole. The patient undergoes surgery for closure of the defect. Which of the following sets of changes are expected after successful repair of this cardiac defect? Left atrial pressure Left ventricular pressure Right ventricular pressure A ↓ ↑ no change B ↓ ↑ ↓ C ↑ ↑ ↑ D ↓ ↓ ↓ E ↑ ↑ ↓
hint: The newborn presented with symptoms of decreased cardiac output (poor feeding) and heart murmurs; he was found to have a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which allowed for abnormal shunting of blood from the left to the right ventricle. Successful repair of this defect will restore normal cardiac output.
learning_objective: Recall the cardiac pressure changes that would occur after successful repair of a ventricular septal defect.

answers.explanation_why: Mitral stenosis (MS) causes a left atrial outflow obstruction. The left atrium has to contract against the partially closed mitral valve, which results in an increased left atrial pressure. Once repaired, left atrial outflow increases, thereby decreasing the left atrial pressure. The left ventricular input increases, thereby increasing the left ventricular pressure. The right ventricular pressure remains unchanged. These hemodynamic changes would not, however, be expected after the closure of a VSD.

A VSD causes left-to-right shunting of blood because the left ventricular pressure is physiologically higher than the right ventricular pressure due to the thicker ventricular wall and higher force of contraction. Closure of a VSD would, therefore, increase the amount of blood in the left ventricle and decrease the amount of blood in the right ventricle during each cardiac cycle. This results in an increase in left ventricular pressure and a decrease in right ventricular pressure as well as right ventricular output, which translates to a decrease in the amount of blood flowing into the left atrium and therefore a decrease in left atrial pressure.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: An increase in the pressure of all the chambers of the heart would be expected following fluid resuscitation in patients with hypovolemic shock. These hemodynamic changes would not be expected after the closure of a VSD.

A decrease in the pressure in all the chambers of the heart would be expected following pericardiotomy for constrictive pericarditis or following aspiration of a hemopericardium. These hemodynamic changes would not be expected after the closure of a VSD.

Both atrial septal defect repair, which stops shunting of blood from the left atrium to the right atrium, and pulmonary stenosis repair, which removes the right ventricular outflow obstruction, would decrease right ventricular pressure and increase left atrial as well as left ventricular pressure by increasing the amount of blood in the left side of the heart. These hemodynamic changes would not, however, be expected after the closure of a VSD.
