question_text: A 71-year-old man with hypertension is taken to the emergency department after the sudden onset of stabbing abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His pulse is 120/min and thready, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a periumbilical, pulsatile mass and abdominal bruit. There is epigastric tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 71-year-old man with hypertension is taken to the emergency department after the sudden onset of stabbing abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His pulse is 120/min and thready, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a periumbilical, pulsatile mass and abdominal bruit. There is epigastric tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
hint: Abdominal pain radiating to the back, a pulsatile abdominal mass, and new-onset hypotension in a man with a history of smoking and hypertension should raise concerns for a certain pathology.
learning_objective: Recognize a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Coronary atherosclerosis resulting in narrowing of the vessel lumen is involved in the pathophysiology of angina pectoris and myocardial infarction (MI). Coronary atherosclerosis leads to narrowing of the arterial lumen, which decreases the blood flow to the myocardium. During exercise, myocardial flow is unable to meet increased myocardial demand, which causes myocardial ischemia and symptoms of angina. While smoking increases the risk for MI, this man's history of acute onset, stabbing abdominal pain with an umbilical mass and hypotension suggest a different disease process.

This patient most likely has a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The pathophysiology of AAA is not fully understood, but numerous genetic and environmental factors, such as smoking, are believed to cause inflammation and proteolysis of connective tissue within the aortic wall. This leads to loss of structural integrity and weakening of the aorta. Other risk factors for AAA include advanced age and male sex. When high aortic wall stress is applied, as in hypertension, further weakening, widening, and rupture of the aortic wall can occur. AAAs are most commonly located below the renal arteries (infrarenal).

images.title: Ruptured aortic aneurysm
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; arterial phase; axial plane)An infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm is measured as 8 cm in transverse diameter. Contrast extravasation (dashed outline) is seen on the left side at the site of rupture (arrowhead). A large left retroperitoneal hematoma (yellow overlay) extends inferiorly into the inguinal canal. Additional intraperitoneal fluid is seen in the pelvis and right upper quadrant (red overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Mesenteric atherosclerosis is involved in the pathophysiology of chronic mesenteric ischemia, in which intestinal blood flow is reduced. In the postprandial period, there is a mismatch between low splanchnic blood flow and high intestinal metabolic demand, which leads to postprandial ischemia and abdominal pain within one hour of eating. Bloating, nausea, and weight loss due to food aversion are common symptoms. This patient has acute-onset, stabbing abdominal pain with an umbilical mass and hypotension, features that suggest a different, more emergent disease process.

Gastric mucosal ulceration is involved in the pathophysiology of peptic ulcer disease. One of the complications of this disease is gastric or duodenal perforation, which manifests with sudden onset, stabbing abdominal pain, and distention that can progress to peritonitis. This patient's periumbilical mass, abdominal bruit, and hypotension are inconsistent with a perforated duodenal or gastric ulcer.

Abdominal wall defects can predispose patients to hernia formation. Uncomplicated hernias are typically asymptomatic and occur when intraabdominal contents protrude through congenital defects or areas of weakness in the abdominal wall. Complicated hernias include incarcerated hernias (irreducible), strangulated hernias (disrupted blood supply), or obstructed hernias (kinked intestine), and typically manifest with acute pain at the site of the hernia and possible bowel obstruction. Although this patient has a periumbilical mass, he also has an abdominal bruit and hypotension, suggesting a different etiology for his symptoms.

Portal vein stasis predisposes patients to the formation of acute portal vein thrombosis, which manifests with right upper quadrant or generalized abdominal pain. Portal vein thrombosis often arises as a complication of cirrhosis, but this patient lacks symptoms of chronic liver disease (jaundice, pruritus, hepatosplenomegaly, telangiectasias, caput medusae, gynecomastia). Furthermore, this patient's periumbilical mass and abdominal bruit suggest a different cause for his symptoms.

question_text: A 72-year-old man with coronary artery disease comes to the emergency department because of chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 3 hours. Troponin levels are elevated and an ECG shows ST-elevations in the precordial leads. Revascularization with percutaneous coronary intervention is performed, and a stent is successfully placed in the left anterior descending artery. Two days later, he complains of worsening shortness of breath. Pulse oximetry on 3L of nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. An x-ray of the chest shows distended pulmonary veins, small horizontal lines at the lung bases, and blunting of the costophrenic angles bilaterally. Which of the following findings would be most likely on a ventilation-perfusion scan of this patient?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man with coronary artery disease comes to the emergency department because of chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 3 hours. Troponin levels are elevated and an ECG shows ST-elevations in the precordial leads. Revascularization with percutaneous coronary intervention is performed, and a stent is successfully placed in the left anterior descending artery. Two days later, he complains of worsening shortness of breath. Pulse oximetry on 3L of nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. An x-ray of the chest shows distended pulmonary veins, small horizontal lines at the lung bases, and blunting of the costophrenic angles bilaterally. Which of the following findings would be most likely on a ventilation-perfusion scan of this patient?
hint: The combination of a recent myocardial infarction, worsening dyspnea, and chest x-ray findings showing pulmonary vein congestion, Kerley B lines, and pleural effusions should raise suspicion for cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and recall its ventilation-perfusion scan findings.

answers.content: Increased apical ventilation with normal perfusion bilaterally
answers.explanation_why: A high apical ventilation-perfusion ratio is a physiologic finding in healthy lungs under resting conditions. At baseline, the lung apices receive less perfusion due to gravity, resulting in a V/Q ratio of around 3 in those areas. In situations of high oxygen demand (e.g., physical exercise), apical perfusion can be increased. This patient, however, shows signs of pulmonary edema.

answers.content: Normal ventilation with multiple, bilateral perfusion defects
answers.explanation_why: The pattern of normal ventilation with multiple perfusion defects can be seen in patients with pulmonary emboli. Blood clots obstruct lung arteries and subsequently cause decreased perfusion. As there is no airway obstruction, ventilation is maintained. This patient's dyspnea could indicate pulmonary embolism. However, his x-ray findings and the history of a recent myocardial infarction suggests pulmonary edema.

A matched ventilation-perfusion ratio bilaterally (e.g., V/Q = 1) can be seen with either decrease in both ventilation and perfusion or increase in both ventilation and perfusion. Bilateral increase in V/Q can be seen with exercise, during which there is physiologic vasodilation of the apical capillaries, resulting in increased perfusion of the apices with matched ventilation. A bilateral decrease in both ventilation and perfusion can be seen in patients with emphysema due to the destruction of both the alveoli and the capillary bed. Other possibilities include the combination of two separate conditions, of which one causes alveolar hypoventilation (e.g., opioid intoxication) and the other causes pulmonary hypoperfusion (e.g., right-sided heart failure, severe hypotension). This patient shows signs of pulmonary edema, which would present with different findings.

answers.content: Normal perfusion with bilateral ventilation defects
answers.explanation_why:
Areas with normal perfusion and no ventilation (ventilation-perfusion mismatch) are seen in patients with pulmonary edema. Elevated pulmonary venous pressures (secondary to decreased left ventricular function) results in increased amounts of intra-alveolar fluid, which leads to impaired alveolar ventilation. Insufficiently oxygenated blood from parts of the lungs that are not ventilated mixes with oxygenated blood from ventilated parts of the lungs, resulting in an overall decrease in PaO_2, increased A-a gradient, and systemic hypoxemia.

Other conditions that can result in ventilation-perfusion mismatch include pneumonia (impaired ventilation) and pulmonary embolism (impaired perfusion).

images.title: Ventilation/perfusion mismatch (V/Q mismatch)
images.description: Pathologic lung conditions can alter V/Q ratios.Decreased ventilation leads to shunt perfusion (wasted perfusion) and a low V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no ventilation left (V = 0), V/Q ratio equals zero.Decreased perfusion leads to dead space ventilation (wasted ventilation) and a high V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no perfusion left (Q = 0), V/Q ratio equals infinity.

answers.content: Normal perfusion with decreased ventilation at the right base
answers.explanation_why: Normal perfusion with focal areas of decreased ventilation can be caused by localized inflammatory processes, such as pneumonia, bronchial obstruction, or malignancy. Patients with pneumonia have increased intra-alveolar fluid in some parts of the lungs, causing a decreased ventilation of those areas. This patient's dyspnea could be a sign of pneumonia but his x-ray findings and the history of a recent myocardial infarction suggest pulmonary edema.

question_text: Six days after falling in the shower, a 75-year-old man with COPD is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows dullness to percussion and decreased fremitus over the left lung base. There are faint expiratory wheezes throughout the lungs. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
content_preview: Six days after falling in the shower, a 75-year-old man with COPD is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 115/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows dullness to percussion and decreased fremitus over the left lung base. There are faint expiratory wheezes throughout the lungs. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
hint: The chest x-ray shows a left-sided opacity, blunting of the costophrenic angles, and mild tracheal deviation to the right.
learning_objective: Recognize hemothorax as a cause of pleural effusion.

answers.content: Air between the pleura and chest wall
answers.explanation_why: Trapped air between the pleura and chest wall is the underlying pathophysiology of pneumothorax. Given this patient's history of progressively worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath, pneumothorax should be considered as a possible diagnosis. A tension pneumothorax can cause tracheal deviation away from the affected side, due to increased intrathoracic pressure. However, x-ray findings in pneumothorax would include absent lung markings and areas of increased radiolucency rather than the large opacity and air-fluid level seen here.

Bacteria in the pulmonary parenchyma (e.g., due to Streptococcus pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) would be consistent with bacterial pneumonia. Expected chest x-ray findings in bacterial pneumonia would also include a lobar opacity, but tracheal deviation and an air-fluid level, as seen here, would be unusual. Furthermore, this patient does not have fever or symptoms of pneumonia, making this unlikely.

Symptoms of pulmonary edema may include dyspnea and low oxygen saturation due to impaired oxygenation. While both are seen in this patient, pulmonary edema alone would not cause such a pronounced air-fluid level on x-ray. Instead, it would appear as bilateral, patchy, confluent opacification, as the fluid is trapped inside the alveoli.

Neoplastic cells in the bronchi would be consistent with lung cancer, which this patient has risk factors for (smoking, age). An obstructive lung cancer could also cause tracheal deviation but would cause tracheal deviation towards the affected side, due to lung collapse, unlike what is seen here. This patient's large left-sided pleural effusion in the setting of recent fall make a different diagnosis more likely.

This patient's history of recent fall and x-ray findings of a large left pleural effusion with tracheal deviation are consistent with hemothorax. Trauma to the chest can cause the ribs to pierce the pleura and damage intrathoracic vessels, which can lead to accumulation of blood in the pleural space. There is tracheal deviation to the opposite side due to the increasing volume in the pleural space. A hemothorax cannot be diagnosed with x-ray alone (diagnosis usually requires CT imaging or thoracentesis) but given the patient's recent trauma, this is the most likely etiology.

images.title: Hemothorax following rib fracture
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of patient with history of rib fracture from a fall 10 days prior and left-sided chest pain accompanied by new dyspnea and orthopneaThe margins of the descending thoracic aorta (dashed line) and left hemidiaphragm are obscured by extensive air space disease (green overlay) and pleural effusion; a meniscus (red line) helps confirm the presence of the effusion. In view of the trauma history, the likely causes are pulmonary contusion and hemothorax. The slightly high position of the gastric bubble (GB) also suggests the presence of left lower lobe atelectasis. The right lung and cardiac silhouette are normal.Circle: fracture of the anterior left seventh rib

question_text: A 58-year old man comes to the emergency department because of progressively worsening shortness of breath and fatigue for 3 days. During the last month, he has also noticed dark colored urine. One month ago, he underwent mechanical aortic valve replacement for high-grade aortic stenosis. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear from the patient is shown. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
content_preview: A 58-year old man comes to the emergency department because of progressively worsening shortness of breath and fatigue for 3 days. During the last month, he has also noticed dark colored urine. One month ago, he underwent mechanical aortic valve replacement for high-grade aortic stenosis. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear from the patient is shown. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
hint: This man's symptoms (fatigue, dyspnea, dark urine), history of mechanical aortic valve replacement, and schistocytes on peripheral blood indicate a diagnosis of macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia.
learning_objective: Recognize macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and recall its associated laboratory finding.

answers.explanation_why: In cases of hemolysis, large amounts of hemoglobin are released upon erythrocyte destruction. This hemoglobin then degrades to unconjugated bilirubin, an insoluble product that is metabolized in the liver into conjugated bilirubin. Large amounts of unconjugated bilirubin can overload the liver's metabolic capacity, which leads to elevated (not low) levels of unconjugated bilirubin.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is an intracytoplasmic enzyme and a nonspecific indicator of increased cellular breakdown. Any cause of hemolysis would result in elevated LDH levels because LDH is abundant in RBCs. Macroangiopathic hemolysis, which occurs in patients with aortic stenosis or heart valve replacement, is characterized by the excess breakdown of RBCs due to mechanical forces applied to the erythrocyte membrane.

Ferritin is a protein complex responsible for iron storage. Decreased serum ferritin concentrations indicate iron deficiency anemia, which would cause fatigue and shortness of breath but it would not cause dark urine or schistocytes in a peripheral blood smear. Instead, a peripheral smear would show hypochromic erythrocytes characterized by a region of central pallor that is greater than ⅓^rd the diameter of the erythrocyte. In the case of hemolytic anemia, ferritin levels are usually normal or increased.

Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia would result in fatigue, dark urine, and schistocytes on a peripheral blood smear and most causes of microangiopathic hemolysis (e.g., DIC, TTP/HUS, SLE, HELLP) are associated with thrombocytopenia. This patient, however, has macroangiopathic hemolysis caused by aortic stenosis, which is not associated with thrombocytopenia.

Haptoglobin is an acute phase reactant and plasma glycoprotein that binds to free hemoglobin. Intravascular hemolysis (e.g., macroangiopathic hemolysis) leads to the release of hemoglobin into plasma and binding of hemoglobin to haptoglobin would result in low rather than elevated levels of haptoglobin.

images.title: Schistocytes
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; high magnification)Normal erythrocytes (example indicated by arrow; bottom left) and several fragmented erythrocytes (schistocytes; examples indicated by black dashed circles) with a normal convex side (example marked with red line) and a fragmented side that is concave or straight (example marked with blue line) can be seen. Additionally, multiple erythrocytes with dark staining Howell-Jolly bodies (examples indicated by arrowheads) are present.Schistocytes are a diagnostic finding in microangiopathic hemolytic anemias. These cellular fragments can also result from mechanical damage to erythrocytes (e.g., due to prosthetic heart valves). Howell-Jolly bodies can occur in functional asplenia or after splenectomy, severe anemia, and bone marrow disorders (e.g., myelodysplastic syndrome).

question_text: Several hours after vaginal delivery, a male newborn delivered at full-term develops tachycardia and tachypnea. His blood pressure is within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 80%. Physical examination shows cyanosis, supraclavicular and intercostal retractions, and a machine-like murmur over the precordium. Bedside echocardiography shows pulmonary and systemic circulation are in parallel rather than in series. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
content_preview: Several hours after vaginal delivery, a male newborn delivered at full-term develops tachycardia and tachypnea. His blood pressure is within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 80%. Physical examination shows cyanosis, supraclavicular and intercostal retractions, and a machine-like murmur over the precordium. Bedside echocardiography shows pulmonary and systemic circulation are in parallel rather than in series. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
hint: The findings of cyanosis early in a neonate's life are concerning for a congenital heart defect. This patient's echocardiogram shows two separate circulations connected by a patent ductus arteriosus (machine-like murmur). This indicates transposition of the great vessels.
learning_objective: Recognize transposition of the great vessels, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to maintain ductal patency.

answers.explanation_why: Sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, is used to dilate pulmonary vessels in neonates with pulmonary hypertension until the underlying cause is addressed. In this patient, dilation of pulmonary vessels could decrease right to left shunting across the PDA and, thus, worsen his symptoms.

Alprostadil (prostaglandin E1) is used in newborns with congenital heart defects to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus. In this infant, who has transposition of the great vessels, only deoxygenated blood is pumped from the right ventricle into the aorta. Therefore, it is important that oxygenated and deoxygenated blood are mixed through a shunt flow until definitive treatment (e.g., surgery) is performed. Other ductal-dependent heart defects include tetralogy of Fallot, critical pulmonic stenosis, and pulmonary atresia.

Beta blockers, such as propranolol and metoprolol, are used for the treatment of neonatal hypertension and congenital long QT syndrome. In this patient, tachycardia is a compensatory mechanism and thus should not be treated with beta blockers.

Indomethacin, an inhibitor of prostaglandin synthesis, is used to close a patent ductus arteriosus in premature infants. In patients with transposition of the great vessels, survival depends on communication between the two parallel circulations. Hence, closure of the patent ductus arteriosus would have a deleterious effect in this infant.
Dopamine can be used to raise systemic blood pressure in infants with cardiogenic shock. This infant does not need a vasopressor as he is not hypotensive.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe dyspnea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain for 20 minutes. Three weeks ago, she underwent surgery for a total right knee replacement. The patient appears distressed. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 88/55 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention. There is a mildly tender surgical scar on her right knee. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe dyspnea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain for 20 minutes. Three weeks ago, she underwent surgery for a total right knee replacement. The patient appears distressed. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 88/55 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention. There is a mildly tender surgical scar on her right knee. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: Orthopedic surgeries, such as a total knee replacement, often cause prolonged immobilization. This is a significant risk factor for venous stasis.
learning_objective: Recognize massive pulmonary embolism, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Endovascular stent-grafting can be used in the treatment of type A (proximal) aortic dissection. Patients typically present with severe, tearing chest pain, hypertension, and asymmetric pulses. Hypotension, severe dyspnea, and cough are less common manifestations of type A aortic dissection. The patient's CT scan also shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than a tear in the aortic intima, which would be typical in a case of dissection.

images.title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swellingThe ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

answers.explanation_why: Tube thoracostomy is used in the treatment of tension pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than air in the pleural space with tracheal deviation, which is typical in cases of tension pneumothorax.

This patient's CT scan shows evidence of a large pulmonary embolism (PE). In cases of massive PE with hemodynamic instability (e.g., SBP < 90 mm Hg), thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) such as alteplase is indicated. Because of the associated significant risk of bleeding, there are several relative and absolute contraindications to thrombolytic therapy. Surgery within the past 10 days is a relative contraindication, but this patient underwent surgery 3 weeks ago. Therefore, alteplase would be the most appropriate treatment. Anticoagulation with heparin, rivaroxaban, warfarin, or apixaban is also appropriate treatment for patients with PE. However, these agents are typically used in patients who remain hemodynamically stable.

Piperacillin/tazobactam can be used in the treatment of pneumonia. Pneumonia can manifest with dyspnea and cough, and, in the setting of sepsis, even hypotension. However, jugular venous distension would not be expected in pneumonia. In addition, this patient's CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than parenchymal infiltrates and/or consolidation, which would be typical in a case of pneumonia.

Coronary angioplasty is used in the treatment of myocardial infarction (MI). MI can manifest with chest pain, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism. In addition, a CT scan is typically not diagnostic in cases of myocardial infarction.

Bumetanide is a diuretic used in the treatment of pulmonary edema. Pulmonary edema can manifest with dyspnea, cough, tachypnea, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect that is consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than the findings typically seen in pulmonary edema (i.e., ground-glass opacities and peribronchovascular interstitial thickening). In addition, administering a diuretic could be detrimental to a patient with hypotension.

Pericardiocentesis is a procedure used to treat patients with pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with PE, as opposed to a fluid-filled pericardial sac, which would be typical in a patient with tamponade. Furthermore, pericardiocentesis would pose a risk of myocardial or endocardial injury in a patient who does not have pericardial effusion.

images.title: Saddle pulmonary embolism
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)A large embolism burden is seen (green overlay), with extension across the bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk into the right and left pulmonary arteries.Straddling of the pulmonary trunk bifurcation by pulmonary embolism is sometimes referred to as saddle embolism.AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; E: esophagus; LMB: left main bronchus; LPA: left pulmonary artery; PT: pulmonary trunk; RMB: right main bronchus; RPA: right pulmonary artery; SVC: superior vena cava

question_text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after falling from a height of 3 feet onto a sharp metal fence pole. He is unconscious. Physical examination shows a wound on the upper margin of the right clavicle in the parasternal line that is 3-cm deep. Which of the following is the most likely result of this patient's injury?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after falling from a height of 3 feet onto a sharp metal fence pole. He is unconscious. Physical examination shows a wound on the upper margin of the right clavicle in the parasternal line that is 3-cm deep. Which of the following is the most likely result of this patient's injury?
hint: This condition can also be caused by improper placement of a central venous catheter.
learning_objective: Recognize pneumothorax due to pleural injury.

answers.content: Rotator cuff tear due to supraspinatus muscle injury
answers.explanation_why: The supraspinatus muscle is part of the rotator cuff, which stabilizes the shoulder joint. It runs from the superior portion of the scapula to the greater tubercle of the humerus. Because this patient's wound is on the upper margin of the right clavicle, injury of the supraspinatus muscle is unlikely.

The pleural membrane covering the apex of the superior lobe of the lung extends approx. 2.5 cm above the medial end of the clavicle. A penetrating injury to the supraclavicular parasternal region, like the one sustained by this patient, can pierce the parietal pleural membrane, permitting air to enter the pleural space and causing an ipsilateral pneumothorax.

images.title: Chest x-ray interpretation
images.description: Interpretation of a chest x-ray typically begins with a comparison of variations in radiolucency between the apical, upper, middle, and lower zones of the lung.This approach allows for only a rough localization of potential pathologies because an opacity projecting onto the middle zone can affect either the middle or the lower lobe (they overlap in AP and PA views).

answers.content: Trapezius muscle paresis due to spinal accessory nerve injury
answers.explanation_why: The spinal accessory nerve exits the skull through the jugular foramen and sends a branch to the sternocleidomastoid muscle 3 cm below the mastoid process before entering the posterior triangle of the neck to innervate the trapezius muscle. Spinal accessory nerve injury resulting in trapezius (and sternocleidomastoid) paralysis would be expected if there were an injury to the upper aspect of the posterior triangle of the neck.

answers.content: Hemothorax due to azygos vein injury
answers.explanation_why: Azygos vein injury would cause hemothorax. However, the azygos vein drains into the superior vena cava at the level of the 4^th thoracic vertebra (T4). It does not extend into the supraclavicular space and would therefore not be susceptible to injury in a penetrating trauma to the right supraclavicular space.

answers.content: Chylothorax due to thoracic duct injury
answers.explanation_why: Injury to the thoracic duct would cause chylothorax. The thoracic duct extends into the left supraclavicular space just before it drains into the venous system at the junction of the left subclavian and internal jugular vein. As this patient has sustained an injury to the right supraclavicular space, his thoracic duct would not be injured.

answers.content: Traumatic aneurysm due to internal carotid artery injury
answers.explanation_why: The internal carotid artery (ICA) usually arises from the common carotid artery at the level of the fourth cervical vertebra (C4). A traumatic aneurysm of the ICA would therefore be expected secondary to a neck injury at or above the C4 level.

question_text: A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the emergency department because of lightheadedness over the past 2 hours. He reports that he has had similar episodes of lightheadedness and palpitations over the past 3 days. His only medication is metformin. His pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular. An ECG shows a variable R-R interval and absence of P waves. The patient undergoes transesophageal echocardiography. During the procedure, the tip of the ultrasound probe is angled posteriorly within the esophagus. This view is most helpful for evaluating which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the emergency department because of lightheadedness over the past 2 hours. He reports that he has had similar episodes of lightheadedness and palpitations over the past 3 days. His only medication is metformin. His pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular. An ECG shows a variable R-R interval and absence of P waves. The patient undergoes transesophageal echocardiography. During the procedure, the tip of the ultrasound probe is angled posteriorly within the esophagus. This view is most helpful for evaluating which of the following conditions?
hint: Other structures lying posterior and in close proximity to the esophagus include the thoracic duct and azygos vein.
learning_objective: Recognize the utility of transesophageal echocardiography, and recall the anatomical structures it evaluates.

answers.content: Thrombus in the left pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: The esophagus lies posterior to the right pulmonary artery, which can be seen in the anterior view on a TEE. However, the left pulmonary artery is hardly visible in any view on TEE.

A tumor in the left atrium, e.g., left atrial myxoma, can be visualized well on TEE, but only when the probe is rotated anteriorly in the mid-esophagus. The left atrium, right atrium, and interatrial septum can be seen in the anterior view.

The upper esophagus lies posterior to the trachea and anterior to the vertebral column. Below the bifurcation of the trachea, the descending aorta lies posterior to the lower esophagus. An aneurysm of the descending aorta can, therefore, be visualized well on transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) through an ultrasound probe that is angled posteriorly within the esophagus.

images.title: The esophagus
images.description: Esophagus and surrounding structures (anterior view)The esophagus begins at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. It first descends posterior to the trachea, and then posterior to the heart. At the level of the 4^th thoracic vertebra, the aorta runs adjacent to the esophagus, pushing it slightly to the right. The esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm at the level of the 10^th thoracic vertebra and ends at the stomach after a brief stretch within the peritoneum.The upper part of the trachea, lungs, and heart are not shown for clarity.

answers.content: Thrombus in the left ventricular apex
answers.explanation_why: A thrombus in the left ventricular apex can be visualized well on transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) because of the proximity of the ventricular apex to the anterior chest wall. While a TEE allows for better imaging quality when evaluating the cardiac structures that lie in close proximity to the esophagus, more anterior structures such as the left ventricular apex would not be seen well.

answers.content: Tumor in the right main bronchus
answers.explanation_why: The esophagus lies posterior to the trachea and left mainstem bronchus. These structures could be visualized in the anterior view on a TEE, but the right main bronchus would not be seen. A chest x-ray or CT imaging of the chest is indicated if a bronchial tumor is suspected.

question_text: A 65-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after the onset of severe anterior chest pain and shortness of breath. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He appears distressed. His pulse is 116/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 156/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. A grade 3/6, high-pitched, blowing, diastolic murmur is heard over the right upper sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after the onset of severe anterior chest pain and shortness of breath. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He appears distressed. His pulse is 116/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 156/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. A grade 3/6, high-pitched, blowing, diastolic murmur is heard over the right upper sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Dyspnea with a high-pitched, blowing, diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border suggests aortic regurgitation.
learning_objective: Recognize aortic dissection by a tear in the tunica intima.

answers.explanation_why:
An aortic dissection is typically caused by a tear in the tunica intima and subsequent longitudinal extension of the dissecting hematoma. Hypertension, which increases the risk of endothelial injury, is the most common predisposing factor for aortic dissection. Most aortic dissections begin in the ascending portion of the thoracic aorta because this is the region of maximum hydraulic stress. Patients present with sudden and severe pain in the chest or interscapular region. The pain can migrate as the dissection progresses. Proximal extension of the dissection into the aortic valve ring can cause acute aortic regurgitation (AR), as seen here. Other features of aortic dissection include syncope, diminished distal pulses, and asymmetrical blood pressure and pulse readings between limbs. Unlike the murmur of AR from aortic valve disease, which is prominent along the left sternal border, the murmur of AR from aortic dissection is prominent along the right sternal border.

Nonmodifiable risk factors for aortic dissection include advanced age, male sex, and certain genetic conditions that weaken the tunica media (e.g., Marfan syndrome, vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Turner syndrome).

images.title: Aortic dissection
images.description: A tear in the tunica intima (entry tear on illustration) allows blood to enter into the tunica media. The column of blood then extends longitudinally, most commonly in the outer half of the tunica media. This creates a false lumen, which may rupture back into the true lumen of the aorta (reentry tear on illustration) or rupture through the tunica adventitia.

answers.content: Fibrofatty plaque in the aortic wall
answers.explanation_why: The formation of a fibrofatty plaque in the aortic wall is characteristic of atherosclerosis, which typically involves the abdominal portion of the descending aorta. Atherosclerosis is implicated in the formation of abdominal aortic aneurysms; atheroma ulceration has been reported in some patients with abdominal aortic dissections and descending thoracic aortic dissections. Although both aortic dissection and atherosclerosis share similar risk factors (e.g., smoking, hypertension, advanced age, and male sex), atherosclerosis is not a major risk factor for most aortic dissections, which tend to occur in the ascending aorta.

Obstruction of the pulmonary arteries is seen in pulmonary embolism, which can manifest with acute-onset dyspnea, chest pain, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, pulmonary embolism would not explain the AR seen here.

answers.content: Rupture of a bulla in the lung
answers.explanation_why: Rupture of a bulla in the lung causes pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, pneumothorax would not explain the AR seen here. Instead, chest auscultation would reveal decreased breath sounds caused by pneumothorax.

Esophageal rupture can manifest with chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea, and dyspnea (due to mediastinitis and/or pleural effusion). However, esophageal rupture would not cause a murmur. Instead, chest auscultation might reveal a crunching sound over the precordium that is synchronous with each heartbeat (Hamman sign) due to a pneumomediastinum and/or decreased breath sounds due to a pleural effusion. Furthermore, esophageal rupture usually has a distinct precipitating cause (e.g., retching or forceful vomiting).

Infarction of the ventricular wall (myocardial infarction) can cause acute-onset chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, and a murmur due to mitral regurgitation that is caused by papillary muscle rupture. However, the murmur due to mitral regurgitation is systolic rather than diastolic and heard best at the cardiac apex, not the right upper sternal border. Moreover, papillary muscle rupture typically occurs 2–7 days after infarction, not at the outset.

question_text: A 43-year-old man from Chile comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of upper back pain and difficulty swallowing. He has had pain in his shoulder and knee joints over the past 10 years. He is 190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 70.3 kg (155 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m^2. His blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg in the right arm and 130/70 mg Hg in the left arm. Physical examination shows a depression in the sternum and a grade 3/6 diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. A CT scan of the chest with contrast is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 43-year-old man from Chile comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of upper back pain and difficulty swallowing. He has had pain in his shoulder and knee joints over the past 10 years. He is 190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 70.3 kg (155 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg in the right arm and 130/70 mg Hg in the left arm. Physical examination shows a depression in the sternum and a grade 3/6 diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. A CT scan of the chest with contrast is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
hint: This axial CT shows an ascending aortic aneurysm, which is often associated with an aortic regurgitation murmur (diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border) caused by dilation of the aortic valve annulus. Dissection of the weakened aneurysmal wall can cause an acute increase in the size of an aneurysm, manifesting with back pain, discordant blood pressure readings in the upper limbs, and difficulty swallowing (dysphagia aortica due to esophageal compression).
learning_objective: Recognize cystic medial degeneration associated with Marfan syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Infection with the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease, which is endemic to South America. This disease can cause dysphagia (due to achalasia) as well as aortic regurgitation (due to dilated cardiomyopathy), which are seen here. However, Chagas disease would not cause pectus excavatum, discordant blood pressure readings, or dilation of the aorta.

Autoimmune valve damage is the cause of rheumatic heart disease (RHD), which, in the US, is most commonly seen in the immigrant population. RHD can cause a diastolic murmur (due to mitral stenosis), and, rarely, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia megalatriensis due to left atrial enlargement). Rheumatic fever, which is the pathologic precursor to RHD, would also cause pain in large joints such as the knee. However, the joint pain would subside after the acute episode of rheumatic fever, and the diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis would be heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient's murmur is caused by aortic regurgitation, which is not common in RHD. Most importantly, RHD would not cause dilation of the ascending aorta.

Granulomatous inflammation is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA), which predisposes to the formation of ascending aortic aneurysms and can present with back and shoulder pain (due to concurrent polymyalgia rheumatica). However, aortic aneurysm usually occurs late in the course of GCA and the disease virtually never affects patients < 50 years.

Granulomatous inflammation is also seen in Takayasu arteritis, which can lead to chronic arthralgia and discordant blood pressure readings between the upper limbs (due to aortic arch narrowing). Takayasu arteritis can, occasionally, lead to aneurysmal dilation of the ascending aorta with aortic regurgitation and dysphagia, which is seen here. However, the condition typically occurs in Asian women and would usually be associated with other features, such as cutaneous nodules, fever, or night sweats.

Systemic fibroblast proliferation is a pathologic process that occurs in patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc), which can cause dysphagia (due to esophageal dysmotility), chronic arthralgia, and vascular disease. Dysphagia due to SSc usually has a subacute or chronic onset. In addition, arthralgia caused by SSc typically affects the small joints of the hands and feet, and the vasculopathy associated with SSc manifests as Raynaud phenomenon, telangiectasia, or thromboembolic phenomena. Furthermore, SS would not cause pectus excavatum, discordant blood pressure readings, aortic regurgitation, or dilation of the ascending aorta.

Congenital narrowing of the aortic arch (aortic coarctation) can cause discordant blood pressure readings in the limbs. Additionally, a bicuspid aortic valve, which is commonly associated with aortic coarctation, can lead to aortic regurgitation (diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border), which is seen here. However, in the case of aortic coarctation, the discordance is usually between the blood pressure measurements of the upper and lower extremities because the coarctation is typically located just distal to the left subclavian artery. Only in very rare instances would aortic coarctation cause disparate blood pressure measurements in the arms. Furthermore, this condition would not be expected to cause significant dilation of the ascending aorta.

This patient's tall stature and pectus excavatum suggest Marfan syndrome. Individuals with Marfan syndrome have hypermobile joints, which predisposes them to chronic arthralgia as a result of recurrent sprains, bursitis, and/or early-onset osteoarthritis. Cystic medial degeneration, which occurs with aging and in connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, leads to the weakening of the aortic wall and aneurysmal dilation, which are seen here.

Weakening of the vessel wall due to atheroma formation (atherosclerosis) is the most common cause of an aortic aneurysm, and the marfanoid features in this patient (e.g., tall stature, pectus excavatum) might be due to homocystinuria, which is a risk factor for early-onset atherosclerosis. However, aneurysms due to atherosclerosis typically occur in the thoracic segment and the abdominal segment of the descending aorta. The ascending aortic aneurysm in this patient suggests a different pathologic process.

images.title: Thoracic aortic aneurysm and pectus excavatum deformity
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane; mediastinal window) of a patient with Marfan syndromeA large aneurysm of the ascending aorta (green overlay) is seen. Pectus excavatum deformity (white arrow) is also present and deviates the mediastinum to the left of midline.Aneurysmal dilatation of the ascending aorta and pectus excavatum can both be seen in Marfan syndrome.AA = Ascending aorta; DA = Descending aorta; MPA = Main pulmonary artery

question_text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 12 hours after the sudden onset of shortness of breath and substernal chest pain at rest; the pain is increased by inspiration. He has also had a nonproductive cough, fever, and malaise for the past 5 days. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows distended neck veins. Auscultation of the chest discloses bilateral basilar rales and muffled heart sounds. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia, diffuse ST segment elevation, low voltage QRS complexes, and fluctuating R wave amplitude. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 12 hours after the sudden onset of shortness of breath and substernal chest pain at rest; the pain is increased by inspiration. He has also had a nonproductive cough, fever, and malaise for the past 5 days. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows distended neck veins. Auscultation of the chest discloses bilateral basilar rales and muffled heart sounds. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia, diffuse ST segment elevation, low voltage QRS complexes, and fluctuating R wave amplitude. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A 12-hour history of dyspnea and inspiratory chest pain in the setting of a 5-day prodrome of subjective fever, malaise, and dry cough suggests an acute infection of the pericardium.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiac tamponade.

answers.explanation_why: Post-infarction fibrinous pericarditis typically occurs 1–3 days after a transmural myocardial infarction (MI) and can manifest with fever, inspiratory chest pain, dry cough, and diffuse ST elevation, as seen in this patient. However, this patient does not have a history of coronary artery disease or recent MI, making post-infarction fibrinous pericarditis unlikely. Rather, his 5-day history of cough, fever, and malaise suggests an infectious cause for the pericarditis.

Kawasaki disease manifests with fever and malaise, as seen in this patient. Myocarditis and myocardial infarction are known complications of this condition that can manifest with chest pain and features of cardiac decompensation (e.g., dyspnea, bilateral rales, distended neck veins). However, a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease requires further specific symptoms, such as erythema and edema of the hands and feet, polymorphous rash, conjunctivitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and oropharyngeal mucositis. Moreover, this condition most commonly affects children under the age of 5 years, so it is an unlikely diagnosis in a 55-year-old man.

Rheumatic fever (RF) manifests with fever and malaise, as seen in this patient. Cardiac complications of RF include pancarditis and valvular heart disease, which can cause symptoms of cardiac decompensation (e.g., dyspnea, bilateral rales, distended neck veins). However, the typical ECG finding in RF is a prolonged PR interval, which is not seen here. Moreover, this patient does not have a history of untreated bacterial tonsillopharyngitis or other typical features of RF (e.g., migratory polyarthritis, subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea).

Dressler syndrome usually occurs 2–10 weeks after myocardial infarction (MI) due to immune complex-mediated damage in the pericardium. While this patient does present with signs and symptoms of acute pericarditis (e.g., fever, pleuritic chest pain, dry cough, and diffuse ST elevation), he does not have a history of coronary artery disease or past MI, making Dressler syndrome unlikely. Rather, his 5-day history of cough, fever, and malaise suggests an infectious cause for the pericarditis.

Infective endocarditis (IE) could explain this patient's fever, malaise, pleuritic chest pain, and features of cardiac decompensation (e.g., dyspnea, bilateral rales, distended neck veins). However, he presents with muffled heart sounds rather than a new murmur, which is a key manifestation of IE, and he does not have extracardiac manifestations of IE (e.g., splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and Roth spots). Additionally, his ECG findings suggest another diagnosis.

Cardiac tamponade, a complication of acute pericarditis, is caused by the combination of increased secretion of fluid into pericardial space and decreased elasticity of the pericardium secondary to inflammation. Once the pericardial effusion becomes sufficiently pronounced, either due to the rate of fluid accumulation or the amount of fluid, the heart can become compressed, which decreases cardiac output and ventricular diastolic filling. This patient presents with the classic symptoms of cardiac tamponade: hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds (i.e., Beck triad) as well as a characteristic ECG finding of low-voltage QRS complexes and fluctuating R wave amplitude (i.e., electrical alternans).

question_text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with chest pain, select the most appropriate next step in management.
A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of left-sided chest pain. She reports that the pain is stabbing in quality and worsens with inspiration. She returned from a business trip to Croatia 3 days ago. She has a 4-year history of hypertension treated with amlodipine. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears distressed. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Physical examination shows swelling of the right lower extremity. Auscultation of the chest shows a friction rub in the left infra-axillary region. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no evidence of ischemia.
content_preview: The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set. For each patient with chest pain, select the most appropriate next step in management. A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of left-sided chest pain. She reports that the pain is stabbing in quality and worsens with inspiration. She returned from a business trip to Croatia 3 days ago. She has a 4-year history of hypertension treated with amlodipine. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears distressed. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Physical examination shows swelling of the right lower extremity. Auscultation of the chest shows a friction rub in the left infra-axillary region. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no evidence of ischemia.
hint: This patient's sudden onset of stabbing chest pain that worsens with inspiration (i.e., pleuritic chest pain), recent immobility, tachypnea, tachycardia, friction rub, and lower limb swelling suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE).
learning_objective: Recognize pulmonary embolism, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous sodium nitroprusside therapy can be used in a hypertensive crisis. However, this patient's blood pressure is normal. Intravenous sodium nitroprusside therapy has no role in the management of pulmonary embolism.

Transesophageal echocardiography can be used at the bedside in a patient with suspected pulmonary embolism who is hemodynamically unstable if it is deemed unsafe for the patient to undergo a CT scan and a portable perfusion scan is unavailable. Echocardiography may show evidence of a pulmonary embolism (e.g., a clot in the pulmonary artery, right ventricular enlargement, or right ventricular hypokinesis). Echocardiography is not the next most appropriate step in management for this patient, who is hemodynamically stable.

Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty is used in the treatment of cardiac valvular disease. This patient does not have physical examination findings of valvular disease, such as a heart murmur, click, or snap. Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty has no role in the management of pulmonary embolism.

In patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) for whom the door-to-balloon time is < 120 minutes, percutaneous balloon angioplasty with stent implantation is indicated. This patient's ECG does not show a STEMI. Percutaneous balloon angioplasty has no role in the management of pulmonary embolism.

In the setting of chronic chest pain, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (EGD) can be helpful in identifying a gastrointestinal source (e.g., esophagitis) as the cause of the pain. However, EGD should be performed only after cardiac and pulmonary causes of chest pain have been ruled out.

Transthoracic echocardiography can be used at the bedside in a patient with suspected pulmonary embolism who is hemodynamically unstable if it is deemed unsafe for the patient to undergo a CT scan and a portable perfusion scan is unavailable. Echocardiography may show evidence of a pulmonary embolism (e.g., a clot in the pulmonary artery, right ventricular enlargement, or right ventricular hypokinesis). Echocardiography is not the next most appropriate step in management for this patient, who is hemodynamically stable.

Contrast esophagography with a nontoxic, water-soluble contrast agent can be used in the setting of acute chest pain if esophageal perforation or rupture is suspected (e.g., by plain radiographs). Esophageal perforation or rupture can occur due to foreign body ingestion, trauma, recent consumption of large amounts of alcohol or food, repeated episodes of vomiting, and after upper endoscopy, none of which are seen in this patient. Contrast esophagography has no role in the management of pulmonary embolism.

Emergency thoracotomy can be used in the setting of acute chest pain for aortic dissection repair, open heart resuscitation, or embolectomy; it is not the next most appropriate step in management for this patient. Typical clinical features of aortic dissection include tearing or ripping chest pain, interscapular pain, elevated blood pressure, syncope, and asymmetrical blood pressure and pulse readings between limbs, none of which are seen here. Open heart resuscitation can be used as a procedure of last resort in patients who have sustained major trauma. In a patient with a pulmonary embolism, embolectomy is a treatment of last resort when thrombolysis is contraindicated or unsuccessful.

Pericardiocentesis can be used in the setting of acute chest pain for the treatment of cardiac tamponade. This condition typically manifests with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins, and low-amplitude QRS complexes on ECG, none of which are seen in this patient. Pericardiocentesis has no role in the management of pulmonary embolism.

Chest x-ray in a patient with a suspected pulmonary embolism rarely shows findings that raise suspicion for that diagnosis (e.g., Hampton hump, Westermark sign). More commonly, findings on chest x-ray are normal or nonspecific. Because of its low diagnostic yield, chest x-ray is not typically indicated for the evaluation of pulmonary embolism and is likely to delay definitive diagnosis and treatment.

This patient likely has a pulmonary embolism (PE), an obstruction of the pulmonary artery and/or one of its branches by a thrombus that most commonly arises from the deep vein system in the legs or pelvis. Her Wells score for PE is 9 (based on clinical symptoms of deep vein thrombosis, history of immobilization in the past 4 weeks, tachycardia, and PE being more likely than other diagnoses), which indicates a high probability of a PE. Accordingly, the next most appropriate step in the evaluation of this patient is a CT angiogram with contrast (CT pulmonary angiography). For patients for whom the clinical probability of a PE is intermediate or high, therapeutic anticoagulation should be initiated if there are no contraindications to anticoagulation.
answers.explanation_but: If a CT angiogram with contrast is not available or contraindicated (e.g., severe renal insufficiency or contrast allergy), ventilation/perfusion scintigraphy (V/Q scan) can be performed instead.

answers.explanation_why: In the setting of a suspected pulmonary embolism (PE), serum D-dimer measurement is the next most appropriate step if the Wells score for PE is ≤ 4, which indicates a low or medium probability of a PE. This patient's Wells score for PE is 9 (based on clinical symptoms of deep vein thrombosis, history of immobilization in the past 4 weeks, tachycardia, and PE being more likely than other diagnoses), which indicates a high probability of a PE. D-dimer measurement is not indicated.

Intravenous tenecteplase therapy can be used as thrombolytic therapy for a pulmonary embolism if the patient's bleeding risk is not high and the patient is hemodynamically unstable. It is not the next most appropriate step in management for this patient, who is hemodynamically stable.

question_text:
For each patient with chest pain, select the most appropriate next step in management.
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after the sudden onset of chest pain and lightheadedness. He describes the pain as stabbing in quality and radiating to the back. He has gastroesophageal reflux disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 42 years and drinks 6 oz of alcohol daily. He does not use illicit drugs. Medications include pantoprazole, amlodipine, lisinopril, and metformin. On arrival, he is diaphoretic and poorly responsive. His pulse is 106/min and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Cardiac examination shows a normal S_1 and S_2. A grade 4/6 early diastolic murmur is heard best at the right upper sternal border. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and left ventricular hypertrophy.
content_preview: For each patient with chest pain, select the most appropriate next step in management. A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after the sudden onset of chest pain and lightheadedness. He describes the pain as stabbing in quality and radiating to the back. He has gastroesophageal reflux disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 42 years and drinks 6 oz of alcohol daily. He does not use illicit drugs. Medications include pantoprazole, amlodipine, lisinopril, and metformin. On arrival, he is diaphoretic and poorly responsive. His pulse is 106/min and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Cardiac examination shows a normal S1 and S2. A grade 4/6 early diastolic murmur is heard best at the right upper sternal border. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and left ventricular hypertrophy.
hint: This patient has an aortic dissection, a condition that is typically precipitated by systemic hypertension and manifests with sudden-onset tearing or stabbing chest pain that radiates to the back. Aortic dissection may result in aortic regurgitation (due to involvement of the aortic valve), which causes an early diastolic murmur that is heard best at the right upper sternal border.
learning_objective: Recognize aortic dissection, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous sodium nitroprusside therapy can be used to control hypertension in patients with an aortic dissection. However, the first-line medical therapy for aortic dissection is an intravenous beta blocker, which decreases shearing forces in the aorta by lowering the heart rate and the left ventricular ejection fraction. Intravenous sodium nitroprusside therapy alone will induce reflex tachycardia (via activation of the sympathetic nervous system), which increases shearing forces in the aorta and may worsen the dissection.

The management of aortic dissection depends on the origin and extent of the dissection. Stanford type A aortic dissections require emergency surgical management; Stanford type B aortic dissections can be managed initially with medical therapies (e.g., blood pressure control). The next most appropriate step in management is an aortic imaging study to establish the diagnosis and classify the dissection. In patients who are hemodynamically stable, CT angiogram with contrast is appropriate. This patient, who is hemodynamically unstable (poorly responsive, tachycardic, and hypotensive), should receive bedside transesophageal echocardiography.
answers.explanation_but: For patients in whom there is a high suspicion for aortic dissection, a beta blocker should be administered to control the blood pressure during concurrent evaluation of the patient.

answers.explanation_why: Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty is used in the treatment of cardiac valvular disease (e.g., severe symptomatic aortic stenosis). This patient has aortic regurgitation from an aortic dissection, not aortic stenosis. Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty has no role in the management of aortic dissection.

In patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) for whom the door-to-balloon time is < 120 minutes, percutaneous balloon angioplasty with stent implantation is indicated. This patient's ECG does not show a STEMI. Percutaneous balloon angioplasty has no role in the management of aortic dissection.

In the setting of chronic chest pain, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (EGD) can be helpful in identifying a gastrointestinal source (e.g., esophagitis) as the cause of the pain. However, EGD should be performed only after cardiac and pulmonary causes of chest pain have been ruled out.

Transthoracic echocardiography is unable to effectively visualize the middle and distal portions of the ascending aorta, the transverse arch, and the descending aorta. Accordingly, it has low sensitivity for detecting and classifying aortic dissections compared to other imaging modalities and is not the next most appropriate step in management for this patient.

Contrast esophagography with a nontoxic, water-soluble contrast agent can be used in the setting of acute chest pain if esophageal perforation or rupture is suspected (e.g., by plain radiographs). Esophageal perforation or rupture can occur due to foreign body ingestion, trauma, recent consumption of large amounts of alcohol or food, repeated episodes of vomiting, and after upper endoscopy, none of which are seen in this patient. Contrast esophagography has no role in the management of aortic dissection.

Emergency thoracotomy can be used to access the aorta for surgical repair of a Stanford type A aortic dissection. Though this patient has an aortic dissection, the classification of dissection is unknown at this time, so emergency thoracotomy would be premature.

Pericardiocentesis can be used in the setting of acute chest pain for the treatment of cardiac tamponade. This condition typically manifests with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins, and low-amplitude QRS complexes on ECG, none of which are seen in this patient. Pericardiocentesis has no role in the management of aortic dissection.

Chest x-rays are commonly obtained during the evaluation of acute chest pain and can show a widened aortic silhouette in patients with an aortic dissection. However, chest x-ray has a low sensitivity for detecting and classifying aortic dissections compared to other imaging modalities and, therefore, is not the next most appropriate step in management for this patient. Because of its low diagnostic yield, chest x-ray is likely to delay definitive diagnosis and treatment.

In patients who are hemodynamically stable, a CT angiogram with contrast is the most appropriate study to detect and classify an aortic dissection. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable (poorly responsive, tachycardic, and hypotensive) and thus is unable to safely receive a CT angiogram with contrast at this time.

Serum D-dimer measurement is used in the evaluation of a patient with a low or medium probability of a having a pulmonary embolism (PE). Though this patient is tachycardic, he lacks other typical manifestations of PE, including dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, and unilateral leg swelling (his Wells score for PE is 1.5, which indicates a low risk). There is no role for serum D-dimer measurement in the evaluation of a patient with a suspected aortic dissection.

Intravenous tenecteplase therapy can be used as thrombolytic therapy for a pulmonary embolism (PE) if the patient's bleeding risk is not high and the patient is hemodynamically unstable. Though this patient is tachycardic, he lacks other typical manifestations of PE, including dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, and unilateral leg swelling (his Wells score for PE is 1.5, which indicates a low risk). Intravenous tenecteplase therapy can also be used to treat ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) where percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) cannot be performed < 120 minutes after the onset of symptoms or if PCI is unsuccessful. This patient's ECG does not show a STEMI. There is no role for intravenous tenecteplase therapy in the management of aortic dissection.

question_text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of headaches and frequent episodes of bleeding from her nose. Over the past 2 months, she has had shortness of breath and intermittent leg pain while jogging. She has no history of previous illnesses. Her father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 52 years. She smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily and occasionally used methamphetamines and cocaine during college, but she has not used illicit drugs for the past 5 years. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (140 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 168/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased femoral pulses compared to the brachial pulses. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
14.2 g/dL

Serum

 Na^+

142 mEq/L

 K^+

3.6 mEq/L

 Cl^-

99 mEq/L

 Urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL

An ECG shows prominent R waves in leads V_5 and V_6 and deep S waves in leads V_1 and V_2. An x-ray of the chest shows enlargement of the cardiac silhouette and erosions of the inferior aspects of the 4^th through 8^th ribs bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of headaches and frequent episodes of bleeding from her nose. Over the past 2 months, she has had shortness of breath and intermittent leg pain while jogging. She has no history of previous illnesses. Her father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 52 years. She smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily and occasionally used methamphetamines and cocaine during college, but she has not used illicit drugs for the past 5 years. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (140 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 168/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased femoral pulses compared to the brachial pulses. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 14.2 g/dL Serum Na+ 142 mEq/L K+ 3.6 mEq/L Cl- 99 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL An ECG shows prominent R waves in leads V5 and V6 and deep S waves in leads V1 and V2. An x-ray of the chest shows enlargement of the cardiac silhouette and erosions of the inferior aspects of the 4th through 8th ribs bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This disease is also often seen in individuals with Takayasu arteritis.
learning_objective: Recognize aortic coarctation, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Cardiac catheterization is a diagnostic and/or therapeutic procedure for several cardiac conditions, including coarctation of the aorta, which this patient has. However, cardiac catheterization is an invasive procedure and is more typically reserved for cases in which a concurrent intervention is expected or evaluation for concurrent coronary artery disease is needed.

The ankle-brachial index would be decreased in patients with arterial insufficiency of the lower extremities but the ankle-brachial index cannot be used to determine the underlying cause of arterial insufficiency. A different diagnostic step is necessary to establish the diagnosis.

Renal duplex ultrasonography is the imaging test of choice for evaluating renal artery stenosis. Although this patient's secondary hypertension is also due to a vascular source, she does not have an abdominal bruit or hypokalemia (secondary to release of renin) that are characteristic of renal artery stenosis. Moreover, renal artery stenosis does not explain her x-ray finding of rib notching.

Doppler echocardiography is the test of choice for diagnosing aortic coarctation. In addition to echocardiography, which provides dynamic imaging of the heart and can detect concurrent anomalies, Doppler helps to localize the coarctation and estimate its severity. This patient's clinical features such as features of arterial insufficiency in the lower extremities (e.g., intermittent claudication during physical activity, decreased femoral pulses), features of brachiocephalic hypertension (e.g., headache, epistaxis), and evidence of collateral circulation (rib notching on x-ray) are consistent with the presentation of aortic coarctation in adulthood. Moreover, this patient is now experiencing sequelae of untreated aortic coarctation such as left ventricular hypertrophy (as evidenced by her ECG findings) due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction and dyspnea due to heart failure.

Measurement of metanephrines in 24-hour urine is the confirmatory test of choice for pheochromocytoma. Hypertension and headaches in a young patient may be consistent with pheochromocytoma, but this type of tumor does not explain this patient's lower extremity claudication with exertion and rib notching on x-ray. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic symptoms of pheochromocytoma, including paroxysmal diaphoresis and palpitations.

Urine toxicology screening for cocaine can help in the assessment for an alternative cause of secondary hypertension, headaches, epistaxis, and heart failure. However, cocaine use would not explain this patient's lower extremity claudication with exertion and rib notching seen on x-ray.

Monitoring of 24-hour blood pressure can be used to diagnose hypertension. While this patient is hypertensive, blood pressure monitoring would not help identify the underlying etiology of this patient's secondary hypertension. She has a constellation of clinical features, including lower extremity claudication with exertion, rib notching on x-ray, and heart failure at a young age, that would be difficult to explain by isolated hypertension.
