question_text: A 2-day-old male newborn is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit because of irritability and feeding difficulty. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman following an uncomplicated delivery. He is awake and alert. He is at the 4^th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Cardiac examination discloses a 3/6 continuous murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular region. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 2-day-old male newborn is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit because of irritability and feeding difficulty. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman following an uncomplicated delivery. He is awake and alert. He is at the 4th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Cardiac examination discloses a 3/6 continuous murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular region. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: Features of heart failure (e.g., irritability, poor feeding, failure to thrive) with a continuous murmur in the left infraclavicular region are highly suggestive of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), for which premature birth is a risk factor. The echocardiography findings confirm the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize patent ductus arteriosus, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitors such as ibuprofen and indomethacin are the mainstay of treatment for symptomatic PDA in premature infants. Prostaglandins keep the ductus arteriosus patent, and by inhibiting cyclooxygenase, NSAIDs decrease prostaglandin production and thus promote ductal closure. NSAIDs are only effective in preterm infants.

Transcatheter or surgical closure is the treatment of choice for infants ≥ 6 kg, children, and adults. In preterm infants, procedural closure is generally only used if pharmacological treatment is unsuccessful.

Digoxin can be used for symptomatic management of heart failure in full-term infants with a large PDA who weigh < 5 kg. However, it would not correct the underlying cause of this patient's heart failure (PDA). In addition, this infant is preterm, and thus requires a different therapeutic approach.

Hydrochlorothiazide can be used in preterm infants with a large PDA for symptomatic management. Although it can provide symptomatic relief, it would not address the underlying cause of heart failure in this patient (PDA).

Prostaglandin E_1 (PGE_1) is indicated in patients with ductal-dependent congenital heart diseases (CHDs) in order to maintain ductus arteriosus patency before surgery can be performed. However, ductal-dependent CHDs typically manifest at birth with pronounced cyanosis. This patient's murmur and normal pulse oximetry reading are suggestive of an isolated PDA, which means that prostaglandins are contraindicated.

Furosemide is the preferred treatment for the management of heart failure in full-term infants with PDA who weigh < 5 kg. However, it would not address the underlying cause of heart failure in this patient (PDA). In addition, this infant is preterm and thus requires a different therapeutic approach.

question_text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he had a cardiac arrest. He was playing soccer with his friends at school when he suddenly collapsed on the field. A teacher who witnessed the incident successfully performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation and called the ambulance. The patient has no history of serious illness. His uncle died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 35. On arrival, he appears exhausted. His pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that is heard best at the apex and left lower sternal border, and an S_4 gallop. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of premature death in this patient?
content_preview: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he had a cardiac arrest. He was playing soccer with his friends at school when he suddenly collapsed on the field. A teacher who witnessed the incident successfully performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation and called the ambulance. The patient has no history of serious illness. His uncle died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 35. On arrival, he appears exhausted. His pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that is heard best at the apex and left lower sternal border, and an S4 gallop. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of premature death in this patient?
hint: This patient's sudden cardiac arrest after physical activity is most likely due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO). His family history (sudden cardiac death in a young relative) and physical examination findings (systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the apex, S_4 gallop) are consistent with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM).
learning_objective: Recognize hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, and choose the most appropriate treatment to prevent sudden cardiac death.

answers.explanation_why: Placement of a cardiac pacemaker may be considered in symptomatic patients with HOCM who have not responded to other pharmacological and nonpharmacological treatment options. Although cardiac pacing can provide symptomatic relief in these patients, it does not decrease their risk of premature death. A different treatment should be attempted in this patient before considering cardiac pacing.

Nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCBs), including verapamil, can be used as second-line agents for the management of symptomatic HOCM to provide heart rate control, which allows for longer diastole and increased diastolic filling. However, these agents are not known to reduce the risk of premature death in patients with HOCM. In addition, if severe LVOTO is also present, nondihydropyridine CCBs should be used with caution because their marked vasodilatory effects can increase the degree of LVOTO and worsen these patients' symptoms.

Placement of an automated implantable cardioverter defibrillator (AICD) is the best method to prevent sudden cardiac death (SCD) in patients with HOCM and a history of sudden cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular tachycardia. Other indications for AICD placement in patients with HOCM include a positive family history of SCD in a close relative ≤ 50 years of age, syncope of unknown cause, left ventricular (LV) wall thickness ≥ 30 mm, LV apical aneurysms, and LV systolic dysfunction. Patients with HOCM who are not in any of these categories still require risk stratification for AICD placement because of the high risk of SCD associated with this condition.

Beta blockers are the first-line therapy for the symptomatic treatment of patients with HOCM. Other therapy options include nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, septal myectomy, and cardiac pacemaker. High-dose diuretics, spironolactone, and digoxin should generally be avoided. It is important to note that these treatment options are not known to reduce the risk of premature death in patients with HOCM.

Septal myectomy is an effective treatment option for patients with symptomatic HOCM who have not responded to medical treatment. Although septal myectomy can provide symptomatic relief in these patients, it does not decrease their risk of premature death. A different treatment should be attempted in this patient before surgery is considered.

Loop diuretics, including furosemide, may be added in patients with HOCM and persistent symptoms despite the first-line treatment regimen, but high-dose diuretics should be avoided, as they can increase outflow obstruction by reducing the preload. In addition, loop diuretics are not known to reduce the risk of premature death in patients with HOCM.

question_text: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department 35 minutes after the sudden onset of dizziness and palpitations. He says his symptoms began while watching TV and resolved spontaneously after 10 minutes. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He had two myocardial infarctions over the past year. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 6 months ago. His medications are aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, ramipril, and atorvastatin. While the nurse is recording an ECG, his symptoms suddenly start again. The patient appears in mild distress but is alert and fully oriented. His pulse is 160/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG is shown. One minute later, a repeat ECG shows the same findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department 35 minutes after the sudden onset of dizziness and palpitations. He says his symptoms began while watching TV and resolved spontaneously after 10 minutes. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He had two myocardial infarctions over the past year. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 6 months ago. His medications are aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, ramipril, and atorvastatin. While the nurse is recording an ECG, his symptoms suddenly start again. The patient appears in mild distress but is alert and fully oriented. His pulse is 160/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG is shown. One minute later, a repeat ECG shows the same findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's ECG shows two normal sinus beats followed by continuous wide (∼ 140 ms) monomorphic QRS complexes with a heart rate of ∼ 160/min, and atrioventricular dissociation, which is consistent with sustained (> 30 seconds) monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). He has no features of unstable tachycardia (e.g., altered mental status or loss of consciousness, hypotension, respiratory distress, ischemic chest pain).
learning_objective: Recognize sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, and choose the appropriate pharmacologic treatment.

answers.explanation_why:
Prompt pharmacologic cardioversion with intravenous antiarrhythmics such as procainamide, sotalol, or amiodarone is the first-line treatment for hemodynamically stable patients with sustained monomorphic VT. If pharmacologic treatment is unsuccessful or if the patient develops signs of hemodynamically unstable VT, electrical cardioversion should be performed.

This patient has a history of myocardial infarctions and ischemic heart disease, which is the most common cause of VT.

Intravenous magnesium sulfate is the first-line treatment for hemodynamically stable patients with torsades de pointes (TdP), a type of VT that occurs in individuals with a prolonged QT interval. The characteristic ECG finding of TdP is polymorphic VT with wide QRS complexes that appear to be twisting around the isoelectric line, producing a spindle-shaped pattern. This patient's ECG shows monomorphic VT.

images.title: Torsades de pointes
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT; rate ∼ 200/min)
– QRS complexes are wide (∼ 280 ms) and appear to be twisting around the isoelectric line, producing a spindle-shaped pattern (best seen in V2; indicated by green ellipse).These findings are characteristic of torsades de pointes (TdP), a subtype of polymorphic VT.Note how the initial sinus rhythm converts to VT/TdP as a result of the R-on-T phenomenon (best seen in rhythm strip II): After the initial normal sinus complex (green overlay), a premature ventricular complex (PVC; red overlay) occurs in the downslope of the T wave, initiating a brief period of VT. After one further sinus complex, the phenomenon repeats itself and initiates a more prolonged period of VT/TdP.

answers.explanation_why: Synchronized cardioversion under sedation is the first-line treatment for patients with sustained monomorphic VT who are hemodynamically unstable but have a palpable pulse. This patient is hemodynamically stable, so a different approach is indicated. If the patient fails to respond to the initial treatment, electrical cardioversion should be performed.

An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) reduces the risk of sudden cardiac death in patients with recurrent VT despite management of reversible causes. An ICD is not indicated in the acute management of patients with VT. Patients with VT need to be investigated and treated for reversible causes before receiving an ICD.

Defibrillation and cardiopulmonary resuscitation are indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with pulseless VT or with polymorphic VT and a palpable pulse. This patient has sustained monomorphic VT and is hemodynamically stable, which confirms that he has a pulse, so defibrillation is not indicated.

images.title: Onset of ventricular tachycardia (1/2)
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)0 to 2.2 seconds:
– Sinus rhythm
– Rate: ∼ 55/min
– Axis: normal, between (-30°) and 0° (R > S in leads I and II, R < S in aVF)
– Normal narrow QRS complexes

2.2 to 4 seconds:
– Regular ventricular rhythm with atrioventricular (AV) dissociation (no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes). P waves are mostly obscured due to the high ventricular rate, but can occasionally be seen partially buried in the T wave.
– Rate: ∼ 160/min
– Axis: remains normal but has shifted rightwards, to between 60° and 90° (R > S in lead I, R < S in aVL)
– Wide (∼ 140 ms), monomorphic QRS complexes with LBBB morphologyThis ECG shows the onset of ventricular tachycardia (VT) following two beats of normal sinus rhythm. Monomorphic VT with LBBB morphology suggests a right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) origin.

question_text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-month history of chest pain, mild shortness of breath, and a dry cough. The chest pain is exacerbated by coughing and deep breathing. She is homeless and has not seen a physician in more than 20 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 33 years and drinks 3–4 beers daily. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 113/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination shows scleral jaundice, diffuse telangiectasias on the chest, and bilateral pedal edema. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion on the right side. Cardiac examination shows normal heart sounds with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is mildly distended and there is shifting dullness to percussion. The spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Based on the findings on CT scan, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-month history of chest pain, mild shortness of breath, and a dry cough. The chest pain is exacerbated by coughing and deep breathing. She is homeless and has not seen a physician in more than 20 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 33 years and drinks 3–4 beers daily. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 113/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination shows scleral jaundice, diffuse telangiectasias on the chest, and bilateral pedal edema. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion on the right side. Cardiac examination shows normal heart sounds with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is mildly distended and there is shifting dullness to percussion. The spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Based on the findings on CT scan, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The CT scan shows a large, hyperdense area on the right side of the thoracic cavity in a gravity-dependent position, which, in combination with this patient's clinical features (pleuritic chest pain, cough, decreased breath sounds, and dullness to percussion on the right side), is consistent with pleural effusion.
learning_objective: Recognize pleural effusion, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic procedure.

answers.explanation_why: Releasing the fluid in the pericardial space (i.e., pericardiocentesis) is appropriate in the management of pericardial effusion that causes cardiac tamponade. Pericardial effusion due to pericarditis can cause cough and chest pain exacerbated by coughing and deep breathing (similar to pleuritic chest pain). However, there is no evidence of fluid in the pericardial cavity on CT scan in this patient, and she lacks typical clinical features of tamponade (i.e., hypotension, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins).

images.title: Pericardial effusion
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; mediastinal window; axial plane)A pericardial effusion (green overlay) encircles the heart. Other findings include a small left pleural effusion (red overlay) and a left lower lobe nodule (yellow overlay).A: aorta; LV: left ventricle; RV: right ventricle

answers.explanation_why: For patients with symptomatic pleural effusions, drainage of the fluid is required for symptomatic relief. However, tube thoracostomy is typically reserved for the management of recurrent pleural effusions, and pleural empyemas. In patients with new unilateral pleural effusions, a different step in management is appropriate.

A patient with a new unilateral pleural effusion requires diagnostic thoracocentesis to obtain a pleural fluid specimen for diagnosis of the underlying etiology. The aspirated pleural fluid is analyzed (e.g., cytochemistry, cell count, pH, albumin, lactate dehydrogenase, glucose) and further categorized as a transudative effusion or an exudative effusion. Given this patient's smoking history and underlying cirrhosis, it is important to differentiate between hepatic hydrothorax (transudate) and malignant pleural effusion secondary to lung or liver cancer (exudate). In patients with large symptomatic pleural effusions, diagnostic thoracocentesis can be combined with therapeutic thoracocentesis to provide symptomatic relief.

Pleural fluid drainage is not required if the patient has bilateral pleural effusions that are asymptomatic, of equal sizes, suspected to be due to transudation (based on the presence of an underlying cause such as cirrhosis, cardiac failure, or nephrotic syndrome), and responsive to medical therapy (e.g., diuretics).

Initiating therapeutic anticoagulation is an appropriate step in the management of pulmonary embolism (PE), which can manifest with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and cough, and can cause a pleural effusion. However, PE manifests acutely, whereas this patient has had symptoms for the past month. Moreover, a CT scan would typically show a wedge-shaped infarction in the affected lung segment(s).

images.title: Pulmonary infarction
images.description: CT chest (with IV contrast; axial plane)A large pulmonary embolism occludes the right lower lobe pulmonary artery. It is accompanied by a nonenhancing wedge-shaped opacity (Hampton's hump) in the periphery of the right upper lobe that abuts the major fissure posteriorly and the pleural surface laterally.The CT findings represent pulmonary infarction secondary to pulmonary embolism.

answers.explanation_why: Beginning broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy is appropriate in the management of pneumonia, which can manifest with symptoms similar to those seen in this patient (e.g., dyspnea, cough) and can also cause pleural effusion (parapneumonic effusion). However, this patient's CT scan findings do not show typical features of pneumonia (e.g., localized hyperdense areas of consolidation, air bronchograms, ground-glass opacities). The etiology of this patient's pleural effusion should be established before starting antibiotic therapy.

images.title: Lobar consolidation
images.description: CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with a history of bacterial pneumoniaOpacification of much of the right lower lobe parenchyma is the result of air space consolidation. Pulmonary vessels are obscured and patent airways (air bronchograms, white dashed line) are seen. Consolidation extends to the major fissure (green overlay).Parenchymal opacification can be caused by fluid or solid material. Major causes in the acute setting include pneumonia, aspiration, edema, and hemorrhage. In the chronic setting, the main causes include invasive adenocarcinoma and alveolar proteinosis.

answers.explanation_why: Administration of diuretics (e.g., furosemide) is an appropriate treatment for hepatic hydrothorax due to cirrhosis, which could explain this patient's pleural effusion. Although this patient may require diuretics in the course of the treatment, another step precedes diuretic administration in this case.

images.title: Pleural effusion
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane; mediastinal window)A homogeneous low-attenuation pleural effusion (green overlay) is seen in the dependent right hemithorax. The upward concave configuration of the anterior margin of the effusion is the result of elastic recoil of the lung.AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; LA: left atrium; LV: left ventricle; RA: right atrium; RV: right ventricle

question_text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics 30 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest during an attempted robbery. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to person and place, but not time. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a knife in situ that enters the thoracic wall just above the 7^th rib in the left midaxillary line. The right lung is clear to auscultation; auscultation of the left lung and cardiac examination remain inconclusive as the patient does not tolerate being examined near the entrance wound. Abdominal examination shows mild diffuse abdominal pain without guarding or rebound. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Five minutes later, the patient becomes unresponsive. Repeat vital signs are temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 120/min, respirations 28/min, and blood pressure 88/50 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics 30 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest during an attempted robbery. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to person and place, but not time. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a knife in situ that enters the thoracic wall just above the 7th rib in the left midaxillary line. The right lung is clear to auscultation; auscultation of the left lung and cardiac examination remain inconclusive as the patient does not tolerate being examined near the entrance wound. Abdominal examination shows mild diffuse abdominal pain without guarding or rebound. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Five minutes later, the patient becomes unresponsive. Repeat vital signs are temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 120/min, respirations 28/min, and blood pressure 88/50 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has sustained penetrating chest trauma, which can result in a number of potentially life-threatening conditions (e.g., pneumothorax, hemothorax, hemopericardium, hemoperitoneum, organ laceration). Since the patient has become hemodynamically unstable (hypotension, tachycardia), speed and comprehensiveness in assessing and treating the underlying condition are essential.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate diagnostic test for a hemodynamically unstable patient with penetrating chest trauma.

answers.explanation_why: Emergency tube thoracostomy is the treatment of choice when hemodynamic instability is caused by tension pneumothorax or hemothorax. Tube thoracostomy should only be performed prior to establishing the diagnosis if there is strong clinical suspicion for the underlying condition (e.g., absent breath sounds on auscultation and hyperresonance to percussion in a patient with pneumothorax). This patient's auscultation findings remain inconclusive, so tube thoracostomy is not indicated at this point.

answers.content: Extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST)
answers.explanation_why: Extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST) is typically used during the primary ABCDE survey and subsequent reassessments of patients with penetrating chest trauma to establish a diagnosis and guide management. eFAST is especially useful for hemodynamically unstable patients because it is fast, comprehensive (includes views of the heart and both hemithoraces to detect cardiac tamponade, hemothorax, and/or pneumothorax), and can be discontinued at any point. In cases of hemodynamic instability where there is a strong clinical suspicion of cardiac tamponade (e.g., muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins) or tension pneumothorax (e.g., absent breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion on the ipsilateral side), emergency pericardiocentesis or tube thoracostomy, respectively, should not be delayed by imaging.

Pericardiocentesis is the treatment of choice for cardiac tamponade, which can result from penetrating chest trauma and manifest with hemodynamic instability. Pericardiocentesis should only be performed prior to establishing the diagnosis if there is strong clinical suspicion for this condition (e.g., muffled heart sounds on auscultation, distended jugular veins). This patient's cardiac auscultation remains inconclusive, so pericardiocentesis is not indicated at this point.

answers.content: Removal of the knife with direct pressure on the wound
answers.explanation_why: Penetrating objects often tamponade the wound, so removal can cause further hemorrhage. Removal should therefore only be performed in settings where definitive care is possible (i.e., by a surgeon in an operating room), preferably not in the emergency department.

answers.content: CT scan of the chest and abdomen
answers.explanation_why: CT scan of the chest and abdomen can be used to assess patients with penetrating chest trauma. It is important to consider concomitant intraabdominal injuries in cases of penetrating trauma below the nipples, which this patient has. However, CT scans should not be performed on hemodynamically unstable patients who are at risk of further deterioration while undergoing the scan.

question_text:
A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after she fainted during a morning walk. Her husband says that she regained consciousness after a couple of minutes. The patient reports a 12-hour history of sharp back pain. She is now experiencing dull abdominal pain. She also notes that her legs have felt strange since she woke up this morning. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled through diet. She smoked a half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but stopped 8 years ago. She does not drink alcohol. Her only medication is lisinopril. She appears in mild distress and is oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness. Femoral pulses are decreased bilaterally. ECG shows sinus tachycardia; chest x-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
9000/mm^3

Platelet count
250,000/mm^3

D-Dimer
550 ng/mL

Serum

 Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after she fainted during a morning walk. Her husband says that she regained consciousness after a couple of minutes. The patient reports a 12-hour history of sharp back pain. She is now experiencing dull abdominal pain. She also notes that her legs have felt strange since she woke up this morning. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled through diet. She smoked a half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but stopped 8 years ago. She does not drink alcohol. Her only medication is lisinopril. She appears in mild distress and is oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness. Femoral pulses are decreased bilaterally. ECG shows sinus tachycardia; chest x-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 12.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 9000/mm3 Platelet count 250,000/mm3 D-Dimer 550 ng/mL Serum Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's presentation should raise concern for aortic dissection, most likely involving the aortic arch and descending aorta. Syncope, a history of sharp back pain migrating to the abdomen, and evidence of perfusion deficit in the lower extremities (bilaterally decreased femoral pulses, leg paresthesia) are consistent with an aortic dissection that extends downward with successive occlusion of branching vessels (e.g., carotid arteries, abdominal arteries, femoral arteries).
learning_objective: Recognize aortic dissection, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test in a hemodynamically stable patient.

answers.explanation_why: Emergency open surgery is indicated for patients with aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta (Stanford type A); urgent surgery may be indicated in patients with aortic dissection involving only the descending aorta (Stanford type B) if there is evidence of malperfusion (e.g., hypotension). However, before proceeding to surgery, the diagnosis must be established and imaging is required.

Beta blockers (e.g., labetalol) may be used for hypertensive and/or tachycardic patients with confirmed aortic dissection if they are managed conservatively. Although these drugs can be administrated simultaneously while establishing the diagnosis in the case of a hypertensive emergency, this patient is hemodynamically stable and requires a definitive diagnosis first. Administering beta blockers prematurely before differential diagnoses have been ruled out may be harmful; e.g., it could lead to severe hypotension in a patient with a ruptured aortic aneurysm. Administration of beta blockers would also not be recommended if the patient required emergency surgery. A different step in management is indicated first.

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the diagnostic test of choice for patients with suspected aortic dissection and hemodynamic instability because of its rapidness, high accuracy, and ability to be performed at the bedside. However, this woman is hemodynamically stable and a different imaging modality can rule out or confirm aortic dissection (and other differentials) with even greater sensitivity and specificity; it also can assess the extension of dissections below the diaphragm, which TEE cannot.

images.title: Transesophageal echocardiography of aortic dissection
images.description: Echocardiography (transesophageal; transverse view)The descending thoracic aorta shows a crescentic false lumen and rounded true lumen.

answers.explanation_why: Diagnostic thoracocentesis is indicated for patients with pleural effusion if the etiology is unknown. However, this patient's presentation is consistent with aortic dissection as the underlying cause of her pleural effusion. Aortic dissection can lead to transudation of fluid to the pleural space, which is a nonspecific finding seen on chest x-ray.

Contrast-enhanced CT angiography (CTA) is the definitive diagnostic test of choice for aortic dissection in hemodynamically stable patients because of its high sensitivity and specificity, the speed and ease with which it can be conducted, and its widespread availability. A false lumen detected on imaging is consistent with aortic dissection. Further, nonspecific findings of aortic dissection in this patient include an elevated D-dimer level due to clot formation in the lumen and pleural effusion on chest x-ray. In this woman, CTA can also be used to rule out pulmonary embolism (which can lead to nonspecific symptoms and a high D-dimer level) and acute aortic occlusion (which can cause leg paresthesia and decreased femoral pulse).

For hemodynamically unstable patients or patients with contraindications to contrast agents (e.g., renal insufficiency), transesophageal echocardiography should be performed instead of CTA.

images.title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swellingThe ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 62 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Ethnicity: White
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “Check-up after recent heart surgery.”
History of Present Illness:

follow-up visit following aortic valve replacement with a mechanical valve 1 month ago 
currently asymptomatic
feels good and needs a physician's release to return to work letter

started going on 0.5-mile walks every other day last week

has not had fever, dyspnea, or chest pain

Past Medical History: 

hypertension
aortic valve stenosis
major depressive disorder
intermittent tension headaches
osteoarthritis of the knee
open-angle glaucoma
status post cholecystectomy due to recurrent cholecystitis in his 50s

Medications:

amlodipine
warfarin
aspirin
acetaminophen
sertraline
topical latanoprost

Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Psychosocial History: 

has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years

drinks one to two glasses of wine on weekends
does not use illicit drugs
lives with his wife and his 30-year-old son
works as a salesman in a local furniture retail store

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp.
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

36.9°C (98.4°F)

80/min
14/min
133/82 mm Hg
97%

165 cm
(5 ft 5 in)
72 kg
(159 lb)
26 kg/m^2

Appearance: no acute distress
Neck: no jugular venous distention
Pulmonary: clear auscultation over all lung fields
Cardiac: normal S_1 and S_2; soft systolic ejection murmur heard over the right upper sternal border 
Abdominal: soft; nontender; normal bowel sounds
Extremities: digital clubbing; 1+ edema of the lower extremities; dorsalis pedis and radial pulses intact
Skin: well-healed nonerythematous midline scar over the sternum; well-healed trocar-insertion scars 
Neurologic: alert and oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal neurologic deficits
Ophthalmologic: optic disc cupping; visual acuity 20/40 in both eyes

Laboratory studies

Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL

Leukocyte count
10,000/mm^3

Platelet count
150,000/mm^3

Serum

 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL

 Glucose
126 mg/dL

 Cholesterol

 Total
206 mg/dL

 HDL
45 mg/dL

 LDL
181 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate change in medication for this patient?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 62 years Gender: M, self-identified Ethnicity: White Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “Check-up after recent heart surgery.” History of Present Illness: follow-up visit following aortic valve replacement with a mechanical valve 1 month ago currently asymptomatic feels good and needs a physician's release to return to work letter started going on 0.5-mile walks every other day last week has not had fever, dyspnea, or chest pain Past Medical History: hypertension aortic valve stenosis major depressive disorder intermittent tension headaches osteoarthritis of the knee open-angle glaucoma status post cholecystectomy due to recurrent cholecystitis in his 50s Medications: amlodipine warfarin aspirin acetaminophen sertraline topical latanoprost Allergies: no known drug allergies Psychosocial History: has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years drinks one to two glasses of wine on weekends does not use illicit drugs lives with his wife and his 30-year-old son works as a salesman in a local furniture retail store Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp. BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 36.9°C (98.4°F) 80/min 14/min 133/82 mm Hg 97% 165 cm(5 ft 5 in) 72 kg(159 lb) 26 kg/m2 Appearance: no acute distress Neck: no jugular venous distention Pulmonary: clear auscultation over all lung fields Cardiac: normal S1 and S2; soft systolic ejection murmur heard over the right upper sternal border Abdominal: soft; nontender; normal bowel sounds Extremities: digital clubbing; 1+ edema of the lower extremities; dorsalis pedis and radial pulses intact Skin: well-healed nonerythematous midline scar over the sternum; well-healed trocar-insertion scars Neurologic: alert and oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal neurologic deficits Ophthalmologic: optic disc cupping; visual acuity 20/40 in both eyes Laboratory studies Hemoglobin 13.5 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,000/mm3 Platelet count 150,000/mm3 Serum Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL Glucose 126 mg/dL Cholesterol Total 206 mg/dL HDL 45 mg/dL LDL 181 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate change in medication for this patient?
hint: Because of his age, gender, cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., hypertension, smoking history), and borderline high LDL cholesterol levels, this patient has a high 10-year ASCVD risk with a calculated score of 20.3%.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate modification in pharmacotherapy for a patient with high ASCVD risk.

answers.explanation_why:
Patients aged 40–75 years with a high risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD) should be started on high-intensity statin therapy (e.g., with atorvastatin) regardless of their LDL levels, for primary prevention of ASCVD. Other indications for high-intensity statin therapy include LDL ≥ 190 mg/dL and/or a history of clinical ASCVD.

Statin therapy does not play a role in the progression of aortic stenosis, and this patient's recent history of aortic valve replacement is not an indication for treatment.

Non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulants (NOACs), such as apixaban, are preferred to warfarin for a variety of conditions because it is not necessary to monitor coagulation parameters (e.g., INR) during therapy. However, the safety and efficacy of NOACs in patients with mechanical valves have not been established, and their use is not recommended.

Metformin is the initial drug of choice in all patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Diagnostic criteria for diabetes mellitus include a random blood glucose level ≥ 200 mg/dL in patients with symptoms of hyperglycemia or two abnormal hyperglycemia tests (e.g., fasting plasma glucose) in those without symptoms. Although this patient has a glucose concentration of 126 mg/dL, he may not have fasted for 8 hours prior to this visit. Moreover, two abnormal test results are required for diagnosis in an asymptomatic individual.

answers.content: No change in medication is indicated at this time
answers.explanation_why: This patient is on appropriate therapy for his mechanical aortic valve. However, because of his high risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, a medication change is indicated at this time.

Furosemide is often used to treat volume overload in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF). Although this patient has 1+ peripheral edema, he has no other signs of CHF (e.g., symptoms of pulmonary congestion). His peripheral edema is likely an adverse effect of amlodipine, which causes precapillary vasodilation, increasing hydrostatic pressure. ACE inhibitors can be used to attenuate edema due to calcium channel blockers by causing postcapillary vasodilation, which normalizes hydrostatic pressure.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 57 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department 
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “It feels like I'm running out of air.” 
History of Present Illness:

dyspnea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain for 20 minutes

pain is rated 9/10
was watching TV when symptoms suddenly started
underwent surgery for total right knee replacement 3 weeks ago

Past Medical History:
osteoarthritis
Medications:
ibuprofen for knee pain
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Psychosocial history:

lives with husband
has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years

does not drink alcohol

Physical Examination 

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

38.2°C
(100.8°F)

112/min
24/min
88/55 mm Hg
92% on 4LNC

165 cm
(5 ft 5 in)
78 kg
(170 lb)
28.7 kg/m^2

Appearance: in acute distress, unable to lay back; feels lightheaded 

Neck: jugular venous pressure of 8 cm H_2O above the sternal angle; trachea is midline

Pulmonary: decreased breath sounds bilaterally; productive cough with blood-tinged sputum
Cardiac: tachycardia; split S2
Abdominal: obese; nontender to palpation; normoactive bowel sounds; no hepatosplenomegaly 
Extremities: mildly tender surgical scar on the right knee, no edema; tenderness and erythema of the right calf; radial and femoral pulses intact bilaterally
Neurologic: alert, fully oriented

Diagnostic Studies

ECG: sinus tachycardia; QRS duration 140 ms, rSR' waves in leads V1-V2, ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion in leads V1-V2

bedside echocardiography: mid-segment dilatation of the right ventricle, tricuspid regurgitation, increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure

CT scan of the chest: shown

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

hint: Orthopedic surgeries, such as a total knee replacement, often cause prolonged immobilization. This is a significant risk factor for venous stasis.
learning_objective: Recognize massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's CT scan shows evidence of a large pulmonary embolism (PE). In cases of massive PE with hemodynamic instability (e.g., SBP < 90 mm Hg), thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) such as alteplase is indicated. Because of the associated significant risk of bleeding, there are several relative and absolute contraindications to thrombolytic therapy. Surgery within the past 10 days is a relative contraindication, but this patient underwent surgery 3 weeks ago. Therefore, alteplase would be the most appropriate treatment. Anticoagulation with heparin, rivaroxaban, warfarin, or apixaban is also appropriate treatment for patients with PE. However, these agents are typically used in patients who remain hemodynamically stable.

Bumetanide is a diuretic used in the treatment of pulmonary edema. Pulmonary edema can manifest with dyspnea, cough, tachypnea, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect that is consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than the findings typically seen in pulmonary edema (i.e., ground-glass opacities and peribronchovascular interstitial thickening). In addition, administering a diuretic could be detrimental to a patient with hypotension.

Pericardiocentesis is a procedure used to treat patients with pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with PE, as opposed to a fluid-filled pericardial sac, which would be typical in a patient with tamponade. Furthermore, pericardiocentesis would pose a risk of myocardial or endocardial injury in a patient who does not have pericardial effusion.

Endovascular stent-grafting can be used in the treatment of type A (proximal) aortic dissection. Patients typically present with severe, tearing chest pain, hypertension, and asymmetric pulses. Hypotension, severe dyspnea, and cough are less common manifestations of type A aortic dissection. The patient's CT scan also shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than a tear in the aortic intima, which would be typical in a case of dissection.

images.title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swellingThe ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

answers.explanation_why: Tube thoracostomy is used in the treatment of tension pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than air in the pleural space with tracheal deviation, which is typical in cases of tension pneumothorax.

Piperacillin/tazobactam can be used in the treatment of pneumonia. Pneumonia can manifest with dyspnea and cough, and, in the setting of sepsis, even hypotension. However, jugular venous distension would not be expected in pneumonia. In addition, this patient's CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than parenchymal infiltrates and/or consolidation, which would be typical in a case of pneumonia.

Coronary angioplasty is used in the treatment of myocardial infarction (MI). MI can manifest with chest pain, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism. In addition, a CT scan is typically not diagnostic in cases of myocardial infarction.

images.title: Saddle pulmonary embolism
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)A large embolism burden is seen (green overlay), with extension across the bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk into the right and left pulmonary arteries.Straddling of the pulmonary trunk bifurcation by pulmonary embolism is sometimes referred to as saddle embolism.AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; E: esophagus; LMB: left main bronchus; LPA: left pulmonary artery; PT: pulmonary trunk; RMB: right main bronchus; RPA: right pulmonary artery; SVC: superior vena cava

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 65 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: "I have a sudden crushing pain in my chest.”
History of Present Illness:

sudden-onset anterior chest pain and lightheadedness for 20 minutes

pain rated 10/10
patient was gardening when symptoms started

Past Medical History:

hypertension
diabetes mellitus

Medications:

lisinopril
amlodipine
metformin

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
father: deceased at age 51 years from myocardial infarction
Psychosocial History:

lives with his wife
drinks one beer daily
does not smoke or use nonprescribed medications or other substances

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

36.8°C
(98.2°F)

110/min
20/min
80/50 mm Hg
97% on RA

185 cm
(6 ft 1 in)
87 kg
(192 lb)
25.4 kg/m^2

Appearance: agitated; in acute distress
Skin: diaphoretic
HEENT: PERRLA; ocular movements are intact
Neck: no jugular venous distention
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation; shallow breath sounds
Cardiac: tachycardia; S_1 and S_2 with no murmurs
Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender
Extremities: radial pulses 1+; femoral pulses 1+ bilaterally 
Neurologic: fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits

Diagnostic Studies

Blood

Hemoglobin
13.9 g/dL

 WBC count
6100/mm^3

Platelet count
210,000/mm^3

Serum

Lactate dehydrogenase
424 U/L

Troponin I
1.94 μg/L

D-dimer
570 ng/mL

ECG: sinus tachycardia; diffuse ST-segment depressions 

CT angiography of the chest: shown

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

hint: This patient has a Stanford type A aortic dissection, which has a high risk of rupture and requires immediate intervention.
learning_objective: Recognize Stanford A aortic dissection, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Labetalol is first-line medical therapy for patients with aortic dissection with hypertension. Labetalol is contraindicated in hypotensive shock.

Endovascular aortic stent implantation is indicated in patients with Stanford type B aortic dissection who develop complications (e.g., aortic rupture, renal failure, abdominal pain due to intestinal ischemia) and have a high risk of complications during open surgery. Endovascular stent grafts are not approved for Stanford type A aortic dissections.

Cardiac catheterization may be indicated before aortic graft replacement surgery in stable patients with Stanford type A aortic dissection and known or suspected coronary artery disease (CAD) to plan for possible concomitant coronary artery bypass surgery. Although this patient has risk factors for CAD (i.e., diabetes mellitus, hypertension, family history), he has hypotensive shock and is therefore unstable, so he needs immediate surgery instead of additional imaging.

Dobutamine is an inotropic medication with vasodilatory properties (inodilator). In patients with aortic dissection, inotropes should be avoided as they can increase shear stress on the aortic wall through increased force of ventricular contraction. Moreover, vasodilation can worsen this patient's hypotension. In patients with aortic dissection and hypotension, vasopressor support with norepinephrine or phenylephrine is recommended if the mean arterial pressure is < 70 mm Hg despite IV fluid therapy.

Emergency open aortic repair surgery with graft placement is critical in the management of ascending aortic dissections (Stanford type A) because of the high risk of complications such as aortic rupture, acute aortic regurgitation, myocardial infarction, and cardiac tamponade. Simultaneously to surgery, this patient requires management of hypotensive shock with IV fluids and, if necessary, vasopressors, as well as supportive care for pain and anxiety. Patients with uncomplicated dissections of the descending aorta (Stanford type B) can be treated conservatively with observation, blood pressure control, and analgesia unless complications develop (e.g., aortic rupture, renal failure, abdominal pain due to intestinal ischemia).

Elevated troponin I and lactate dehydrogenase levels indicate myocardial stress due to involvement of the coronary arteries, while D-dimer levels are commonly elevated in aortic dissection and may have prognostic value.

images.title: Classifications of aortic dissection
images.description:
Stanford classification
– Type A: dissection involves the ascending aorta or aortic arch
– Type B: dissection involves only the descending aorta (distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery)DeBakey classification
– Type I: dissection involves the ascending and descending aorta
– Type II: dissection involves only the ascending aorta (up to the brachiocephalic artery)
– Type III: dissection involves only the descending aorta (distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery)Surgical management is recommended for aortic dissections involving the ascending aorta (i.e., Stanford A and DeBakey types I and II). Medical management is recommended for aortic dissections involving only the descending aorta (i.e., Stanford B and DeBakey type III).

answers.explanation_why: Mechanical circulatory support with an intraaortic balloon pump (IABP) or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is indicated as bridging therapy in conditions with acutely reduced cardiac output (e.g., cardiogenic shock and refractory heart failure). IABP is contraindicated in Stanford type A aortic dissection and ECMO does not improve outcomes.

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit following surgical repair of a ventricular septal defect. On postoperative day 2, the nurse notes that he is more irritable and less responsive than the day before. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 210/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 84/52 mm Hg. He appears pale and diaphoretic. Capillary refill is delayed at 4 seconds. Cardiac examination shows muffled heart sounds with no murmurs. Breath sounds are clear bilaterally. Electrocardiography shows a narrow complex tachycardia at 210 beats per minute with regular RR intervals and retrograde P waves visible as small negative deflections immediately after the QRS complexes in leads II, III, and aVF. There is no response to vagal maneuvers and adenosine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit following surgical repair of a ventricular septal defect. On postoperative day 2, the nurse notes that he is more irritable and less responsive than the day before. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 210/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 84/52 mm Hg. He appears pale and diaphoretic. Capillary refill is delayed at 4 seconds. Cardiac examination shows muffled heart sounds with no murmurs. Breath sounds are clear bilaterally. Electrocardiography shows a narrow complex tachycardia at 210 beats per minute with regular RR intervals and retrograde P waves visible as small negative deflections immediately after the QRS complexes in leads II, III, and aVF. There is no response to vagal maneuvers and adenosine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This type of arrhythmia is most commonly seen in young children after cardiac surgery.
learning_objective: Recognize junctional ectopic tachycardia.

answers.explanation_why: Although ventricular tachycardia can cause hemodynamic instability, it is characterized by wide QRS complexes and AV dissociation, not narrow complexes and retrograde P waves following the QRS complexes.

Although atrial flutter typically manifests with a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia, the rhythm is atrial (often ∼ 300/min) with characteristic flutter waves, most visible in the inferior leads. In addition, atrial flutter often responds to AV nodal blockade.

Although sinus tachycardia causes a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia, it typically manifests with normal P waves preceding each QRS complex and a physiological rate increase (rarely > 180–200/min in young children) that is often triggered by fever, pain, or hypovolemia.

Junctional ectopic tachycardia (JET) is a potentially life-threatening arrhythmia most often seen in young children after cardiac surgery, particularly repairs involving the ventricular septum or near the AV node. JET originates from an automatic focus in or near the AV junction, resulting in a narrow complex, rapid, and regular tachycardia. Typically, retrograde P waves are seen immediately after each QRS complex, most clearly as negative deflections in leads II, III, and aVF. JET is notably resistant to AV nodal blocking maneuvers such as vagal stimulation or adenosine, distinguishing it from reentrant supraventricular tachycardias. An abrupt onset, hemodynamic instability, and ECG findings in a patient with recent cardiac surgery are characteristic of JET, which requires urgent identification and specific antiarrhythmic therapy to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

images.title: Junctional tachycardia
images.description: 12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)- Regular rhythm- Heart rate: ∼ 130/min- P waves immediately follow the QRS complexes (examples indicated with green arrowheads) and are inverted in I, II, aVF, and V_4–V_6 (retrograde P waves; examples indicated with red arrowheads).- Cardiac axis borderline normal/right axis deviation (isoelectric in I, R > S in aVF)- Narrow QRS complexes (∼80 ms)- Persistent S waveA regular, narrow complex tachycardia with retrograde P waves is suggestive of junctional tachycardia.

answers.explanation_why: Atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) is a common cause of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia in children and adults, typically resulting in a narrow-complex, regular tachycardia. Retrograde P waves may be seen, but AVNRT is a reentrant rhythm that relies on the AV node and is typically terminated by vagal maneuvers or adenosine.
